ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Reimbursement of expenses. 
Members of city boards or commissions and employees of the city shall be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred by the member and employee when such members and employees are required to be out of the city attending to the business of the city. Spouses, children and other family members are welcome at meetings, but the portion of the expenses attributable to them is not reimbursable, and shall be borne by them or the member. 
(Ord. No. 7, § 3, 5-12-44; Ord. No. 82-862, § 1, 6-21-82; Code 1958, § 2-14(c))  
Secs. 2-2—2-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— City council, art. 3; recall of officers, art. 6; initiative and referendum, art. 7. 
State Law reference— Compensation of officers in home rule municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 141.004. 
 
Sec. 2-26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-1983, § 1, adopted Apr. 2, 2012, repealed § 2-26, which pertained to compensation for attendance at meetings—mayor and derived from Code 1958, § 2-1; and Ord. No. 92-1200, § 2, adopted June 1, 1992.  
Sec. 2-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-1983, § 1, adopted Apr. 2, 2012, repealed § 2-27, which pertained to compensation for attendance at meetings—councilmen and derived from Ord. No. 7, § 2, adopted May 12, 1944; Code 1958, § 2-2; and Ord. No. 92-1200, § 2, adopted June 1, 1992.  
Sec. 2-28. - Extra compensation of officers prohibited; limited expense reimbursement permitted. 
(a)  Neither the mayor, nor any councilmember shall receive any salary, fee, or compensation, except as provided by ordinance as required by the City Charter, for any services rendered the city; nor shall they or any of them receive any compensation for any extra duties performed or services rendered to or for the city. 
(b)  The mayor and councilmembers shall be reimbursed only for actual bona fide official expenses incurred by the mayor and councilmembers when all or any of them are required to be out of the county attending to the official business of the city or when they incur the in-county cost, for the meal, at BCCA meetings. All other expenses and costs (including travel, food, and admissions) incurred in-county by the mayor or councilmember are to be paid by the mayor or councilmember. Spouses, children, and other family members are welcome at out of the county or in-county meetings, but the portion of the expenses attributable to them is not reimbursable, and shall be borne by them or the councilmember. 
(Ord. No. 7, § 3, 5-12-44; Ord. No. 82-862, § 1, 6-21-82; Code 1958, § 2-14(a), (b); Ord. No. 96-1373, § 1, 4-15-96)  
Sec. 2-29. - Vote required on application for alcoholic beverage on-premises permit. 
(a)  All applications for an on-premises alcoholic beverage permit shall be filed with the city manager or his designee. The city manager or his designee shall place such application on the agenda of a regularly scheduled city council meeting, said meeting to be not less than fifteen (15) nor more than thirty (30) days from the date of application, and shall post a notice of the meeting and the agenda item in at least one of the official newspapers of the city ten (10) days prior to the council meeting. 
(b)  The city council shall vote on each application for an on-premises alcoholic beverage permit, and shall send its recommendation to the county liquor control agent and to the county judge. 
(Ord. No. 78-673, § 1, 12-4-78; Code 1958, § 2-16)  
Sec. 2-30. - Joint public hearings with planning commission. 
(a)  Any public hearing required to be held by the city council may, after proper notice, be held jointly with any public hearing required to be held by the city planning commission, provided that such joint hearing shall be with respect to the same subject matter. 
(b)  Subsequent to a joint hearing of the city council and city planning commission, no action shall be taken by the city council prior to receiving the final report or recommendation of the city planning commission with respect to the matters considered. 
(Ord. No. 69-395, §§ 1, 2, 5-19-69; Code 1958, § 2-18) 
State Law reference— Notice of meetings held by governmental body, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6252-17, § 3A.  
Sec. 2-31. - Procedures for council inquiries and investigations. 
(a)  In exercise of its power to inquire and investigate in furtherance of its legislative function and supervisory powers, the council may conduct inquiries or investigations into matters set out in section 3.13 of the City Charter, to wit: into the conduct of any office, department, agency, officer or employee of the city and to make investigations as to municipal affairs. The council may authorize a subcommittee of the council to inquire or investigate matters outlined in section 3.13 of the Charter, or it may appoint a legally qualified person or persons to inquire or investigate such matters. 
(b)  A subcommittee of the council or a legally qualified person(s) appointed by the council to inquire or investigate matters that may be assigned by the council shall provide a report to the council of their inquiry or investigation findings and advise whether there may be a future need for legislation in the subject matters investigated. 
(c)  The council, a subcommittee of the council or a legally qualified person(s) appointed by the council shall have and be able to exercise all the powers outlined in section 3.13 of the City Charter, subject to the limitations set out herein, including the power to administer oaths to witnesses. 
(1)  In all investigations and inquiries conducted by the city council or any person or committee authorized by the council for the purpose of making investigations as to municipal affairs, the city council, by majority vote of its eligible members, shall for that purpose be able to authorize the subpoena of witnesses and compel production of books, papers and other evidence that is material to such investigation or inquiry in the same manner as is now prescribed by the laws of this state for compelling the attendance of witnesses and production of evidence in the municipal court. 
(2)  A witness who attends a proceeding under process is entitled to the same mileage and per diem as a witness who appears before a grand jury in the State of Texas, and to be paid by the City of Lake Jackson. 
(3)  The municipal court of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, shall be the forum for hearings concerning subpoenas and other matters under this section, and the Texas Rules of Civil Procedure shall apply to any such hearings or matters. There shall be a right of appeal from decision of the municipal court and said appeal shall follow the rules for appeals from municipal courts as outlined in the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(d)  All documents, books, papers and other document evidence, during the investigation, that is subpoenaed and received by the council, subcommittee of the council or a person(s) appointed by the council shall at all times be safeguarded and made secure so that there is no comingling with other documents and so that the documents are not lost. At the conclusion of the investigation, or the testimony, the evidence collected by the council, subcommittee, or person, may be returned to those witnesses who possessed the evidence if the investigative body or person determines that it is proper to return the material. Under oath testimony shall be taken in a forum open to the public. 
(e)  A person commits an offense if the person has been summoned as a witness to testify or produce papers and refuses to appear with no valid reason given. An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. 
(f)  The municipal court of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, shall be the forum for the prosecution of all violations of this section. 
(g)  (1)  The rules of evidence for any inquiry or investigation under section 3.13 of the Charter shall be the Texas Rules of Evidence. 
(2)  The rules of procedure, if not established herein, shall be the Texas Rules of Civil Procedure. 
(h)  (1)  The investigative body or investigator may require a person to testify or produce a document concerning a matter under inquiry unless the person claims that the testimony or document may incriminate him. 
(2)  If a person testifies or produces a document while claiming that the testimony or document may incriminate him, the person may not be prosecuted for any transaction, matter, or thing by using the testimony or document by which the person truthfully testified or produced evidence. 
(3)  A witness has a right to counsel while testifying before the Council or person investigating hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 97-1418, § 1, 5-19-97)  
Secs. 2-32—2-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference— Compensation of officers and employees, § 3.07(m); official bonds for officers and employees, § 3.12. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-46. - Cost of defense of city officers, employees to be incurred by city. 
(a)  As a matter of public policy, if any official or employee of the city, whether elected or appointed, is sued or made a defendant in a lawsuit in any court or forum for any reason arising out of the performance of the duties of office, which suit is based on an act or omission arising out of the good faith performance of the duties of such official or employee or within the scope and course of his employment for the city, and unless legal defense is otherwise provided by insurance coverage, the city shall indemnify and provide the public official or employee of the city with such legal defense, together with expenses incident thereto. 
(b)  If damages are recovered by the party bringing the suit in the nature outlined in subsection (a) of this section, and if such recovery stems from the performance of duties which are imposed upon such public official by law or by order of the city council, or the employee becomes personally liable for the payment of damages because of the good faith performance of his official duties or duties within the course and scope of his employment, the city council shall authorize the payment of such damages on behalf of such public official or public employee from the city treasury, provided such action on the part of the city council is authorized under the constitution and laws of the state. This section shall not apply to action for damages which are covered by insurance coverage of the employee, the city or the public official. 
(c)  The city council shall determine and make findings relating to whether such officer or employee was engaged in the good faith performance of his duties and acting within the course and scope of his employment at the time of the act or omission in question and shall not indemnify or provide the legal defense for any officer or employee found not to have been so acting. 
(Ord. No. 76-581, §§ 1, 2, 3-1-76; Ord. No. 88-1062, § 2, 2-2-88; Code 1958, § 2-15)  
Sec. 2-47. - Emergency action. 
Every officer, agent or employee of the city, while responding to emergency situations, is hereby authorized to act in such a manner as to most effectively deal with the emergency. This provision shall prevail over every other ordinance of the city and, to the extent to which the city has the authority to so authorize, over any other law establishing a standard of care in conflict with this section. Neither the city nor the employee shall be liable for any failure to use ordinary care in such emergency. 
(Ord. No. 85-993, § 1, 11-18-85; Code 1958, § 2-15.1)  
Secs. 2-48, 2-49. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 1.5. - CODE OF CONDUCT 
 
Sec. 2-50. - Policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city that the proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial and responsible only to the people of the city; that no officer, employee or member of any standing committee or board shall permit any interest, financial or otherwise, direct or indirect, or engagement in any business, transaction or professional activity to conflict with the proper discharge of his duties in the public interest; that public office not be used for personal gain. To implement such a policy, the city council deems it advisable to enact a code of conduct for all officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid, to serve not only as a guide for official conduct of the city's public servants, but also a basis for discipline for those who refuse to abide by its terms, the overriding interest being that officers and employees of the city shall at all times strive to avoid even the appearance of impropriety. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-51. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings subscribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Employee means any person employed by the city, including those individuals on a part-time basis, but shall not mean any independent contractor hired by the city. 
Officer or official means any member of the city council and any appointed member of a board, commission, or committee set up by ordinance, charter, state law or otherwise, on a temporary or permanent basis. 
Relative means any person related to an officer or employee within the first degree by consanguinity or affinity and shall include a spouse, father, mother, son, daughter, brother or sister. 
City council means the legislative and governing body of the city consisting of the mayor and council members. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-52. - Standards of conduct—Officers and employees. 
No council member, board member or employee of the city nor a relative of a council member, board member or employee shall: 
(1)  Have a financial interest, direct or indirect, in any contract with the city, nor shall be financially interested, directly or indirectly, in the sale to the city of any land, or rights or interest in any land, materials, supplies, or service. 
The above provision shall not apply where the interest is represented by ownership of stock in a corporation involved, provided such stock ownership amounts to that percentage of the corporation stock permitted by state law, (see 171.002(a)(1) of Texas Local Government Code [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 171.002(a)(1)]). 
(2)  a. 
Represent or appear in behalf of private interests of others before any agency of the city or any city board, commission or committee, nor shall he represent any private interest of others in any action or proceeding involving the city, nor voluntarily participate on behalf of others in any litigation to which the city might be a party. 
b.  Represent or appear in behalf of the private interests of others before the board, commission or committee of which he is a member, or before the city council or other board on an appeal from such board, commission or committee concerning such matter. 
(3)  Accept any gift, or favor from any person that might reasonably tend to influence him in the discharge of his official duties, or grant in the discharge of his official duties any improper favor, service or thing of value. 
(4)  Use his official position to secure special privileges or exemptions for himself or others. 
(5)  Disclose information that could adversely affect the property, government, or affairs of the city; nor directly or indirectly use any information gained solely by reason of his official position or employment for his own personal gain or benefit or for the private interest of others. 
(6)  Disclose confidential information. 
(7)  Engage in any outside activities which will conflict with, or will be incompatible with his position as an officer of the city, the duties assigned to him in his employment with the city, or in which his employment in the city will give him an advantage over others engaged in a similar business, vocation, or activity. 
(8)  In any planning or zoning matter which may appear before the planning commission or the city council, any commission member or city council member who has a financial interest in any property within two hundred (200) feet of the zoning request shall disclose the existence of such interest to the other commission or council members and thereafter abstain from voting in the matter and refrain from attempting to influence the vote of any other commission or council member. 
(9)  In the event that any matter comes before the planning commission or city council involving directly or indirectly the interest of a present business client/customer of any commission or city council member or the interest of a person or entity who has been a business client/customer of any commission or council member within the prior twelve (12) months and funds received by the commission or council member, or the entity for which he is employed, from past/present business client/customer amount to the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more in gross income during such twelve-month period and such fact is known to the commission or council member, then that commission or council member shall disclose the existence of such interest to the other commission or council members and thereafter abstain from voting in the matter and refrain from attempting to influence the vote of any other commission or council member. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-53. - Disclosure of interest. 
Any officer or employee, whether elected, appointed, or hired, who has a prohibited financial interest in any matter pending before the city, shall disclose such interest to other members of the city council, committee, commission or board, of which he is a member, or, in the case of an employee, to his supervisor and shall refrain from further discussion of the matter and shall not be physically present when the subject is discussed in Executive Session; and shall not vote on or participate further therein in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-54. - Contracts with the city/affidavit. 
All contracts in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) entered into by any person, corporation or entity seeking to do business with the city shall contain an affidavit executed by a legally authorized party to the effect that no person included within the ordinance defined term of "officer or employee" has or will have during the term of said contract, any prohibited interest as defined in section 11.02 of the City Charter and the Code of Conduct Ordinance of the City of Lake Jackson. The affidavit shall include an acknowledgment and acceptance by the affiant that the existence of a prohibited interest at any time during the term of said contract will render the contract voidable. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-55. - Violations—Council members. 
The failure of any city council member to comply with or who violates one (1) or more of the standards of conduct in this article, which apply to him, shall constitute grounds for reprimand. Such reprimand shall require a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the eligible council members. Offenses committed in violation of the City Charter shall be punished in accordance with the terms of the City Charter, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-56. - Violations—Appointed board members and employees. 
(a)  The failure of a board member to comply with or who violates one (1) or more of the standards of conduct in this code of conduct shall constitute grounds for expulsion, reprimand, or removal from office to the extent allowed by law. 
(b)  In the case of any employee of the city, disciplinary action and appeals therefrom shall be in conformance with procedures established by the City Charter and personnel rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Sec. 2-57. - Adoption of state statute. 
Section 171.001 et seq., [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 171.001 et seq.] as amended, being the statute which regulates conflicts of interest of officers of municipalities in the State of Texas, is hereby adopted and made a part of this code of conduct for all purposes with the provision that in the case of a conflict between the provisions of this code of conduct and the state statute, then in that event the more restrictive provision shall govern. 
For purposes of clarity and information Section 171.001 et seq. [V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, § 171.001 et seq.] is set out herein as follows: 
Section 171.001. Definitions. 
(1)  "Local public official" means a member of the governing body or another officer, whether elected, appointed, paid or unpaid, of any district (including a school district), county, municipality, precinct, central appraisal district, transit authority or district, or other local governmental entity who exercises responsibilities beyond those that are advisory in nature. 
(2)  "Business entity" means a sole proprietorship, partnership, firm, corporation, holding company, joint-stock company, receivership, trust, or any other entity recognized by law. 
Section 171.002. Substantial Interest in Business Entity. 
(a)  A person has a substantial interest in a business entity if: 
(1)  The person owns ten (10) percent or more of the voting stock or shares of the business entity or owns either ten (10) percent or more or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more of the fair market value of the business entity; or 
(2)  Funds received by the person from the business entity exceed ten (10) percent of the person's gross income for the previous year. 
(b)  A person has a substantial interest in real property if the interest is an equitable or legal ownership with a fair market value of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or more. 
(c)  A local public official is considered to have a substantial interest under this section if a person related to the official in the first degree by consanguinity or affinity, as determined under Article 5996h, Revised Statutes [Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 5996h], has a substantial interest under this section. 
Section 171.003. Prohibited Acts; Penalty. 
(a)  A local public official commits an offense if the official knowingly: 
(1)  Violates Section 171.004; 
(2)  Acts as surety for a business entity that has work, business or a contract with the governmental entity; or 
(3)  Acts as surety on any official bond required of an officer of the governmental entity. 
(b)  An offense under this section is a class A misdemeanor. 
Section 171.004. Affidavit and Abstention From Voting Required. 
(a)  If a local public official has a substantial interest in a business entity or in real property, the official shall file, before a vote or decision on any matter involving the business entity or the real property, an affidavit stating the nature and extent of the interest and shall abstain from further participation in the matter if: 
(1)  In the case of a substantial interest in a business entity the action on the matter will have a special economic effect on the business entity that is distinguishable from the effect on the public; or 
(2)  In the case of substantial interest in real property, it is reasonably foreseeable that an action on the matter will have a special economic effect on the value of the property, distinguishable from its effect on the public. 
(b)  The affidavit must be filed with the official record keeper of the governmental entity. 
(c)  If a local public official is required to file and does file an affidavit under subsection (a), the official is not required to abstain from further participation in the matter requiring the affidavit if a majority of the members of the governmental entity of which the official is a member is composed of persons who are likewise required to file and who do file affidavits of similar interests on the same official action. 
Section 171.005. Voting on Budget. 
(a)  The governing body of a governmental entity shall take a separate vote on any budget item specifically dedicated to a contract with a business entity in which a member of the governing body has a substantial interest. 
(b)  Except as provided by Section 171.004(c), the affected member may not participate in that separate vote. The member may vote on a final budget if: 
(1)  The member has complied with this chapter; and 
(2)  The matter in which the member is concerned has been resolved. 
Section 171.006. Effect of Violation of Chapter. 
The finding by a court of a violation under this chapter does not render an action of the governing body voidable unless the measure that was the subject of an action involving a conflict of interest would not have passed the governing body without the vote of the person who violated the chapter. 
Section 171.007. Common Law Preempted; Cumulative of Municipal Provisions. 
(a)  This chapter preempts the common law of conflict of interests as applied to local public officials. 
(b)  This chapter is cumulative of municipal charter provisions and municipal ordinances defining and prohibiting conflicts of interests. 
Section 171.008. Renumbered as Section 171.006 by Acts 1989, 71st Leg., ch.1, Section 40(a), effective August 28, 1989. 
Section 171.009. Service on Board of Corporation for no Compensation. 
It shall be lawful for a local public official to serve as a member of the board of directors of private, nonprofit corporations when such officials receive no compensation or other remuneration from the nonprofit corporation or other nonprofit entity. 
(Ord. No. 95-1354, § 1, 11-20-95)  
Secs. 2-58—2-65. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER[4] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-66. - Appointment. 
The city council shall appoint a city manager who shall be administrative head of the municipal government under the direction and supervision of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 1, 11-29-48; Code 1958, § 2-4)

Sec. 2-67. - Residence in city required. 
The city manager may or may not be a resident of the city when appointed, but during the term of his office shall reside in the city. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 2, 11-29-48; Code 1958, § 2-5)  
Sec. 2-68. - Term of office. 
The city manager shall be appointed for an indefinite period and shall be subject to discharge at the will of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 3, 11-29-48; Code 1958, § 2-6)  
Sec. 2-69. - Compensation as fixed. 
The city manager shall receive such compensation as the city council shall fix from time to time by ordinance or resolution. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 6, 11-29-48; Code 1958, § 2-7)  
Sec. 2-70. - Acting city manager. 
During the absence or disability of the city manager, the city council shall designate some properly qualified person to perform the duties of such office. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 4, 11-29-48; Code 1958, § 2-8)

DIVISION 4. - CITY TREASURER 
 
Sec. 2-106. - Office created. 
There is created hereby the office of city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 211, § 1, 1957; Code 1958, § 2-9)  
Sec. 2-107. - Qualifications. 
The city treasurer must have either the qualifications required of members of the city council as provided in the city charter or the qualifications required for city manager as provided in the city charter. 
(Ord. No. 211, § 2, 1957; Code 1958, § 2-10)  
Sec. 2-108. - Disposition of receipts and expenditures. 
The city treasurer shall receive and securely keep all moneys belonging to the city, and make all payments for the same upon the order of the mayor, attested by the secretary under the seal of the city. He shall render a full and correct statement of his receipts and payments to the city council once each month and whensoever, at other times, he may be required by them so to do. At the end of every year he shall cause to be published, at the expense of the city, a statement showing the amount of receipts and expenditures for the twelve (12) months next preceding, and the general condition of the treasury. He shall do and perform such other acts and duties as the city council may require. 
(Ord. No. 211, § 3, 1957; Code 1958, § 2-11)  
Sec. 2-109. - City manager may act. 
The city manager shall be the city treasurer, or at the direction of the city council, he shall appoint the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 211, § 4, 1957; Code 1958, § 2-12)  
Secs. 2-110—2-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - CITY COLLECTOR OF TAXES 
 
Sec. 2-126. - Bond. 
The city collector of taxes shall be required to give bond for the faithful performance of his official duties, such bond to be separate and distinct from the official bond of any other office. Such bond shall be in such amount as required by law. 
(Code 1958, § 2-13) 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 94.  
Secs. 2-127—2-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference— Boards and commissions, § 3.07(a), (f). 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-146. - Participation of members; vacancies. 
Membership on all city boards and commissions shall be accompanied by active participation in the activities of the commission or board and any member who is absent for three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the commission or board or whose overall attendance at regular meetings for any twelve-month period falls below seventy-five (75) percent, shall automatically be dismissed from membership unless the chairman of the board writes a letter or appears before the city council and informs the council of the reason why the member should not be dismissed, and the council decides to permit the member to continue to serve. Vacancies occurring in the commission or board, for whatever reason, shall be filled within thirty (30) days by appointment by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. Members of the commission or board shall be considered at will appointees. 
(Ord. No. 80-743, § 1, 7-7-80; Code 1958, § 2-17; Ord. No. 95-1338, § 1, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 98-1570, § 1, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 01-1677, § 1, 11-19-2001; Ord. No. 10-1939, § 1, 5-17-2010)  
Secs. 2-147—2-165. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYEE COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-166. - Established. 
There shall be established and maintained an employee commission of the city consisting of four (4) members, who shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 75-547, §§ 1—5, 2-17-75; Ord. No. 92-1200, § 1, 6-1-92; Code 1958, § 2-24(a))  
Sec. 2-167. - Members; term of office. 
(a)  One (1) member of the employee commission shall be a city councilman appointed by the city council to be appointed in each odd-numbered year; and three (3) members shall be elected, one (1) each from the department of police, salaried employees and hourly wage employees. The member from the department of police shall be elected in each odd-numbered year and the members from the salaried employees and hourly wage employees shall be elected in each even-numbered year. The appointment and elections shall be made or held each year within thirty (30) days following the regular election. 
(b)  The term of office of each such member shall be two (2) years. 
(c)  In addition, there shall be four (4) alternate members of the employee commission, consisting of a city councilman to be designated by the city council; and three (3) elected alternates, one (1) each from the department of police, salaried employees and hourly wage employees. The alternates shall be appointed or elected at the same time and in the same manner as the voting member. Alternate members shall have no voting rights, unless the voting member is absent and shall attend meetings as requested. 
(d)  Any city employee with the supervisory power to recommend hiring or firing of other employees shall not be eligible for membership of the employee commission and shall not vote in elections of members. 
(Ord. No. 75-547, §§ 1—5, 2-17-75; Ord. No. 92-1200, § 1, 6-1-92; Code 1958, § 2-24(b))  
Sec. 2-168. - Election process. 
Elections for positions on the employee commission shall be conducted by the city secretary under the same rules as exist in city elections to include: 
(1)  Candidates listed on a ballot in alphabetical order. 
(2)  Ballots numbered. 
(3)  Eligible voters on a voter's list. 
(4)  Secret ballot. 
(5)  If no candidate receives a majority of the ballots cast, then a runoff election shall be held immediately. 
(Ord. No. 75-547, §§ 1—5, 2-17-75; Ord. No. 92-1200, § 1, 6-1-92; Code 1958, § 2-24(c))  
Sec. 2-169. - Officers; rules of procedure. 
(a)  The chairman of the employee commission shall be the city council member or his alternate and the commission shall establish its own rules and procedures. 
(b)  A quorum shall consist of the majority of the voting members of the commission and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, except that on tie votes, the chairman's vote shall be determinative, the chairman being entitled to vote only on a tie vote. 
(c)  Meetings shall be held at least every six (6) months and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of city secretary. 
(d)  The substantial evidence rule shall be the standard or proof required, and the commission may meet in executive session on subjects for which such sessions are permitted under the Texas Open Meetings Act (Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6252-17). Other evidentiary and procedural rules shall be as chosen by commission. 
(Ord. No. 75-547, §§ 1—5, 2-17-75; Ord. No. 92-1200, § 1, 6-1-92; Code 1958, § 2-24(e))  
Sec. 2-170. - Duties. 
The employee commission shall be in the nature of an advisory and reviewing body reporting, if appropriate, to the city council in executive session or if not appropriate to the proper authority. The employee commission is not a quasijudicial body. The employee commission is empowered to perform the following duties: 
(1)  Hear complaints or grievances from workers in an informal (nonjudicial) atmosphere with regard to work environment, safety equipment or personnel and the commission may then make a recommendation to the proper authority. 
(2)  Review all activity relating to work stoppages and strikes and recommend appropriate punishment, if necessary, to the city council, or the proper authority. 
(3)  Study employee proposals for increases in pay and other benefits; present results of study and recommendations to, if any, to the city council. 
(4)  Study and entertain proposals for improving working conditions; present results of study and recommendations, if any, to the city council or the proper authority. 
(5)  Perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the city council shall from time to time authorize. 
(Ord. No. 75-547, §§ 1—5, 2-17-75; Ord. No. 92-1200, § 1, 6-1-92; Code 1958, § 2-24(f))  
Secs. 2-171—2-185. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LIBRARY BOARD[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference— Public library, § 11.05. 
 
Sec. 2-186. - Established. 
There shall be established and maintained a library board of the city, consisting of five (5) members who shall be residents of the city and who shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 79-687, § 1, 3-5-79; Code 1958, § 2-25(a))  
Sec. 2-187. - Appointment and term of members; ex officio members. 
(a)  All members of the library board shall be appointed by the city council, two (2) such members to be appointed in each even-numbered year, and three (3) such members to be appointed in each odd-numbered year, the appointments to be made each year within thirty (30) days following election. The term of office of each such member shall be two (2) years. 
(b)  In addition, a representative of the city manager shall be an ex officio member of the board and shall serve the board in an advisory capacity, but shall have no voting rights, and shall attend meetings as requested. The city librarian and the county librarian shall be invited to attend all meetings. 
(Ord. No. 79-687, § 2, 3-5-79; Code 1958, § 2-25(b))  
Sec. 2-188. - Officers; rules and procedures. 
A library board chairman and secretary shall be elected by the board annually. The board shall establish its own rules and procedures, which shall include the following: 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of the majority of the voting members of the board; and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, the chairman being entitled to vote upon all questions. 
(2)  Meetings shall be held as needed but not less than once each quarter; and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 79-687, § 4, 3-5-79; Code 1958, § 2-25(d))  
Sec. 2-189. - Representative to county commissioner's court. 
The library board shall nominate one of its members subject to appointment by commissioner's court of the county to be a representative to the county library board. 
(Ord. No. 79-687, § 5, 3-5-79; Code 1958, § 2-25(e))  
Sec. 2-190. - Duties. 
The library board shall be in the nature of an advisory and reviewing body, reporting to the city council. The library board is empowered to perform the following duties: 
(1)  Encourage participation of citizens' groups who are interested in contributing to a quality library in the city. 
(2)  Report on: 
a.  Furnishings. 
b.  Security. 
c.  Books. 
d.  Insurance coverages. 
(3)  Advise the city council and the city staff on the needs of the library, to include: 
a.  Maintenance. 
b.  Utilities. 
(4)  Establish policies for the use of the meeting rooms of the library (not to include the library proper). 
(5)  Represent the city at the county library board meetings and report back and communicate the actions and activities of the county board. 
(6)  Communicate with the county library board and the county libraries and branch librarian. 
(7)  Recommend and establish policies for the acceptance of gifts of materials and equipment (other than circulating materials and/or equipment) to the library in the name of the city as provided for in contract between the city and county. 
(8)  Recommend contract provisions between the city and the county library. 
(9)  Recommend library programs and changes in existing programs for the city. 
(10)  Advise the city staff and the city council on budget needs of the library. 
(Ord. No. 79-687, § 6, 3-5-79; Code 1958, § 2-25(f))  
Secs. 2-191—2-205. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference— Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission, § 4.09. 
Cross reference— Vandalizing beautification projects, § 62-10. 
 
Sec. 2-206. - Created; number of members; compensation. 
There is hereby created a beautification commission to be known as the Lake Jackson Beautification Commission for the restoration, preservation and enhancement of scenic beauty, consisting of eight (8) members who shall be residents of the city and who shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 73-495, § 1, 5-14-73; Code 1958, § 2-19)  
Sec. 2-207. - Appointment; terms; ex officio members; duties of director of parks and recreation. 
The members of the beautification commission shall be appointed by the city council, three (3) such members to be appointed in each even-numbered year and four (4) such members to be appointed in each odd-numbered year, the appointments to be made each year within thirty (30) days following the regular election. The term of office of each such member shall be two (2) years. In addition, the director of parks and recreation, as a representative of the city manager, shall be an ex officio member of the commission, and shall serve the commission in an advisory capacity, but shall have no voting rights and shall attend the meetings of the beautification commission. The director of parks and recreation as representative of the city manager shall also coordinate the activities of the beautification commission and those of the parks and recreation board and serve as a liaison between these boards and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 73-495, § 2, 5-14-73; Code 1958, § 2-20)  
Sec. 2-208. - Organization; rules of procedure. 
The beautification commission shall annually elect one of its members as chairman, and shall establish its own rules and procedures which shall include the following: 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of the majority of the voting members of the commission and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, the chairman being entitled to vote upon questions. 
(2)  Meetings shall be held not less than once each month, shall be open to the public, and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of city secretary and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 73-495, § 4, 5-14-73; Code 1958, § 2-22)  
Sec. 2-209. - Powers and duties. 
The beautification commission shall be and is hereby vested with the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies regarding the landscaping, the placement of trees, grass, shrubs, flowers and decorations within the corporate limits of the city, including public parks and private property used for public purposes. 
(2)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies regarding the aesthetic placement of all signs in the city, including signs used in the advertisement of businesses, products for sale, services for sale or for charity and political signs and posters. 
(3)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies regarding the control and elimination of junk yards and automobile graveyards within areas under the jurisdiction of the city. 
(4)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies concerning the aesthetic qualities that are involved in preserving and enhancing scenic beauty in planning and zoning the future development and redevelopment of the city. 
(5)  Initiate studies concerning the aesthetic placement of trees, grass, shrubs, flowers and decorations within the city and hold public hearings as necessary with regard to these studies. 
(6)  Perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the city council shall from time to time authorize. 
(Ord. No. 73-495, § 5, 5-14-73; Code 1958, § 2-23) 
Cross reference— Signs, ch. 78; solid waste, condition and use of premises, ch. 82; zoning, ch. 110.  
Secs. 2-210—2-225. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - KEEP LAKE JACKSON BEAUTIFUL COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Charter reference— Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission, § 4.09. 
 
Sec. 2-226. - Created, number of members, compensation. 
There is hereby created a Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission for the purpose of performing and carrying out the duties of the beautification commission as set out in the City Charter and assisting the city council in establishing a city-wide policy for landscaping and aesthetic improvements and for decreasing the amount of loose refuse in the city. The commission shall consist of five (5) or more members who shall be residents of the city and who shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 80-737, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 00-1633, § 1, 9-5-2000; Code 1958, § 2-27; Ord. No. 05-1789, § 1, 9-19-2005)  
Sec. 2-227. - Appointment; terms, duties of representatives and liaisons. 
The members of the Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission shall be appointed by the city council; half of the members shall be appointed each year within thirty (30) days following the regular city election. In the event of an odd number of members, the extra member will be appointed in even-numbered years. The term of office of each such member shall be two (2) years. In addition, a representative of the city manager, or any person appointed by the city council shall serve as liaison between the commission and city council, but shall have no voting rights. 
(Ord. No. 80-737, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 00-1633, § 1, 9-5-2000; Code 1958, § 2-28; Ord. No. 05-1789, § 1, 9-19-2005)  
Sec. 2-228. - Organization; rules of procedure. 
The Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission shall annually elect one (1) of its members as chair, and shall establish its own rules and procedures which shall include the following: 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of the majority of the voting members of the commission and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, the chairman being entitled to vote upon questions. 
(2)  Meetings shall be open to the public, and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of the city secretary and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 80-737, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 00-1633, § 1, 9-5-2000; Code 1958, § 2-30; Ord. No. 05-1789, § 1, 9-19-2005)  
Sec. 2-229. - Powers and duties. 
The Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission shall be and is hereby vested with the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies regarding the landscaping, the placement of trees, grass, shrubs, flowers and decorations within the corporate limits of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, including public parks and private property used for public purpose. 
(2)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies concerning the aesthetic qualities that are involved in preserving and enhancing scenic beauty in planning and zoning the future development and redevelopment of the municipality to include control and elimination of junk yards and automobile graveyards. 
(3)  Recommend to the city, for adoption, legislative changes with regard to the handling of solid waste or the control and elimination of litter, trash and waste materials. 
(4)  Conduct a continuous education program designed to change the attitude of all the citizens of the city toward the disposal of waste and to motivate citizens to keep their city clean. 
(5)  Encourage citizen involvement and participation. 
(6)  Encourage strict code enforcement. 
(7)  Introduce new forms of technology. 
(8)  Develop programs within the city government and community which will aid in the sustained reduction of litter. 
(9)  Periodically measure litter accumulation in the city. 
(10)  Make an annual report to the city council showing the activities of the commission and the Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful subcommittees for the current year. 
(11)  Initiate studies and undertake review of the waste problem in the city. 
(12)  Perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the city council shall from time to time authorize. 
(Ord. No. 80-737, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 00-1633, § 1, 9-5-2000; Code 1958, § 2-31; Ord. No. 05-1789, § 1, 9-19-2005)  
Sec. 2-230. - Subcommittees. 
To exercise the powers and accomplish the duties of the Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission, the commission may establish subcommittees including, but not limited to, the areas of business and industry, communications, community organizations, municipal operations and schools. Each subcommittee shall be chaired by a Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful member with an unspecified number of community volunteers chosen by the commission as working subcommittee staff. 
(Ord. No. 80-737, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 00-1633, § 1, 9-5-2000; Code 1958, § 2-32; Ord. No. 05-1789, § 1, 9-19-2005)  
Sec. 2-231. - Funding. 
Office space, supplies, telephone, postage and secretarial support for the Keep Lake Jackson Beautiful Commission shall be furnished by the city within the budgetary appropriation process. Additional funds involving travel or training shall also be supplied by the city within council-imposed budgetary restraints. However, supplemental funds for commission activities may be gained from donations. Such donations may be received by the city from the general public, business, industry, foundations and other sources for the purposes set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 80-737, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 00-1633, § 1, 9-5-2000; Code 1958, § 2-33; Ord. No. 05-1789, § 1, 9-19-2005)  
Secs. 2-232—2-234. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5.5. - YOUTH ADVISORY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-235. - Established. 
There shall be established and maintained a commission to be known and maintained as the Lake Jackson Youth Advisory Commission in the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, to serve as a liaison between the city council and the youth of the community. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97)  
Sec. 2-236. - Membership. 
The commission shall consist of at least eight (8) members who are between the ages of twelve (12) and eighteen (18) and are residents of the city. The members shall be chosen by the city council to serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97; Ord. No. 15-2078, § 1, 9-21-2015)  
Sec. 2-237. - Selection and appointment of members. 
All members of the commission shall be selected through an application process and shall be appointed by the city council and take office upon being sworn on their oath to uphold the duties of the office and the Constitution of Texas and of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97)  
Sec. 2-238. - Term of office. 
The term of office for each member shall run from August 1 to May 31 of each year. However, when a vacancy occurs prior to the expiration of a term, an appointment shall be made by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97; Ord. No. 15-2078, § 2, 9-21-2015)  
Sec. 2-239. - Officers. 
The commission shall have a chairperson, vice-chairperson, and secretary. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97; Ord. No. 15-2078, § 3, 9-21-2015)  
Sec. 2-240. - Function of commission. 
The function of the commission shall be to serve as a liaison between city council and the youth of the community on issues affecting youth by involving them in social, cultural, recreational, and other drug-free and alcohol-free activities. When requested by city council or the city manager, the commission shall give advice and assistance on matters concerning the needs of youth. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97)  
Sec. 2-241. - Meetings. 
The commission shall hold meetings at least monthly. The presence of a majority of the commissioners shall be necessary and sufficient to constitute a quorum, and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions. On tie votes, the vote of the chairman shall be determinative, the chairman in addition being entitled to vote on all questions. Minutes of meetings shall be kept and the record filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97; Ord. No. 15-2078, § 4, 9-21-2015)  
Sec. 2-242. - Authority to make recommendations. 
In the performance of its function, the commission is an advisory body authorized to make recommendations to the city council and the city manager on: 
(1)  Policy matters affecting the youth of the community; 
(2)  Planning, organizing, coordinating, and carrying out drug-free and alcohol-free social, cultural, recreational, achieving, educational, and other activities for the youth of the community; and 
(3)  Establishing guidelines, rules, and procedures for participation in such activities. 
(Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, 7-18-97; Ord. No. 15-2078, § 5, 9-21-2015)  
Sec. 2-243. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2078, § 6, adopted Sept. 21, 2015, repealed § 2-243, which pertained to written report; annual plan and derived from Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 1996; and Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, adopted July 18, 1997.  
Sec. 2-244. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2078, § 6, adopted Sept. 21, 2015, repealed § 2-244, which pertained to attendance policy and procedure; notification of vacancy and derived from Ord. No. 96-1361, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 1996; and Ord. No. 97-1425, § 1, adopted July 18, 1997.  
Secs. 2-245—2-247. - Reserved.
