DIVISION 6. - JOINT AIRPORT ZONING BOARD[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning, ch. 110. 
 
Sec. 2-251. - Created. 
Subject to like provision being made by the commissioners' court of the county and the City of Angleton, by proper order, duly promulgated and entered on its minutes, and as authorized by the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.014, there is hereby created a joint airport zoning board, to be known as the Brazoria County-Angleton-Lake Jackson Joint Airport Zoning Board, which shall have the powers and exercise the duties set forth in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 241.001—241.903. 
(Ord. No. 78-664, § 1, 7-10-78; Ord. No. 79-710, § 1, 8-20-79; Code 1958, § 2-26(a))  
Sec. 2-252. - Composition. 
The Brazoria County-Angleton-Lake Jackson Joint Airport Zoning Board shall be composed of seven (7) members, two (2) to be appointed by the city council of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas; two (2) to be appointed by the city council of the City of Angleton, Texas, and two (2) members to be appointed by the commissioners' court of Brazoria County, Texas. The seventh member shall be elected by a majority of the members so appointed and such seventh member shall serve as chairman of the Brazoria County-Angleton-Lake Jackson Joint Airport Zoning Board. The two (2) members appointed by the city council of this city shall serve two-year terms, or until their successors are appointed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 78-664, § 2, 7-10-78; Ord. No. 79-710, § 2, 8-20-79; Code 1958, § 2-26(b))  
Sec. 2-253. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - SENIOR CITIZENS COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-254. - Created; number of members; compensation. 
The commission shall consist of five (5) or more members who shall be residents of the city and who shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 99-1606, § 1, 8-2-99)  
Sec. 2-255. - Appointment; terms, duties of representatives and liaisons. 
The members of the senior citizens commission shall be appointed by the city council, half of the members shall be appointed each year within thirty (30) days following the regular city election. In the event of an odd number of members, the extra member will be appointed in even numbered years. The term of office of each such member shall be two (2) years. In addition, a representative of the city manager, or any person appointed by the city council shall serve as liaison between the commission and the city council, but shall have no voting rights. 
(Ord. No. 99-1606, § 1, 8-2-99)  
Sec. 2-256. - Organization; rules of procedure. 
The senior citizens commission shall annually elect one (1) of its members as chairman, and shall establish its own rules and procedures, which shall include the following: 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of the majority of the voting members of the commission and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, the chairman being entitled to vote upon questions. 
(2)  Meetings shall be held not less than once each month, shall be open to the public, and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of the city secretary and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 99-1606, § 1, 8-2-99)  
Sec. 2-257. - Powers and duties. 
The senior citizens commission shall be and is hereby vested with the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To recommend to the city, for adoption, legislative or administrative changes with regard to issues affecting or improving the quality of life for all citizens of Lake Jackson. 
(2)  To recommend to the city changes that will improve the quality of life and services to the senior citizens of Lake Jackson. 
(3)  To encourage citizen involvement and participation. 
(4)  To initiate studies and study new forms of technology. 
(5)  To develop programs within the city government and the community which will aid in improving the quality of life. 
(6)  To make an annual report to the city council showing the activities of the commission for the current year. 
(7)  To perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the city council shall from time to time authorize. 
(Ord. No. 99-1606, § 1, 8-2-99)  
Sec. 2-258. - Subcommittees. 
To exercise the powers and accomplish the duties of the senior citizens commission, the commission may establish subcommittees. Each subcommittee shall be chaired by a senior citizen commission member with an unspecified number of community volunteers chosen by the commission as working subcommittee staff. 
(Ord. No. 99-1606, § 1, 8-2-99)  
Secs. 2-259, 2-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-261. - Created; number of members; compensation. 
(a)  There is hereby created a hotel occupancy tax committee for the purpose of recommending to city council how to expend level 2 hotel tax funds. The committee shall consist of seven (7) members who shall not be compensated and who shall represent the following organizations: 
(1)  Brazosport Convention and Visitors Council; 
(2)  Brazosport Fine Arts Council; 
(3)  Museum of Natural Science at the Center for Arts and Services; 
(4)  Lake Jackson Historical Association; 
(5)  Hotels in the city; 
(6)  City of Lake Jackson staff (to be assigned by the city manager); and 
(7)  City council. 
(b)  It is preferred that the committee members be Lake Jackson residents, but it is not a requirement. 
(Ord. No. 17-2127, § 1, 3-6-2017)  
Sec. 2-262. - Appointment; terms. 
The members of the hotel occupancy tax committee shall be appointed by city council within thirty (30) days following the regular city election and shall serve two-year terms. Each organization or group listed in section 2-261(a)(1)—(5) may make a recommendation to city council as to who their representative on the committee shall be. 
(Ord. No. 17-2127, § 1, 3-6-2017)  
Sec. 2-263. - Organization; meetings. 
(a)  The hotel occupancy tax committee shall annually elect one (1) of its members as a chairperson. The committee shall hold meetings each month unless cancelled by the chair following meeting posting requirements. The presence of a majority of the committee shall be necessary and sufficient to constitute a quorum, and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, the chairperson being entitled to vote on all questions. Minutes of meetings shall be kept and the record filed with the city secretary. 
(b)  All meetings shall follow the Texas Open Meetings Act and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which record shall be filed with the city secretary and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 17-2127, § 1, 3-6-2017)  
Sec. 2-264. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The hotel occupancy tax committee shall have the power to and shall be required to: 
(1)  Hear requests for level 2 hotel occupancy funds and submit a recommendation to city council; 
(2)  Recommend allocation of level 2 hotel occupancy funds to city council; 
(3)  Recommend to city council a budget of expected revenue from and proposed expenditures of level 2 hotel occupancy funds for the next ensuing fiscal year; and 
(4)  Perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the city council shall from time to time prescribe. 
(b)  All recommendations for the allocating of level 2 hotel occupancy funds shall be for a lawful method of advertising the city or encouraging tourism, including preservation of historical sites, promoting visitation through attraction of conventions, and encouraging visitations to museums. 
(Ord. No. 17-2127, § 1, 3-6-2017)  
Secs. 2-265—2-270. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city to issue and sell bonds or notes, § 2.01; audit and examination of city books and accounts, § 3.14; municipal finance, art. 9. 
 
Sec. 2-271. - Selection of depositories. 
City depositories shall be selected by requests for proposals and the requirements of law. 
(Ord. No. 50, § 1, 12-14-47; Ord. No. 65-322, § 1, 12-6-65; Code 1958, § 20-7) 
State Law reference— Depositories for municipal funds, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 105; state and private banks as city depositories, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 342-901.  
Sec. 2-272. - Investment policy. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall have the authority to invest city money and shall be responsible for and be obligated to invest the money in investments that yield the highest rate of return while providing the necessary protection of principal consistent with state law. The city treasurer shall determine the highest or best rate of interest available by consulting the available financial services. 
(b)  The city treasurer shall invest local funds in any sources that are permitted under state law which provide the best combination of short term and long term interest rates. 
(c)  The city treasurer shall make projections of the city's cash on a continuing basis by forecasting both revenues and expenditures. 
(d)  Ninety-five (95) percent of the total funds available will be the goal for the amount of funds invested. 
(e)  At least four (4) times each year, the city treasurer shall prepare a signed written report to the city council concerning the city's investment transactions for the preceding quarter, describing in detail the investment position of the city as of the date of the report. The report shall be signed by the treasurer and delivered through the city manager to the council. 
(Ord. No. 80-729, § 1, 2-11-80; Code 1958, § 20-8) 
State Law reference— Public Funds Investment Act of 1987, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 842a-2.  
Secs. 2-273—2-290. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— Preservation and management of local government records, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 441.151 et seq.; Local Government Records Act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 201.001 et seq.; municipal records management, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.021 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-291. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Department head means the officer who by ordinance, order or administrative policy is in charge of an office of the city that creates or receives records. 
Director and librarian means the executive and administrative officer of the state library and archives commission. 
Essential record means any record of the city necessary to the resumption or continuation of operations of the city in an emergency or disaster, to the recreation of the legal and financial status of the city or to the protection and fulfillment of obligations to the people of the state. 
Permanent record means any record of the city for which the retention period on a records control schedule is given as permanent. 
Records control schedule means a document prepared by or under the authority of the records management officer listing the records maintained by the city, their retention periods and other records disposition information that the records management program may require. 
Records management means the application of management techniques to the creation, use, maintenance, retention, preservation and disposal of records for the purposes of reducing the costs and improving the efficiency of recordkeeping. The term includes the development of records control schedules, the management of filing and information retrieval systems, the protection of essential and permanent records, the economical and space-effective storage of inactive records, control over the creation and distribution of forms, reports and correspondence, and the management of micrographics and electronic and other records storage systems. 
Records management officer means the person designated in section 2-295. 
Records management plan means the plan developed under section 2-296. 
Retention period means the minimum time that must pass after the creation, recording, or receipt of a record, or the fulfillment of certain actions associated with a record, before it is eligible for destruction. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-61) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions pertaining to local government records, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 201.003, and V.T.C.A., Government Code § 441.151.  
Sec. 2-292. - Records affected; procedures generally. 
All documents, papers, letters, books, maps, photographs, sound or video recordings, microfilm, magnetic tape, electronic media, or other information recording media, regardless of physical form or characteristic and regardless of whether public access to it is open or restricted under the laws of the state, created or received by the city or any of its officers or employees pursuant to law or in the transaction of public business are hereby declared to be the records of the city and shall be created, maintained, and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this article or procedures authorized by it unless otherwise directed by law. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-60)  
Sec. 2-293. - City records declared public property. 
All city records are hereby declared to be the property of the city. No city official or employee has, by virtue of his or her position, any personal or property right to such records even though he may have developed or compiled them. The unauthorized destruction, removal from files, or use of such records is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-62) 
State Law reference— Declaration of local government records as public property, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 201.005.  
Sec. 2-294. - Policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to provide for efficient, economical and effective controls over the creation, distribution, organization, maintenance, use and disposition of all city records through a comprehensive system of integrated procedures for the management of records from their creation to their ultimate disposition, consistent with the requirements of the Local Government Records Act (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, ch. 201 et seq.), the Texas Government Code, and accepted records management practice under Texas law. 
(1)  Definitions: 
a.  Confidential documents or information means information considered confidential by law, either constitutional, statutory or by judicial decision as set out in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 552.101. 
b.  Exempt documents or information means information considered to be excepted from disclosure under V.T.C.A., Government Code, §§ 552.101 through 552.123. 
(2)  Guidelines. To further implement this policy the following guidelines are adopted: 
a.  The city manager shall be the official in the city to whom shall be made all open records requests or requests for city documents. 
b.  The city manager shall maintain a file of, or access to, all public, exempt and confidential city documents. All other public officials should keep the city manager informed of materials in their possession that they believe are exempt or confidential under the Open Records Act. 
c.  The city attorney should be consulted, both by the city manager and other city officials, whenever that official comes into possession of materials that might be considered exempt or confidential under the Open Records Act. 
1.  Any information that relates to pending or prospective litigation should be clearly marked as such. The attorney, rather than the city manager, must then decide whether that litigation material should be exempt from public disclosure. 
2.  All documents that contain information that is confidential under the law should be clearly marked as confidential. Although some information contained in these records may not, in fact, be confidential (that is, the document may contain some purely factual information that is not privileged and thus must be distributed to the public upon a proper request under the Act), all documents containing privileged information should be carefully perused by the city attorney before being publicly distributed. The city attorney may request an attorney general opinion within ten (10) days after receiving an open records request if he is uncertain as to whether specific information should or should not be publicly distributed. 
3.  All documents that contain attorney-client confidential information should be clearly marked as such to avoid any misunderstandings, attorney advice, recommendations or opinions should be contained in documents drafted directly by the city attorney, not the city manager or any other public official. Confidential client communications from city council members or the city manager should also be labeled "Attorney-Client Confidential Communication." 
4.  All confidential documents that are distributed to city council members in executive session and whose release would cause the City of Lake Jackson harm should be collected by the city attorney or the city manager after each executive session and kept safe by the appropriate official. 
d.  All open records requests for city council information shall be made to the city manager. 
e.  If any person requests official city materials from any other public official, the public official should direct that person to the city manager. No city council member shall distribute city council documents or any city records to the public on his own initiative. Such requests for documents shall be referred to the city manager. Council members who violate this provision are in violation of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 552.201 and with regard to confidential material are subject to the penalties established in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 552.352. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-63; Ord. No. 98-1551, § 1, 3-17-98) 
State Law reference— Purpose of Local Government Records Act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 201.002.  
Sec. 2-295. - Designation of officer. 
The city manager shall designate an individual, employed by the city, to serve as records management officer for the city. Upon the resignation, retirement, dismissal or removal by action of the city manager of the individual so designated, the city manager shall promptly designate another individual to serve as records management officer. The individual designated as records management officer shall file his name with the director and librarian within thirty (30) days of the date of designation, as provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-64) 
State Law reference— Designation of records management officer, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.025.  
Sec. 2-296. - Plan to be developed; approval of plan; authority of plan. 
(a)  The records management officer shall develop a records management plan for the city for submission to the city. The plan must contain policies and procedures designed to reduce the costs and improve the efficiency of recordkeeping, to adequately protect the essential records of the city, and to properly preserve those records of the city that are of historical value. The plan must be designed to enable the records management officer to carry out his duties prescribed by state law and this article effectively. 
(b)  Once approved by the city the records management plan shall be binding on all offices, departments, divisions, programs, commissions, bureaus, boards, committees or similar entities of the city and records shall be created, maintained, stored, microfilmed or disposed of in accordance with the plan. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-65) 
State Law reference— Custodians of records required to participate in records management program, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.022(b); records management program to be established, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.026.  
Sec. 2-297. - Duties of records management officer. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article or by law, the records management officer shall: 
(1)  Administer the records management program and provide assistance to department heads in its implementation; 
(2)  Plan, formulate and prescribe records disposition policies, systems, standards and procedures; 
(3)  In cooperation with department heads identify essential records and establish a disaster plan for each city office and department to ensure maximum availability of the records in order to reestablish operation quickly and with minimum disruption and expense; 
(4)  Develop procedures to ensure the permanent preservation of the historically valuable records of the city; 
(5)  Establish standards for filing and storage equipment and for recordkeeping supplies; 
(6)  Study the feasibility of and, if appropriate, establish a uniform filing system and a forms design and control system for the city; 
(7)  Provide records management advice and assistance to all city departments by preparation of a manual of procedure and policy and by on-site consultation; 
(8)  Monitor records retention schedules and administrative rules issued by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission to determine if the records management program and the city's records control schedules are in compliance with state regulations; 
(9)  Disseminate to the city and department heads information concerning state laws and administrative rules relating to local government records; 
(10)  Ensure that the maintenance, preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition of the city is carried out in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program and the requirements of state law; 
(11)  Maintain records on the volume of records destroyed under approved records control schedules, the volume of records microfilmed or stored electronically, and the estimated cost and space savings as the result of such disposal or disposition; 
(12)  Report annually to the city the implementation of the records management plan in each department of the city, including summaries of the statistical and fiscal data compiled under subsection (13) of this section; and 
(13)  Bring to the attention of the city noncompliance by department heads or other city personnel with the policies and procedures of the records management program or the Local Government Records Act (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 201 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-66) 
State Law reference— Duties of records management officer, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.023.  
Sec. 2-298. - Duties and responsibilities of department heads. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article, department heads shall: 
(1)  Cooperate with the records management officer in carrying out the policies and procedures established in the city for the efficient and economical management of records and in carrying out the requirements of this article. 
(2)  Adequately document the transaction of government business and the services, programs, and duties for which the department head and his staff are responsible. 
(3)  Maintain the records in his care and carry out their preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition only in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program of the city and the requirements of this article and state law. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-67)  
Sec. 2-299. - Electronic information records management. 
(a)  Storage schedules and compliance. Records retention schedules apply regardless of the recording or storage media. Electronically stored records require special diligence because their creation, storage and destruction are often automated and may be performed by another function. 
The retention schedules mandated by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission are adopted as the schedules for the City of Lake Jackson. 
(b)  Internet services. Internet services provided by the City of Lake Jackson are to be provided in accordance with the City of Lake Jackson's Acceptable Use Guidelines for Internet Services, prepared under the authority of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 98-1551, § 2, 3-17-98)  
Sec. 2-300. - Records control schedules to be developed; approval; filing with state. 
(a)  The records management officers in cooperation with department heads shall prepare records control schedules on a department by department basis listing all records created or received by the department and the retention period for each record. Records control schedules shall also contain such other information regarding the disposition of the city records as the records management plan may require. 
(b)  Each records control schedule shall be monitored and amended as needed by the records management officer on a regular basis to ensure that it is in compliance with records retention schedules issued by the state and that it continues to reflect the recordkeeping procedures and needs of the department and the records management program of the city. 
(c)  Before its adoption a records control schedule or amended schedule for a department must be approved by the department head. 
(d)  Before its adoption a records control schedule must be submitted to and accepted for filing by the director and librarian as provided by state law. If a schedule is not accepted for filing, the schedule shall be amended to make it acceptable for filing. The records management officer shall submit the records control schedules to the director and librarian. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-68; Ord. No. 98-1551, § 3, 3-17-98) 
State Law reference— Records control schedules, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.041 et seq.; records retention schedules, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 441.158.  
Sec. 2-301. - Implementation of records control schedules; destruction of records under schedule. 
(a)  A records control schedule for a department that has been approved and adopted under section 2-296 shall be implemented by department heads according to the policies and procedures of the records management plan. 
(b)  A record whose retention period has expired on a records control schedule shall be destroyed unless an open records request is pending on the record, the subject matter of the record is pertinent to the pending lawsuit, or the department head requests in writing to the city manager that the record be retained for an additional period. 
(c)  Prior to the destruction of a record under an approved records control schedule, authorization for the destruction must be obtained by the records management officer from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-69; Ord. No. 98-1551, § 3, 3-17-98) 
State Law reference— Retention periods, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 203.042.  
Sec. 2-302. - Records center. 
A records center, developed pursuant to the plan required by section 2-296, shall be under the direct control and supervision of the records management officer. Policies and procedures regulating the operations and use of the records center shall be contained in the records management plan developed under section 2-296. 
(Ord. No. 90-1142, § 1, 11-19-90; Code 1958, § 2-70; Ord. No. 98-1551, § 3, 3-17-98)  
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, adopted Jan. 5, 2009, amended Ch. 10 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 10 pertained to similar subject matter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18; keeping certain animals as nuisance, § 38-28; barking dogs, § 38-57; health and sanitation, ch. 50; removal of dead animals by city, § 82-74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98; zoning, ch. 110. 
State Law reference— Local Public Health Reorganization Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 121.001 et seq.; animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.001 et seq.; dangerous dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.001 et seq.; Rabies Control Act of 1981, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.001 et seq.; livestock, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code § 141.001 et seq.; permitting a head of cattle or a domestic turkey to run at large in certain counties, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code § 143.082; cruelty to animals, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.11; dog fighting, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.111; certain tax exemptions for charitable organizations, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.18. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Court means the Lake Jackson Municipal Court. 
Destructive animal means an animal, while not on its owner's property, that injures or kills a domestic animal. 
Domestic animal means any animal which is not livestock, not prohibited, and commonly kept as pets at the owner's residence, including, but not limited to, dogs, cats, fish, reptiles, and small caged rodents. 
Feral cat means a domestic cat that exists in an untamed state, either from birth or due to reversion to a wild state from domestication. 
Fowl means domesticated birds commonly kept for eggs or meat, including, but not limited to, chickens, ducks, geese, and turkeys. 
Handler means a person having control or custody of the animal. 
Injure means a wound characterized by bite wounds or ripping and tearing of skin or muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent animal owner to take the animal to a veterinarian. 
Livestock means any farm animal commonly kept for pleasure or profit, including, but not limited to, swine, cattle, horses, sheep, goats, chickens, ducks, geese, and rabbits. 
Nuisance animal means an animal that: 
(1)  Molests people; 
(2)  Attacks other animals; 
(3)  Is repeatedly at large; 
(4)  Damages private or public property other than that of the animal's owner; 
(5)  Repeatedly barks, yelps, whines, howls or makes any other sound loud and long enough to unreasonably disturb the peace of other people in the neighborhood; 
(6)  Creates an offensive odor; 
(7)  Creates a health hazard; or 
(8)  Deposits body waste upon public property or private property other than that of the animal's owner. 
Owner means any person who owns, keeps, maintains, possesses, harbors, feeds, shelters, or allows to remain on a premises under his control one (1) or more animals. 
Shelter means the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. 
Tying and staking means the securing of an animal by a leash or lead. 
Unrestrained animal means any animal, excluding cats, that is not inside a fenced yard; at the end of a leash controlled by a responsible person; in a house, apartment or a completely enclosed cage; or tied or staked upon open or unfenced land. 
Wild animal means and includes any wild mammal, amphibian, reptile or fowl which is not naturally tame or gentle, but is of a wild nature or disposition and which, because of its size, vicious nature or other characteristics would constitute a danger to human life or property if not kept or maintained in a safe manner or in secure quarters. Such animals shall include, but not be limited to, tigers, lions, bobcats, ocelots, cougars, leopards, panthers, bears, wolves, alligators, crocodiles, apes, foxes, elephants, rhinoceri, hippopotami, monkeys, skunks, all forms of poisonous reptiles and other like animals, or any other animal usually confined to cages. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, §§ 3-7(d), 3-22(a); Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009; Ord. No. 17-2126, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-2. - Protection of birds. 
(a)  The entire area within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as a bird refuge. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to intentionally destroy the eggs or nests of any wild bird or fowl in the city. 
(c)  It is an exception to the application of this section if the destruction of the eggs or nest occurs as an unintended consequence of an otherwise lawful activity, such as trimming or clearing of trees or shrubbery. 
(d)  Provided, however, if European starlings, English house sparrows, grackles, red-winged blackbirds, cowbirds, feral rock pigeons (Columba livia) or crows are found to be congregating in such number in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property, in the opinion of the city health officer, then such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by said health officer under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-26; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Protection of nongame birds, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 64.002.  
Sec. 10-3. - Penalty. 
Any person found guilty of violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-28; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-4—10-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
 
Sec. 10-31. - Humane officer; appointment, function. 
The city manager shall appoint for a period to be terminated at his pleasure a qualified person to act in the capacity of city humane officer, whose duty it shall be to see that the provisions of this chapter and any other city ordinance relating to the control of animals are enforced. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-1; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-32. - Enforcement; interference with officers. 
(a)  The city humane officer or any police officer of this city having probable cause to believe that a violation of this chapter has occurred, shall have the right to enter upon all yards or other outside areas within the city in the course of enforcement for the purpose of impounding an animal or issuing a citation, or both. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as to authorize the humane officer to enter dwellings or buildings attached thereto without the consent of the owner or person in control of such dwelling. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to interfere with or oppose or resist the chief of police or any of his officers, the humane officer or his deputies, or the city health officer or his deputies while such officers are engaged in the performance of the duties pertaining to the enforcement of this chapter. All police, humane, and health officers, deputies and employees are empowered to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-2; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-33—10-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - KEEPING ANIMALS GENERALLY  
DIVISION 1. - CARE AND CONFINEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-2126, § 2, adopted Feb. 6, 2017, added Div. 1 title for existing §§ 10-81—10-86 to facilitate inclusion of new Div. 2, §§ 10-91—10-94, as set out herein. 
 
Sec. 10-81. - Animal care; cruelty. 
(a)  No owner shall fail to provide his animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper protection from the weather, veterinary care, when needed to prevent suffering, and with humane care and treatment. 
(b)  No person shall beat, cruelly ill treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal, including a wild animal, or cause, instigate or permit any combat between animals and humans or another animal. 
(c)  No owner of an animal shall abandon such animal. 
(d)  Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal shall stop at once and render such assistance as may be possible and shall immediately report such injury or death to the animal's owner; if the owner cannot be ascertained and located, such operator shall at once report the accident to the police department. 
(e)  If an animal is found in an enclosed vehicle without adequate ventilation and is in distress, an animal control officer, police officer, or personnel of the fire department may use reasonable force to remove the animal from the vehicle and the owner of the animal shall be subject to fine. Neither the city nor any of its employees will be held responsible for any damage done to the vehicle during the attempt to remove the animal from the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-17; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.09.  
Sec. 10-81.1. - Tying and staking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to tie or stake any animal unless: 
(1)  The tying or staking is accomplished by providing an overhead cable onto which is attached a lead or leash that allows the animal to be free to travel unrestricted between the extreme terminations of the overhead cable and the lead or leash is of sufficient length to allow the animal to move about laterally from the overhead cable without the possibility of strangulation but not so long to allow it to wrap around or become entangled on any obstacles that may restrict the movement of the animal; or 
(2)  The at-grade tying and staking systems include posts or rod stakes with three hundred sixty-degree swivels to which the lead is attached and cable hoop and lead wherein the lead is free to slide three hundred sixty (360) degrees around the cable hoop which is placed around a tree or fixed post and without the possibility of strangulation but not so long to allow it to wrap around or become entangled on any obstacles that may restrict the movement of the animal. 
(b)  Within the range of travel of the lead or leash, the animal shall be provided ready access to water, food, shade and shelter. 
(Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-82. - Use of poisons. 
No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that the same shall be liable to be eaten by any animal. It shall not be unlawful for any person to expose on his own property common rat poison mixed only with vegetable substances. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-18; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-82.1. - Feeding of unlicensed animals prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to cause or permit the maintenance of an attractive environment for any dog, cat or other animal, by the placement of food or other means, when the animal is not confined inside a fenced or otherwise restrictive area, and the animal is not licensed as provided herein. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the person placed the food or other attractive environment solely for the purpose of apprehending an animal for surrender to a humane organization or to the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 05-1786; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-83. - Sanitation of quarters. 
(a)  The premises or place in which any animal is kept or harbored shall be at all times maintained in a sanitary manner. It shall be the duty of the health officer of the city and of the humane officer and the assistant humane officers of the city to, from time to time, visit the premises where any animal is kept or harbored in the city and report any such violation of this section respecting the sanitary conditions of such premises to the health officer of the city. 
(b)  When the health officer or humane officer, upon inspection of any premises or place where any animal is kept or harbored shall find that unsanitary conditions exist, he shall notify the owner, lessor or lessee of the premises or place and give notice to such person to remedy and make sanitary the condition within three (3) days. Any owner, lessor or lessee of a premises or place determined to be unsanitary by the health officer and who does not remedy the condition within three (3) days after official notification, shall be subject to section 1-5 of this Code for harboring a nuisance. 
(c)  The health officer or humane officer shall notify the owner, lessor, or lessee of the unsanitary conditions in writing and deliver such writing either in person or through certified mail. If the certified mail is returned "refused" or "unclaimed", the notice shall be valid and deemed delivered. 
(d)  In the municipal court, the owner, lessor or lessee shall be considered a prima facie violator of this section if the health officer determines that unsanitary conditions exist and the condition is not made sanitary to the satisfaction of the health officer within three (3) days of notification. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-19; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-84. - Wild animals; caging; prohibition against running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to lead or permit any animal of a species that is generally vicious and wild in nature to walk, run, parade, tour, sit or be tied in a public place outside a secure cage without permission of city council. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to keep or harbor any wild animal within the city unless prior permission is gained from city council and unless the same is kept in a cage in a safe manner and in secure quarters. 
(c)  Secure quarters shall mean a completely enclosed cage or a cage with a stake for tying any member of the cat family or shall mean a chain link fence or wall of sufficient height and strength to keep other animals within a confined private area. 
(d)  Any wild animal found loose outside the confined private area is prima facie evidence that the owner or handler did not keep the wild animal in a safe manner or in secure quarters. 
(e)  Secure quarters shall not mean the passenger section of an automobile, truck or other motorized vehicle operated, parked or used on a public street or in a public area, nor shall it mean the hauling area of a truck or trailer unless the area is caged with chain link fence. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for anyone who owns, raises, keeps or is caring for any wild animal to allow the same to be at large outside of its secure quarters or cage. The fact that such animal is discovered outside of the secure quarters or cage, is prima facie evidence that the person who owns, raises, keeps or cares for the same allowed it to roam at large outside the secure quarters or cage. 
(g)  When any animal coming under this section shall be found running at large in the city or not in a cage or secure quarters, as provided in subsection (b) of this section, all police officers and humane officers are authorized to capture, restrain and impound any such animal to preserve the public peace and safety. When recapturing or attempting to handle a wild animal, police officers, humane officers and other lawfully constituted authorities may take any reasonable action, including the use of deadly force, against such animal for the safety and welfare of themselves or of other persons and property. The city shall select and establish a place within the city for impounding animals found running at large in violation of this section. Any such animal may be released to the person entitled to its possession, if all applicable fees as authorized in section 10-172 are paid to the city. If not reclaimed within one hundred twenty (120) hours, the city may dispose of the animal in any manner it deems appropriate. Should the person entitled to possession ask to have the animal released to him within the one hundred twenty-hour time limit, he shall satisfy the chief of police or authorized representative that equipment adequate to meet the provisions of this section in restraining any such animal is available and will be used for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-22(b)—(f); Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-85. - Abandonment and confinement of animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, release, or abandon any animal on any property, whether public or private, within the corporate limits of the city. An animal shall be considered abandoned if the owner has not provided water, food and shelter, for three (3) or more consecutive days. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall bear the full costs and expenses incurred by the city in the care of the abandoned animal and the person shall reimburse to the city all costs therefore as determined by the animal control officer. 
(c)  Any person having knowledge of any animal which has been or is believed to have been dumped, released, or abandoned shall notify the humane officer and shall give all pertinent information, including description and location of the animal and the name, address, car license, or any other information or description of the person who dumped, released, or abandoned the animal, if known. 
(Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-86. - Selling of animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, trade, barter, lease, rent, or give away, any animal on any roadside, public right-of-way, commercial parking lot, or at any, flea market or festival. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display for a commercial purpose any animal on any roadside, public right-of-way, commercial parking lot, or at any garage sale, flea market or festival. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any non-profit organization founded for the purpose of providing humane sanctuary or shelter for abandoned or unwanted animals. 
(Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-87—10-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DESTRUCTIVE ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 10-91. - Destructive animals—Impoundment. 
(a)  If a humane officer has probable cause to believe that an animal, while not on its owner's property, has injured or killed a domestic animal, the humane officer shall impound the animal at the shelter, a boarding kennel or a veterinarian's office. The animal shall remain impounded until the court holds a hearing to determine whether the animal is a destructive animal and to determine the disposition of that animal. 
(b)  If the owner of the animal does not allow the humane officer to impound the animal, a humane officer or police officer shall obtain a seizure warrant for the animal. 
(c)  If a humane officer or police officer finds an animal running at-large and the humane officer or police officer has probable cause to believe that, while not on its owner's property, the at-large animal has injured or killed a domestic animal, the humane officer or police officer shall take possession of the animal and impound it at the shelter. A humane officer shall send notice of the impoundment to the owner within two (2) business days of impoundment. 
(d)  If the owner wants to surrender the animal, the owner shall surrender the animal to the humane department. The animal shall remain on a police hold at the shelter or other appropriate facility until the court holds a hearing to determine the animal's disposition. 
(Ord. No. 17-2126, § 2, 2-6-2017)  
Sec. 10-92. - Same—Hearing. 
(a)  Within ten (10) days of impoundment, the court shall hold a bench hearing to determine whether the animal is a destructive animal. The court shall follow the procedures set forth in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.0423. 
(b)  If the court finds that the animal, while off its owner's property, injured or killed a domestic animal, the court shall deem the animal a destructive animal. The court shall also issue at least one (1) of the following orders: 
(1)  Order the animal to be destroyed; 
(2)  Prohibit the owner from owning the same type of domestic animal as the destructive animal while the owner lives in the city limits; 
(3)  Order that the animal be placed in the custody of the shelter so that the animal will be placed for adoption, with specific restrictions; 
(4)  Order the shelter to release the animal to its owner with a written notification to the owner that the owner must do one (1) or more of the following within a designated time: 
a.  Microchip the animal; 
b.  Sterilize the animal; 
c.  Place and keep a red collar on the animal with the wording "caution"; 
d.  Register the animal yearly with the Lake Jackson Humane Department; 
e.  Restrain the animal at all times on a leash or within a secure enclosure; 
f.  Provide the humane department annual proof of liability insurance for the duration of the destructive animal's life, in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per incident, to cover expenses for injured or killed domestic animals that the destructive animal may cause in the future; 
g.  Retrieve the destructive animal from the shelter only when the owner has paid all costs for the impoundment of the animal; 
h.  Retrieve the destructive animal from the shelter only when the owner has provided the humane department with proof that the animal will be kept in a secure enclosure. 
(c)  Placing the destructive animal for adoption or transferring ownership does not affect the destructive animal designation or the requirements ordered by the court. 
(d)  Restitution. The court may order the owner of the destructive animal to pay restitution to the owner of the animal that was injured or killed. If the owner cannot pay restitution, the court may order the owner to perform community service. 
(e)  No finding. The court shall not deem the animal destructive if: 
(1)  The damage or attack happened in an enclosure in which the animal was being kept; 
(2)  The animal was protecting its offspring, itself, or another animal; or 
(3)  The animal was protecting a person. 
(f)  Appeal. An owner may appeal the decision of the court in the same manner as provided for in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.0424. 
(Ord. No. 17-2126, § 2, 2-6-2017)  
Sec. 10-93. - Same—Adoption. 
(a)  If ordered to be placed for adoption, the court will order the shelter to give the new owner written notification of the restrictions in section 10-92(b)(4) that the court has put in place. 
(b)  If the court orders the animal to be placed for adoption, the court may set limitations on who may adopt the animal and the type of environment in which the animal can live, such as no other animals or small children living in the house. 
(c)  If a specific person wants to adopt the animal, that person must appear at the hearing and prove that person can control the animal. 
(Ord. No. 17-2126, § 2, 2-6-2017)  
Sec. 10-94. - Same—Violations. 
(a)  An owner violates this division if: 
(1)  After being deemed a destructive animal, while not on its owner's property, the animal injures or kills another domestic animal; or 
(2)  An animal that has not been deemed destructive, while not on its owner's property, injures or kills another domestic animal and the owner of the animal had knowledge that the animal had injured or killed, or attempted to injure or kill another domestic animal before. 
(3)  The owner does not follow the court's orders. 
(b)  If the destructive animal is found running at large or if the animal owner does not follow the court's orders, the animal shall be impounded at the shelter. 
(1)  Within ten (10) days of impoundment, the court shall hold a hearing to determine if the animal should be returned to the owner or if one (1) or more of the options listed in section 10-92(b) should be ordered; 
(2)  The court shall follow the same notice provisions as in section 10-92. 
(Ord. No. 17-2126, § 2, 2-6-2017)  
Secs. 10-95—10-106. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LIVESTOCK AND OTHER SUCH DOMESTIC ANIMALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Livestock, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code § 141.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10-107. - Livestock and fowl prohibited in city limits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or lead any livestock on any sidewalk within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, raise, or care for any livestock or fowl within the city. 
(c)  The keeping of any livestock or fowl within the city is a public nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with chapter 38 of this Code. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The owner of land upon which the animals are kept if the owner has obtained an agricultural designation of such land for tax purposes; 
(2)  A licensed animal shelter, veterinarian clinic, or similar facility for the treatment and temporary shelter of animals; 
(3)  An officer or employee of the federal, state, or local government engaged in the performance of official duties; or 
(4)  A person who has received permission from the city manager to temporarily keep livestock or fowl within the city limits for a period not to exceed fourteen (14) days. All livestock and fowl kept under this section shall be provided a pen, shed, or other structure of adequate size for the shelter and safekeeping of such animals. Such structures shall be maintained in a manner that prevents the escape of noxious odors or substances to adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-25; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-108—10-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DOGS AND CATS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Barking dogs, § 38-57. 
State Law reference— Regulation of animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.001 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 10-131. - Sentry dog—Registration and training. 
Any person owning or having custody of one (1) or more dogs used, kept, maintained or trained or purported to be trained to work without supervision in a fenced area to deter or detain unauthorized persons found within such area shall register the dog with the humane officer. Before any sentry dog may be registered by the humane officer, evidence of training of such dog must be given so as to ensure that the person having possession of the dog is able to exercise control over it. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-20; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-132. - Same—Notice. 
No person shall keep any sentry dog in any business establishment, residence or other enclosed lot unless there is posted at every entrance thereto a sign of sufficient size and design to warn persons that such a dog is used at such place. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-21; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-133. - Vicious dogs—Disposition. 
(a)  If it is determined by the humane officer that any dog is a vicious dog, the humane officer may order the person who owns or has custody of the dog to keep the dog at all times securely confined within the private property of such owner or person having the custody of the dog. The dog must be kept in such manner as the humane officer may direct to prevent it from biting or having the opportunity of biting any person, including persons lawfully on the premises where the dog is confined, and a sign of sufficient size and design to warn persons shall be clearly posted at every entrance, until after further order of the humane officer. If, after proper notice, the dog is found running at large, the humane office shall capture and may destroy the dog. 
(b)  If the humane officer determines any dog to be both vicious and a perilous threat to human safety after it has first bitten someone, the dog shall be destroyed after giving proper notice to the owner and after the ten-day rabies observation period. 
(c)  For cases arising under this subsection, the humane officer shall notify the dog's owner that the dog has been determined to be a vicious dog or the dog is to be destroyed. The owner shall have five (5) days after receipt of the notice to appeal the decision of the humane officer to the judge of the municipal court. 
(d)  The humane officer shall notify the owner of the dog in writing and deliver such writing either in person or through certified mail. If the certified mail is returned "refused" or "unclaimed", the notice shall be valid and deemed delivered. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Ord. No. 83-893, § 1, 5-16-83; Code 1958, § 3-15; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-134. - Same—determination of viciousness. 
(a)  In determining whether or not a dog is vicious, the humane officer shall be guided by the following: 
(1)  Whether or not the dog has bitten any person at any time other than the occasion which gave rise to the operation of section 10-133; 
(2)  The circumstances surrounding the occasion indicating the temper or ferocity of the dog; 
(3)  The reputation of the dog in the community with regard to its temper or ferocity; and 
(4)  Its general menace to the public. 
(b)  This section shall be operative even though the dog in question has been vaccinated as required by this chapter. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to a dog guarding property against trespassers. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-16; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-135. - Animal waste removal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person not to immediately remove and dispose of, in a sanitary manner, feces left by a dog being handled by that person on property, public or private, other than the premises of the owner or handler of such dog. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to walk a dog on public property or the private property of someone other than the owner or handler of such dog without having in their possession a container or other instrument suitable for the removal and disposal of the dog's feces in a sanitary manner. 
(c)  This section shall not, however apply to handicapped persons using guide dogs or to peace officers while using animals in the discharge of emergency law enforcement activities. 
(Ord. No. 05-1794; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-136—10-145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RABIES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Municipalities may adopt rabies control ordinances or rules, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.015. 
 
Sec. 10-146. - Vaccination required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to own, keep, possess, harbor or to allow to remain upon the premises under his control any dog or cat four (4) months of age or older that is not vaccinated against rabies. 
(b)  Once the dog or cat has received an initial rabies vaccine, the animal must receive a booster within the twelve-month period following the initial vaccination. Thereafter, the animal must be revaccinated against rabies at an interval of at least once every three (3) years, unless more frequent vacations are required by the animal's veterinarian. 
(c)  Nothing in this section prohibits an owner from having the animal vaccinated more frequently. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-3; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Rabies vaccinations, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.021 et seq.  
Sec. 10-147. - Vaccination certificates. 
(a)  Any licensed veterinarian may vaccinate any dog or cat and shall, upon administering the vaccination, issue a vaccination certificate to the owner of the animal in a form approved by the state department of health. 
(b)  The owner of the animal shall keep the rabies vaccination tag securely fastened around the neck of the animal at all times by means of a collar or harness. 
(c)  The fact that a dog or cat is not wearing the vaccination tag is prima facie evidence of the owner's failure to vaccinate the animal for rabies. This prima facie evidence may be rebutted with a copy of the vaccination certificate that shows the animal was vaccinated in accordance with section 10-146. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-4; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Vaccination certificate, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.021(b).  
Sec. 10-148. - Licensing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the City of Lake Jackson to own, keep, possess, harbor, or allow to remain on the premises, under such person's control, an unlicensed dog or cat that is six (6) months of age or older. The licensing tag must be attached to the collar or harness of the animal at all times. 
(b)  A license may be obtained from a participating veterinarian or the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. Proof of rabies vaccination shall be required before issuance of the licensing tag. A reasonable fee shall be charged for the tag and the fee shall be used toward the operational costs of the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. 
(c)  The fact that a dog or cat is not wearing the license tag is prima facie evidence of the owner's failure to have the animal licensed. This prima facie evidence may be rebutted with a copy of the licensing paperwork from the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter or the veterinarian that issued the licensing tag. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-6; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-149. - Removal of tag or collar prohibited without consent. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner, to remove any tag issued under this article from a dog or cat's collar or harness without the written consent of the owner of such dog or cat. 
(Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-150. - Animal bite or scratch; report; confinement, observation and destruction of animal. 
(a)  A person who knows of an animal bite or scratch to an individual, or who knows of an animal that the person suspects is rabid, shall report the incident or animal to the humane officer if the City of Lake Jackson is the location in which the person lives, in which the animal is located, or in which the bite or scratch occurred. 
(b)  The report must include: 
(1)  The name and address of the victim and of the animal's owner, if known; and 
(2)  Any other information that may help in locating the victim or animal. 
(c)  The humane officer shall investigate a report filed under this section. 
(d)  Should any person be bitten or scratched by any animal and a report is made under this section, the humane officer shall have the authority to immediately retrieve the animal and place it with a licensed veterinarian or the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter for confinement and observation for at least ten (10) days. Any and all fees, including transport fees and expenses shall be billable to and be paid by the owner of, or person responsible for, the animal. 
(1)  Should the humane officer decide that it is not necessary to retrieve the animal and place it under confinement and observation with a licensed veterinarian, the person responsible for such animal shall be notified to keep such animal confined and under observation by a licensed veterinarian for not less than ten (10) days after the person was bitten or scratched. The veterinarian shall not release the animal until the local rabies control authority approves the release. 
(2)  Upon the failure of the person responsible for such animal to comply with such notice, the humane officer shall cause such animal to be confined and placed under observation with a veterinarian duly licensed to practice in the state or the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. The owner or owners of such animal shall be responsible for any actual expenses incurred for treatment, veterinary fee and lodging fees. 
(e)  If any animal dies while under observation, the head will be sent to the Texas Department of Health Rabies Lab. 
(f)  If, after the ten-day observation period, the animal does not show signs of rabies, the veterinarian or the humane officer shall release the animal if the owner has an unexpired rabies vaccination certificate for the animal or if the animal is vaccinated against rabies at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-13; Ord. No. 97-1427, § 1, 8-18-97; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Reports of rabid animal, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.041.  
Sec. 10-151. - Killing of rabid animal. 
The chief of police or any police officer of this city shall have the right to destroy any animal suspected of being rabid within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-14; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-152—10-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - IMPOUNDMENT, REDEMPTION AND DISPOSITION 
 
Sec. 10-171. - Unrestrained and nuisance animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any animal (excluding cats) that he owns, keeps, possesses, harbors or allows to remain upon the premises under his control to be unrestrained. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, possess, harbor or allow to remain upon the premises under his control a nuisance animal. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-7(a)—(c); Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 04-1767, § 1, 11-1-2004; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Restraining dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.033(a)(1); quarantine and impoundment facilities, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.051 et seq.  
Sec. 10-171.1. - Trapping. 
(a)  Humane officers shall only use humane cage style traps as a means of apprehending nuisance and feral cats. 
(1)  Humane officers may trap on private property if the property owner or agent of the property owner requests the removal of a nuisance or feral cat. 
(2)  Humane officers shall not trap during weekends, city holidays or during times of inclement weather. 
(b)  Any person who is a property owner or agent of that property owner may trap on their property. 
(1)  People may borrow traps from the police department. However, traps will not be loaned out during times of inclement weather. 
(2)  Whether the person is using a private trap or one loaned from the police department, the humane officer shall provide said person guidelines concerning how long an animal may remain in a trap. If a humane officer is not available to retrieve the animal within the hours established in the guidelines, the person must release the animal or take it to the animal shelter. Violation of said guidelines shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(3)  Any person who traps an animal will be subject to criminal prosecution if it is determined animal cruelty laws are violated. 
(4)  Any person who unintentionally traps a domestic animal shall immediately release the animal at the site where it was trapped. 
(5)  The relocation and abandonment of any trapped animal is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-171.2. - Impoundment. 
(a)  All humane officers and police officers have the authority to pick up any unrestrained animal (excluding cats), any nuisance animal, any animal that is treated in a manner determined by an animal control officer to be cruel or inhumane, or any animal being kept in a condition which is a violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(b)  Unrestrained animals may be returned to their owner if known and if the owner has a secure area for the animal. 
(c)  Unrestrained animals not returned to their owners and all other animals picked up according to this section, shall be confined in the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. 
(Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-171.3. - Redemption, disposition. 
(a)  Unrestrained animals impounded in the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter shall be kept for up to seventy-two (72) hours in the case of an animal without a collar or up to one hundred twenty (120) hours in the case of an animal wearing a current vaccination and/or license tag. After such time period, the animal shall become the property of the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter, and the animal may be destroyed or placed for adoption. 
(b)  Nuisance animals impounded in the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter shall be kept until the nuisance situation has been abated. If the situation is not abated within fourteen (14) days, the city shall ask the court to hold a hearing on whether the animal should be returned to the owner, temporarily retained at the shelter to give the owner more time, or placed for adoption. 
(c)  Animals that are impounded at the shelter because they are dangerous, destructive, cruelly treated, or nuisances shall remain on a police hold and shall not become the property of the shelter without a court order. 
(Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009; Ord. No. 17-2126, § 3, 2-6-2017)  
Sec. 10-172. - Redemption fees; fees for services rendered; revenue to general fund. 
Reasonable fees will be charged for redemption of animals and for all costs and services rendered by the humane department and the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. Such fees are to be paid by the owner or person entitled to redeem the animal before the animal is redeemed. The humane officer and the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter shall keep a current schedule of fees to be charged, such fees approved by the city council and the board of directors of the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter. All fees and monies for pickup and daily fees will be collected by the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter and are to be used to defray operational costs of the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter facility. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-7.1; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Impoundment fee, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.033(c).  
Sec. 10-173. - Notice. 
As soon as possible after any animal has been impounded at the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter, it shall be the duty of the humane officer to post the required notice at the door of the shelter describing each such animal, whether bearing a vaccination tag, or not and giving the number of the tag, and the name of the person registering the animal in the case where the animal bears a vaccination tag. If the animal bears a vaccination tag, in addition to posting such notice, it shall be the duty of the humane officer to contact the veterinarian who issued the vaccination tag, to determine the identity of the owner of the animal. The humane officer will notify such person by letter, postal card or telephone. The mailing of such letter or postal card shall be deemed sufficient notice whether the person addressed shall receive the same or not. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-8; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-174. - Release of redeemed animals; prerequisite. 
The person entitled to the possession of an animal impounded under this article, upon proper application within the specified time limits after the impounding of such animal, shall be entitled to have the animal released to him/her provided such animal is not affected or thought to be affected with rabies, displays proof of a current rabies vaccination and proof of a current license and all current pickup and shelter fees have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-9; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009) 
State Law reference— Impoundment for a period set by ordinance or rule, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.033(a)(4).  
Sec. 10-176. - Adoption of unredeemed animals, sterilization, rabies vaccination required. 
(a)  The Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter shall not release for adoption by a new owner any animal more than six (6) months of age that has not been sterilized. In addition, there shall be satisfactory evidence that the animal has been vaccinated against rabies, and that the vaccination is current, before any animal may be released. The cost of sterilization and vaccination must be deposited with the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter for payment to a veterinarian selected by the person adopting the animal. The deposit shall be returned upon receipt by the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter of a notice from the veterinarian that the animal has been sterilized and vaccinated as set forth in this article. 
(b)  When a person picks up an animal that he already owns, the animal does not have to be sterilized. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-11; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-177. - Records, reports. 
The humane officer shall submit a monthly report to the chief of police as to the number of dogs and cats picked up, the number of wild animals relocated, and the number of citations and warnings given for violations of this chapter. The humane officer shall make such other reports as are requested. 
(Ord. No. 79-709, § 1, 10-15-79; Code 1958, § 3-12; Ord. No. 03-1709, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1729, § 1, 10-5-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Secs. 10-178—10-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - ANIMAL SHELTER ADVISORY COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 10-201. - Created, composition. 
There is hereby created an animal shelter advisory committee, to advise the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter in complying with Chapter 823 of the Texas Health and Safety Code, consisting of four (4) or more members composed of at least one (1) licensed veterinarian, one (1) county or municipal official, one (1) person whose duties include daily operation of an animal shelter, and one (1) representative from an animal welfare organization, and all shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 06-1811, § 1, 5-22-2006; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-202. - Appointment of members. 
The members of the animal shelter advisory committee shall be appointed by the city council, four (4) such members to be appointed in each even-numbered year, and the remainder number of members appointed in each odd-numbered year, the appointments to be made each year within thirty (30) days following the regular election. 
(Ord. No. 06-1811, § 1, 5-22-2006; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-203. - Chairman, rules of procedure. 
The animal shelter advisory committee shall annually elect one (1) of its number as chairman and shall establish its own rules and procedures, which shall include the following: 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members, the chairman being entitled to vote upon questions. 
(2)  Meetings shall be held at least three (3) times each calendar year, shall be open to the public, and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of the record keeper for the animal shelter board and shall be public record. 
(Ord. No. 06-1811, § 1, 5-22-2006; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)  
Sec. 10-204. - Powers, duties. 
The animal shelter advisory committee shall be and is hereby vested with the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To assist in complying with the requirements of Chapter 823 of the Texas Health and Safety Code. 
(2)  To act as an advisory body, with power to advise and recommend to the Southern Brazoria County Animal Shelter and its board of directors policies, rules and regulations for the care and control of animals within the jurisdiction of the shelter. 
(Ord. No. 06-1811, § 1, 5-22-2006; Ord. No. 09-1895, § 1, 1-5-2009)
