ARTICLE II. - ANNEXATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— For complete description of city boundaries at adoption of charter, see § 1.02. The annexations contained herein are set out in chronological order. 
 
DIVISION 1. - PRECODE ANNEXATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— The City of Lake Jackson's first codification was in 1954. There were three annexations prior to the codification in 1954 that were not listed in this chapter: Ord. No. 124, passed 3-10-1952; Ord. No. 131, passed 8-25-1952; and Ord. No. 134, passed 1-31-1953. Said ordinances have since been codified herein as §§ 12-18—12-20. 
 
Sec. 12-18. - Precode annexation one. 
This section amends Ordinance No. 75, same being the zoning ordinance of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, reflecting the inclusion of areas "L", "E Extension" and "M" into the city limits of said City of Lake Jackson, and setting forth zoning and other pertinent regulations to govern said areas. 
I.  A new paragraph, designated as paragraph (40), to follow under paragraph (39) of Section 1 entitled "Definitions" in said Ordinance No. 75, is hereby adopted, which shall read as follows: 
"(40) In measuring distances from permitted structures to front, side and rear property lines, the measurements shall be made from the foundation or vertical wall of said permitted structure." 
II.  A new paragraph, designated as paragraph (41), to follow under paragraph (40) of Section 1 entitled "Definitions" in said Ordinance No. 75, is hereby adopted, which shall read as follows: 
"(41) Block lines - Lines bounding a block." 
III.  Paragraph (2) of Section 2 entitled "District Regulations" is hereby amended to read as follows: 
"(a) For the purpose of this ordinance, the City of Lake Jackson is hereby divided into five districts, namely: 
"A" Residence Districts; 
"B" Residence Districts; 
"B-1" Residence Districts; 
"C" Local Business Districts; 
"D" Commercial Districts." 
IV.  A new section, designated as Section 4-a to follow Section 4 in said Ordinance No. 75 is hereby adopted, which shall read as follows: 
"SECTION 4-a - "B-1" RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 
(a)  Use Regulations: Unless hereafter provided, no building or premises shall be used and no building shall be hereafter erected or structurally altered within a "B-1" Residence District except for one or more of the following uses: 
(1)  Any use permitted in "A" Residence Districts; 
(2)  Any use permitted in "B" Residence Districts; 
(3)  Two-family residences may be constructed and a campus-style arrangement of said two-family residences is hereby permitted, subject to approval of the governing body of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas. 
(b)  Area Regulations: 
(1)  Set Back Sides and Rear of Permitted Structures. No residence or other permitted structure, whose end or side wall lines have an angle of 15° or less with any block line, shall be constructed nearer than fifteen (15) feet from the front block line; nor nearer than fifteen (15) feet from any side street block line; nor nearer than five (5) feet from the rear block line; nor nearer than three (3) feet to any side block line other than a side street block line. 
No residence or other permitted structure, whose end or side wall lines have an angle of 16° or more with any block line, shall be constructed on said block nearer than five (5) feet from the front block line; nor nearer than five (5) feet from any side street block line; nor nearer than five (5) feet from the rear block line; nor nearer than three (3) feet to any side block line other than a side street block line. 
No structure shall be constructed nearer than ten (10) feet from any other structure. 
The restrictions contained herein shall not extend to steps, fences, terraces or trellises, but do apply to the building proper and to any and all garages, porches and galleries attached thereto. If more than one lot is used as one building site, the restrictions set out herein shall not apply to the common side property line of such lots. 
(2)  Garages, Laundries and Other Accessory Buildings. In addition to the structures permitted in subparagraphs (1), (2) and (3), of subparagraph (a) of Section 4-a, there may be erected or constructed multiple garages, laundries or other buildings essential for residential purposes for the use of the occupants of said residences. No garage or outbuilding on said lots or building sites shall be used as a residence or living quarters, except for servants engaged on the premises. 
(3)  Places of Public Assembly. Any such use as churches, schools and community buildings or any place of public assembly seating 100 persons or more, located in a "B-1" Residence District, shall observe the regular set-back requirements of that district and there shall be a side yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet and there shall be a rear yard of not less than fifteen (15) feet." 
V.  Paragraph 1, Section 11, entitled "Description of Districts" is hereby amended to read as follows: 
"1.  A map of the City of Lake Jackson, showing the various districts created by this Ordinance, is attached to this Ordinance, marked "Zoning Map, City of Lake Jackson, Texas". A map of said City of Lake Jackson marked "Exhibit A" is attached to this amendment which reflects the inclusion of Areas "L", "E Extension" and "M" in the City Limits of said City of Lake Jackson." 
VI.  Paragraph (a) under 2, Section 11, entitled "Description of Districts" is hereby amended to read as follows: 
"(a)  "A" Residence Districts. 
"A" Residence Districts shall include the entire City of Lake Jackson and all of the land within the corporate limits, except those parts of the City of Lake Jackson included within "B" Residence Districts, "B-1" Residence Districts, "C" Local Business Districts, and "D" Commercial Districts, said "A" Residence District being outlined in blue on the attached map." 
VII.  A new paragraph, designated as (b-1), to follow under Paragraph 2 of Section 11 in said Ordinance No. 75, is hereby adopted, which shall read as follows: 
"(b-1) "B-1" Residence Districts. No part of the corporate limits of the City of Lake Jackson shall be "B-1" Residence District unless and until so provided by proper amendment hereof." 
(Ord. No. 124, §§ I—VII, 3-10-1952) 
Note— See editor's note at Div. 1.

There is hereby received and annexed as a part of the city the following territory:

Thence northwesterly coincident with a line 500 feet northerly of and parallel with the northerly city limit line of Freeport, Texas, as described in said Freeport, Texas, Ordinances Numbered 1022 and 1031, said northerly city limit line of Freeport, Texas, being a line in the centerline of the Brazos River, to a point for corner; 
Thence north 50° 00' 00? east to the point of beginning. 
(Ord. No. 87-1026, § 1, 1-19-87; Code 1958, § 1-56)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Adoption of technical codes. 
(a)  The following codes and the standards contained therein, are hereby adopted as the minimum building standard codes of the city, save and except those sections added, deleted or amended in this chapter: 
(1)  Building code. The 2018 International Building Code, including all appendixes except A (Employee Qualifications), B (Board of Appeals), H (Signs), and K (Administrative Provisions) 
(2)  Fire code. The 2018 International Fire Code, including all appendixes except A (Board of Appeals). 
(3)  Electrical code. The 2015 National Electrical Code, including the annexes. 
(4)  Plumbing code. The 2018 International Plumbing Code including all appendixes except A (Plumbing Permit Fee Schedule). 
(5)  Swimming pool code. The Texas Department of State Health Services, Standards for Swimming Pools and Spas. 
(6)  Property maintenance code. The 2018 International Property Maintenance Code, including the appendix. 
(7)  Mechanical code. The 2018 International Mechanical Code, including all appendixes except B (Permit Fee Schedule). 
(8)  Residential code. The 2018 International Residential Code (IRC), including all appendixes except G (Swimming Pools, Spas, and Hot Tubs), I (Private Sewage Disposal), L (Permit Fees), and excluding Ch. 11. Ch. 11 of the 2015 International Residential Code is adopted. Any requirement that one- or two- family dwellings be protected by fire sprinkler systems shall not become effective until mandated by the State of Texas. 
(9)  Fuel gas code. The 2018 International Fuel Gas Code including the appendixes. 
(10)  Life safety code. The 2018 Life Safety Code, including supplements. 
(11)  Energy code. The 2015 International Energy Conservation Code. 
(12)  Accessibility code for multi-family residences. The 2009 ICC/ANSI A117.1 Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities Code. 
(b)  If there is a conflict between a state law and an adopted code or this chapter, then the state law will take precedence. In cases of conflicts between a provision of this chapter and these adopted codes, the provision of this chapter will take precedence. Otherwise, all structures shall be designed, built, and maintained in accordance with these adopted codes. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 09-1900, § 1, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 1, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 15-2064, §§ 1, 2, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 16-2111, § 1, 9-6-2016; Ord. No. 16-2116, § 1, 11-7-2016; Ord. No. 17-2141, § 1, 9-5-2017; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 1, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-2. - Drainage to be provided. 
All new construction within the city limits shall be placed on a site which will eliminate low areas beneath buildings and provide complete and proper drainage for the building site and the complete lot. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 3, 4-7-2015)  
Sec. 14-3. - Standards for trench excavations. 
All trenching and excavations on public or private property within the city shall comply with federal occupational safety and health standards. All bid documents and contracts for city projects, including excavation, shall contain provisions requiring the same. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 2, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-4. - Street numbers. 
(a)  Each main residential, business, commercial and industrial building shall have placed on the front of the building a street number of a size and color legible enough to be seen by the public from the street immediately in front of the building in accordance with the International Fire Code. 
(b)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of all builders to place these numbers on new buildings. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the owners and occupants of every house or building used for residential, business, commerce or industry in the city to place and maintain the numbers on their buildings. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 4, 4-7-2015)  
Sec. 14-5. - Street curb address numbers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of contractors, builders and solicitors that paint address numbers on street curbs in any area of the city to procure a solicitor's license. If the contractor, builder or solicitor makes representations that the city endorses or supports the contractor's, builder's or solicitor's services or products, the license may be revoked. 
(b)  All individuals painting or causing the painting of address numbers on curbs in any area of the city shall comply with the following: 
1.  Prior to painting the base background, the surface shall be prepared by removing all foreign particles, substances or mildew by wire brushing and/or scraping. 
2.  The numbers shall be painted at the approximate mid-lot location of the property. 
3.  The numbers shall be placed upon a dark green (i.e., forest green) background (base) that is sixteen (16) inches long (i.e., curb run) and from top to bottom of the curb rise. 
4.  The numbers shall be painted white and be four (4) inches tall, leaving at least a two-inch side margin of the dark green background. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 3, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-6. - Satellite-signal receiving antennae. 
(a)  A device used for or designed for receiving electromagnetic signals from one or more satellites either directly or through repeating transmitters, including but not restricted to those of dish or disc shapes, shall be the definition of satellite-signal receiving antennae. 
(b)  Satellite-signal receiving antennae may be permitted as long as it is located, placed and installed behind all setback lines specified in the zoning code, and is located on the property in a place that will diminish any danger to neighborhood property in the event of collapse or other failure. All other placements of satellite-signal receiving antennae shall be prohibited and violations subject to the provisions of section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-7. - Fees. 
All fees required under this chapter shall be approved by city council either by minute order or as part of the annual budget. A copy of the schedule shall be on file with the city secretary and building official. A permit shall not be issued nor any amendment made to a permit until all fees have been paid. The city council may waive permit fees for work being performed by humanitarian or charitable organizations that work to provide people affordable housing. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-8. - Appeals. 
All appeals of administrative decisions under articles I through X of this chapter shall be handled by the board of adjustment and appeals. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-9. - Inspections. 
(a)  The building official or his designee may enter a building to perform any inspection under this chapter with the express consent of a person in control of the property or if a building is unsecured to the extent that it could be entered by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children. 
(b)  If entry is refused, the building official is authorized to pursue recourse as provided by law, including all rights and authority granted under the Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Article 18.05. 
(c)  All medical gas piping inspections and required third party inspections are the financial responsibility of the property owner or the property owner's designee. Prior to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy, reports for medical gas piping inspections and required third party inspections shall be submitted to the city building official. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 16-2116, § 1, 11-7-2016)  
Secs. 14-10—14-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 
 
Sec. 14-25. - Definitions. 
Improvements means the construction, alteration, modification, repair or replacement of buildings or building systems. 
(Ord. No. 18-2171, § 4, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-26. - Building official. 
The office of building official is hereby created, which office shall be filled by the city manager or by appointment by the city manager. The building official shall be well versed in the requirements of the city building code. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-27. - Amendments to code. 
(a)  The following parts of the Adopted International Building Code are deleted: 
(1)  The definition of "Height, Building" in Section 102. 
(2)  Section 105.1.1 (Annual Permit). 
(3)  Section 105.1.2 (Annual Permit Records). 
(4)  Numbers 1 through 6 (Work not requiring a permit). 
(5)  Section 113 (Board of Appeals). 
(6)  Section 116 (Unsafe Structures and Equipment). 
(b)  Section 102.6 of the Adopted International Building Code is hereby amended and supplemented as follows: 
(1)  If, within any twelve (12) months period, alterations or repairs costing in excess of fifty (50) percent of the then physical value of the building are made to an existing building, such building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
(2)  If an existing building is damaged by fire or otherwise in excess of fifty (50) percent of its then physical value before such damage is repaired, it shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
(3)  If the cost of such alterations or repairs within any twelve (12) month period or the amount of such damage as referred to in paragraph 2 is more than twenty-five (25) but not more than fifty (50) percent of the then physical value of the building the portions to be altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings to such extent as the Building Official may determine. 
(4)  For the purpose of this section physical value of the buildings shall be determined by the Building Official. 
(5)  If the occupancy classification of an existing building is entirely changed the building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for the new occupancy classification. If the occupancy classification of only a portion of an existing building is changed and that portion is separated from the remainder as stipulated in section 302.32, then only such portion need be made to conform. 
(6)  Repairs and alterations, not covered by the preceding paragraphs of this section, restoring a building to its condition previous to damage or deterioration, or altering it in conformity with the provisions of this code or in such manner as will not extend or increase an existing non-conformity or hazard, may be made with the same kind of materials as those of which the building is constructed; but not more than twenty-five (25) percent of the roof covering of a building shall be replaced in any period of twelve (12) months unless the entire roof covering is made to conform with the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 10-1935, § 1, 5-3-2010; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 2, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 15-2064, §§ 5, 6, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 15-2068, § 1, 6-1-2015; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 5, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-2171, § 6, adopted Nov. 19, 2018, repealed § 14-28, which pertained to fire districts and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007.  
Sec. 14-28.1. - Erection or use of pier on city-owned land or waters. 
It shall be unlawful to erect any pier or mooring site on, along, over or in any city-owned land or water areas such as Shy Pond. 
It shall also be unlawful to use or operate any houseboat, powerized boat or any other boat that is designed to be powered by anything but human power on, along, over or in any city-owned land or water areas such as Shy Pond. 
No boats or surface vessels may be tied at any city-owned shoreline or on city property or unloaded from any trailer or other vehicle on city property except at locations where permitted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 84-946, § 1, 10-15-84)  
Sec. 14-29. - Elevation of ground floor. 
The ground floor elevation of all buildings constructed after July 22, 1968, within the city limits must be at least twenty-four (24) inches above the center of the street in front of such lot or other building site. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-30. - Foundations slab/form survey required. 
(a)  All foundations for new construction shall have a forms survey completed and an exact duplicate copy given to the inspection department prior to the foundation inspection being approved by the city. 
(b)  With regard to construction involving remodeling and/or additions to a property which has a current survey, the building official shall decide if a forms survey is needed at the time the permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-31—14-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FIRE CODE 
 
Sec. 14-36. - Definitions. 
NICET means the National Institute for the Certification of Engineering Technologies. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 09-1900, § 2, 2-17-2009)  
Sec. 14-37. - Duties and powers of fire marshal and building official. 
The fire marshal and building official are authorized to enforce the provisions of this article. The fire marshal and building official shall have the authority to render interpretations of this article and to adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the application of its provisions. Such policies and procedures shall not have the effect of waiving requirements specifically provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 09-1900, § 2, 2-17-2009)  
Sec. 14-38. - Amendments to code. 
(a)  The following parts of the Adopted International Fire Code are deleted: 
1.  Section 108 (Board of Appeals) 
2.  Section 110 (Unsafe Buildings) 
3.  The exceptions to 907.2.1, 907.2.2, 907.2.3, 907.2.4, 907.2.6, 907.2.6.1, 907.2.6.2, 907.2.8.1, 907.2.8.2, 907.2.10.1, 907.2.11.2, 1103.7.1, 1103.7.2, 1103.7.3, 1103.7.5.1, 1103.7.5.2, 1103.7.5.2.1, 1103.7.6, and 1103.7.7. 
(b)  Section 907.2.9 is deleted and replaced with the following: 
907.2.9 Group R-2. A manual fire alarm system shall be installed in Group R-2 occupancy classifications. 
(c)  Section 903 of the code is deleted and replaced with the following: 
A.  Fire sprinklers. 
(1)  Plan certification for fire alarm systems and occupant notification. All fire alarm and occupant notification system plans submitted to the fire marshal and building official for review and approval shall bear a review certification of a minimum level III NICET in fire alarms. 
(2)  Plan certification for fire sprinkler systems. All fire sprinkler plans submitted to the fire marshal and building official for review and approval shall bear a review certification of a minimum level III NICET in fire sprinklers. 
(3)  Plan certification for all other fire protection systems. Plan certification for all other fire protection systems will be accompanied by a certification of competence when required. 
(4)  On-site plans. Plans and specifications shall be submitted to the fire marshal and building official for review and approval prior to construction. One (1) set of approved plans shall be on the job site for each inspection. 
B.  Fire sprinklers—Where required. 
(1)  Where required. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in accordance with this section throughout all levels of all new group A, B, E, F, M, and S occupancy classifications of more than eight thousand (8,000) square feet. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in accordance with this section throughout all levels of new H, I, and R occupancies. New Group U occupancies will be required to have an automatic sprinkler system if the level of fire hazard their use encompasses shows the need for said system. This subsection shall become effective immediately for one- and two-family dwellings once mandated by the State of Texas. For all other occupancy classifications, this subsection becomes effective March 9, 2009. 
a.  All buildings—In every story or basement. Fire-resistive substitutions may be allowed in accordance with provisions in the International Building Code, provided that the automatic sprinkler is not otherwise required throughout the building by any other provision or section of the building code. 
b.  At the top of rubbish and linen chutes and in their terminal rooms. Chutes extending through three (3) or more floors shall have additional sprinkler heads installed within such chutes at alternate floors. Sprinkler heads shall be accessible for servicing. 
c.  In rooms where nitrate film is stored or handled. See section 306 of the International Building Code. 
d.  In protected combustible fiber storage vaults. 
e.  In any building that has a change in occupancy classification as defined in the building code. For example, an automatic sprinkler system shall be installed if a building is converted from the Group E (Educational) occupancy classification to the Group M (Mercantile) occupancy classification. 
(2)  Exception. If the International Fire Code or International Building Code has a stricter square footage or occupancy requirement, then the requirements in the International Fire Code and/or International Building Code shall be followed. 
The following accessory structures shall be exempt from fire sprinkler requirements. 
a.  Gazebos and ramadas for residential and public use. 
b.  Independent rest room buildings that are associated with golf courses, parks and similar uses. 
c.  Guardhouses for residential and commercial developments. 
d.  Detached non-combustible carports for residential and commercial developments with covered parking less than fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet (1394 m 2 ). 
e.  Barns and agricultural buildings for private, residential, non-commercial use, not exceeding one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet (139.35 m 2 ) with no habitable areas. 
f.  Detached storage sheds for private, residential, non-commercial use, not exceeding one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet (139.35 m 2 ). 
g.  Detached one-, two- and three-car garages (without habitable spaces) in existing residential lots for replacement only within four hundred (400) feet hydrant spacing. 
h.  Fuel dispensing canopies exceeding fifteen (15) feet in clear height. 
i.  Open shade horse stalls of non-combustible construction for private, residential, non-commercial use, not exceeding five thousand (5,000) square feet (464.52 m 2 ) and no storage of combustible products, vehicles, or agricultural equipment. 
j.  Detached one-story accessory building used as tool and storage shed of non-hazardous materials, and not exceeding two hundred (200) square feet (11.15 m 2 ). 
k.  Special use non-combustible structures as approved by the fire marshal and building official. 
(3)  Groups A, E, F, H, M, S-1, Repair Garages, S-2 Occupancy Classifications, Commercial Parking Garages, Group B Occupancy Classifications. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 13 installation of sprinkler systems. 
(4)  Group I. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout all group I occupancy classifications in accordance with NFPA 13 installation of sprinkler systems. 
a.  Exception: In jails, prisons and reformatories, the piping system may be dry, provided a manually operated valve is installed at a continuously monitored location. Opening of the valve shall cause the piping system to be charged. Sprinkler heads in such systems shall be equipped with fusible elements or the system shall be designed as required for deluge systems in the building code. 
(5)  Group R, Installation Requirements. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout all group R occupancy classifications in accordance with NFPA 13, 13-R, or 13D installation of sprinkler systems. This subsection shall become effective immediately for one- and two-family dwellings once mandated by the State of Texas. For all other group R occupancy classifications, this subsection becomes effective January 1, 2008. 
(6)  All group R-3 and U occupancy classifications. An automatic sprinkler system shall be installed throughout all group R-3 and U occupancy classifications in accordance with NFPA 13 or 13-D installation of sprinkler systems. This subsection shall become effective immediately for one- and two-family dwellings once mandated by the State of Texas. For all other group R-3 and U occupancy classifications, this subsection becomes effective March 9, 2009. 
(7)  Section 1103.5.1 of the Adopted International Fire Code is deleted and replaced with the following: 
Where alcoholic beverages are consumed in a Group A-2 occupancy having an occupant load of 301 or more, the fire area containing the Group A-2 occupancy shall be equipped with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 09-1900, § 2, 2-17-2009; Ord. No. 09-1901, § 1, 3-2-2009; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 3, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 7, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 18-2171, §§ 7, 8, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-39. - Alarm systems. 
(a)  Where required. 
(1)  New buildings and structures. An approved manual, automatic, or manual and automatic fire alarm system shall be provided in buildings and structures in accordance with the most current adopted fire code and most current referenced NFPA standard. Where automatic sprinkler protection installed is provided and connected to the building fire alarm system, automatic heat detection required by this section shall not be required. The automatic fire detectors shall be smoke detectors, except that an approved alternative type of detector shall be installed in spaces such as boiler rooms where, during normal operation, products of combustion are present in sufficient quantity to actuate a smoke detector. 
(2)  Owner landlord and occupant responsibilities. In a dwelling unit occupied under the terms of a rental agreement or under a month-to-month tenancy: 
a.  At the time of each occupancy, the landlord shall provide smoke detection devices in working condition and, after written notification by the tenant, shall be responsible for replacement; and 
b.  The tenant shall keep the devices in working condition and shall refrain from disabling the devices. 
(b)  Records and maintenance. The landlord or owner of any rental property shall inspect all smoke detection devices as required under NFPA 72 annually and a record of all inspections and maintenance activities shall be kept by the landlord or owner and available for inspection upon request by the fire marshal's office or building official. 
(c)  Activation. Where an alarm notification system is required by another section of this code, it shall be activated by: 
(1)  Required automatic fire alarm system. 
(2)  Sprinkler water-flow devices. 
Multilevel structures. All multilevel structures are required to have a flow switch and tampered control valve per floor. 
Exception: Group R-1 and R-2, occupancy classifications with a domestic water supply serving six (6) units or less and group R-3. 
(3)  Manual fire alarm boxes at locations designated by the fire marshal and building official. 
(d)  Additions, alterations and repairs. When alterations or repairs within a 12-month period exceed fifty (50) percent of the value of an existing building or structure, such building or structure shall be made to conform to the requirements for new buildings or structures. 
(e)  Partial systems. When additions to existing non-sprinkled buildings and structures increase the value of the existing building or structure by more than fifty (50) percent, an automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in said addition in accordance with this section. Sprinkled and non-sprinkled areas of a structure shall be separated in accordance with all applicable codes and standards. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 8, 4-7-2015)  
Secs. 14-40—14-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-56. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Apprentice or helper electrician means any person other than master electrician or journeyman electrician who, as his principal occupation, is engaged in learning and assisting in the installation of electrical systems by assisting a journeyman and who has a letter from a master electrician to the effect that he will be employed by the master. There shall be no more than two (2) apprentices/helpers on a job for each journeyman. 
Electrical inspector means any person employed by the city for the purpose of inspecting electrical work and installation in connection with enforcing health and safety laws and ordinances of the city. 
Electricity means and includes: 
(1)  All wiring, fixtures, conduits and appurtenances or other devices used for the distribution of electrical energy for all personal or commercial purposes in and through buildings where people live, work or assemble; all wiring, fixtures, conduits and appurtenances or conductors attached to a building connecting the building with the source of electrical supply, on the premises; and 
(2)  The installation, repair and maintenance of all wiring, fixtures, conduits, appurtenances or other devices used in and about a building where a person or persons live, work or assemble, for the distribution of electrical energy. 
Journeyman electrician means any person other than a master electrician who immediately supervises and engages in or works at the actual installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical systems and who has successfully fulfilled the examination and requirements of the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulations. 
Master electrician means an electrician who, by himself or through a person or persons in his employ, performs electrical work; who has the sole responsibility for adequate performance of the work; who is actively a part of the job; and who has successfully fulfilled the examinations and requirements of the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulations. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-57. - Amendments to code. 
(1)  The following parts of the Adopted National Electrical Code are deleted: 
a.  Annex H, section 80.15 (Electrical Board) 
b.  Annex H, section 80.19(D) (Annual Permits) 
c.  Annex H, section 80.27 (Inspector's Qualifications) 
(2)  Any and all code references permitting or requiring aluminum wire shall not be applicable, except when used as an option in underground service to the electric utility meter or when all of the following requirements are met: 
(a)  The building consists of at least 3 stories or 75,000 sq. ft.; 
(b)  The building electrical service from the utility provider is 480Y/277V, 3 phase, 4 wire; 
(c)  The building has a main service of 1600 Amps or larger; 
(d)  The building Main Service Disconnecting Means is of Switchboard Construction. (Buildings served with Gutter and Disconnect Switch configurations will not be permitted to use above ground aluminum feeders.); 
(e)  All aluminum conductors are compression type conductors and use an approved joint compound with compression termination fittings. 
(f)  The electrical contractor provides the number of lugs and proper lug sizes to accept the larger aluminum conductor sizes required; 
(g)  Aluminum feeders are not used to serve chillers, elevators or equipment utilizing variable frequency drives; 
(h)  Aluminum conductors are not used on the secondary side of step down transformers; and 
(i)  Aluminum conductors are only to be used on feeders that are 200Amps and larger. 
(3)  All references concerning the size of wiring are amended to require that all wiring be adequate for planned facilities, and in no case shall wiring be less than #12, including the switch legs and throughout the system. 
(4)  All references concerning grounding are amended to require that all light fixtures, switches, plugs, etc., must be grounded to an equipment grounding conductor. 
(5)  All references concerning ground rods are amended to require that each service entrance conductor (meter loop) be furnished with an eight-foot copper, copper clad or galvanized ground rod (not pipe). 
(6)  All references concerning disconnecting means are amended to require that with the service entrance conductors required by the Lake Jackson amendments, the following disconnecting means must be used: 
a.  #2 copper or #1/0 A1-100 amp. 
b.  #0 copper or #3/0 A1-150 amp. 
(7)  All references concerning disconnecting means are amended to require that main breakers or disconnecting means be used if there are more than six (6) circuits on any one (1) service entrance conductor (meter loop). 
(8)  All applicable sections of the code are amended to require that no circuit shall contain a combination of more than eight (8) duplex receptacles or lighting fixtures, on a Standard 20A breaker. Lighting only circuits intended for more than 8 fixtures must be approved by the building official, and electrical load calculations by a licensed master electrician must be submitted at the time of permit application. 
(9)  With respect to residences, all references concerning service entrance conductors (meter loops) are amended to require a conduit of at least ridge metal, intermediate metal 2, one and one-quarter (1 1/4) inches consisting of a #2 copper or #1/0 aluminum wiring (aluminum allowed only on underground service) for residences of one thousand (1,000) to one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet and consisting of #0 copper or #3/0 aluminum wiring (aluminum allowed only on underground service) for residences of one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet or more. 
(10)  With respect to residences, all references concerning kitchen utilities are amended to require: 
a.  That a three-wire branch circuit supplying a household electric range shall be at least #6-3/g with a fifty-amp breaker; 
b.  Ranges with cook tops shall have a #10-3/g with thirty-amp breaker; 
c.  Ranges with separate ovens shall have #10-3/g with thirty-amp breaker. 
(11)  With respect to residences, rooms such as kitchens and utility rooms shall have not more than three (3) outlets on the same circuit and lighting and other service in these two (2) areas shall not be on the same circuit. 
(12)  Conductors of different systems shall not be installed in the same raceway, box, gutter, or other type of enclosures without the approval of the building official. 
(13)  With respect to commercial and residential ceiling grid and tile systems, all lights, luminaries, and other appurtenances must be suspended independently of the ceiling grid system. 
(14)  When there is any work involving an electrical panel in a clothes closet, other than the replacement of individual breakers, the electrical panel must be moved to a location that is in compliance with the adopted electrical code. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 4, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 14-2047, § 1, 7-7-2014; Ord. No. 15-2064, §§ 9—13, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 17-2141, §§ 2—4, 9-5-2017; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 9, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-58. - Penalty. 
Any person found guilty of violation of any of the provisions of this article or neglecting or refusing to comply with any order or notice of the electrical inspector or other officer made pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per day for each day the violation exists or continues. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-59. - Permit—Alteration or change in connection with electrical wiring or fixtures. 
No alteration or change shall be made in the electric wiring or fixtures located within a building for use in connection with the production of electric light, heat or power, with the exception of a power plant; nor shall any such electric wiring for the distribution of electrical energy be installed in any building without first securing a permit therefor; nor shall any change be made in any wiring or fixtures after inspection without notifying the electrical inspector and securing a permit therefor. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 10, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-60. - Same—Application, filing, permission to deviate therefrom. 
Before issuing a permit for the installation of any wiring or fixtures or the alteration or change of any wiring or fixtures as provided in section 14-59, an application shall be filed with the electrical inspector describing such installation or the alteration or changes to be made, including the fixtures and material used. Any changes in the permitted job shall require approval by the inspector in writing. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-61. - Interference with fire department or obstruction of fire escapes by wires—Prohibited. 
No wire or wires shall be installed, operated or maintained over any street, alley, sidewalk or building in the city which shall be liable to interfere with the work of the fire department in the use of ladders or other apparatus, or which shall obstruct or render hazardous the use of fire escapes; and on complaint of the fire chief, such obstructing, interfering or hazardous wires shall be removed or properly rearranged. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-62. - Same—Powers to remove wires and turn off current; unsafe conditions, powers of officers. 
(a)  The fire marshal, fire chief, building official, electrical inspector, or one (1) of their designees, shall have the power to immediately cause the removal of all wires or the turning off of all electrical current where the circuits interfere with the work of the fire department during the progress of a fire. 
(b)  The fire marshal or building official is hereby authorized and empowered to cause the turning off of electric current from all conductors or fixtures, which, under section 14-101 were not corrected within sixty (60) days after notification of a dangerous or unsafe condition, or which have not been installed in conformity with the provisions of this article; and the corporation, company, partnership, association or individual agent, owner, user or operator has been given sixty (60) days' notice and failed to correct the condition. 
(c)  The fire marshal or building official is authorized to cause the turning off or disconnection of electric current from all conductors or fixtures and/or to cause the disconnection of power or fuel sources from utility distribution systems if the electricity is posing an immediate danger to life or property. Written notification to the property owner at their last known address and to the occupant of the building shall be given within twenty-four (24) hours of the disconnect. No person shall reconnect the power or fuel after a disconnection under this subsection until the fire marshal or building official authorizes the reconnection. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 14, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 11, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-63. - Joint occupancy of signal wires and high-potential wires. 
Signal wires and open conductor spacings shall be in conformity with the electrical code adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-64. - Liability for injury. 
This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person installing, operating or controlling any electric wiring for the distribution of electrical energy for damages to anyone injured thereby; nor shall the city be held as assuming any liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein or certificate or permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-65—14-75. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR 
 
Sec. 14-76. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2064, § 15, adopted Apr. 7, 2015, repealed § 14-76, which pertained to creation of office, qualifications and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007.  
Sec. 14-77. - Enforcing regulations. 
It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this article or any ordinance now in force or which may be adopted concerning the distribution of electrical energy and installation of electrical circuitry, except for those functions delegated to the building official. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-78. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2064, § 15, adopted Apr. 7, 2015, repealed § 14-78, which pertained to supervision of erection of signs and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007.

Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2064, § 15, adopted Apr. 7, 2015, repealed § 14-79, which pertained to assistants and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007.

Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2064, § 15, adopted Apr. 7, 2015, repealed § 14-80, which pertained to deciding questions not herein provided for and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007.  
Sec. 14-81. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-2064, § 15, adopted Apr. 7, 2015, repealed § 14-81, which pertained to records and reports and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007.  
Sec. 14-82. - Interference with inspector. 
No person shall interfere with the electrical inspector. Each such interference shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 16, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 12, 11-19-2018)  
Secs. 14-83—14-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 14-101. - Periodically by fire marshal; notice to repair. 
The fire marshal shall periodically make inspections of electrical work in buildings to which the general public has access. Where wires are in dangerous or unsafe condition, or are deemed to be an interference with the work of the fire department, he shall notify the person owning, using or operating them to place them in a safe, secure and noninterfering condition. Any person failing, neglecting or refusing to make the necessary corrections within sixty (60) days after notification of a dangerous or unsafe condition shall be deemed guilty of violation of this article. Every day which shall elapse after the expiration of such 60-day period until such wires for the distribution of electrical energy are repaired, removed or changed as required by the electrical inspector shall be considered a separate offense within the intent and meaning of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-2171, § 13, adopted Nov. 19, 2018, repealed § 14-102, which pertained to notice to inspector, certificate of satisfactory inspection, conformity with code and derived from Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted Nov. 19, 2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 17, adopted April 7, 2015.  
Sec. 14-103. - Permission to conceal after inspection, notice thereof. 
(a)  No person shall conceal or cause to be concealed any electric wiring for the distribution of electrical energy mentioned in this article except with the express permission of the electrical inspector, and he is hereby authorized and directed to remove any flooring, lathing, plaster, sheet metal or other material which may conceal any electric wiring or fixture contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  On completion of the inspection of any wiring for the distribution of electrical energy or fixtures designed to be concealed and found to be in full compliance with the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to post a notice to that effect at the main cutout center, and such notice shall be considered as an express permission to conceal such electric wiring and fixtures. No concealment shall take place until such notice has been posted by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-104—14-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING CODE 
 
Sec. 14-116. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
House sewers means the sewers leading from the main or lateral sewers to the house on either side. 
Main or lateral sewers means the sewers in the alleys or streets adjacent to the various lots. 
Plumbing is defined as provided in V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1301.002. 
Sanitary sewers means the sanitary sewer system of the city, consisting of main and lateral conduits of salt-glazed vitrified earthenware, and number one concrete sewer pipes, or other similar pipe, with necessary accessories. They are designed to carry off liquid wastes. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-117. - Amendments to the Adopted International Plumbing Code. 
The following parts of the Adopted International Plumbing Code are deleted: 
(1)  Section 109 (Means of Appeal) 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 5, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 14, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-118. - Bond or certificate of insurance of permittee. 
(a)  All plumbers must be licensed through the State of Texas and meet all requirements stated in V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1301. 
(b)  All plumbers must: 
(1)  Obey all ordinances regulating excavations in or puncturing of streets, alleys, or other public property; 
(2)  Refill and refinish such excavations or punctures according to standards established by the city; 
(3)  Replace all pavement in as good condition as same was prior to such excavation of puncture; 
(4)  Place lights and guards around all plumbing materials or apparatus left in any street, alley or other public way; 
(5)  Place lights and guards around all excavations or punctures; and 
(6)  Repair all damages that arise in making connections with water, gas and sewer mains or laterals. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-119. - Inspection requirements. 
(a)  The plumbing inspector shall be given notice when any work is ready for inspection, and all work must be left uncovered and convenient for examination until inspected and approved. Such inspection shall be made within twenty-four (24) hours after notification is received. The plumber shall perform the tests required in the Adopted International Plumbing Code, in the presence of the plumbing inspector, and the plumber shall remove and repair any defective material or labor when so ordered by the plumbing inspector. 
(b)  Before fixtures are placed in connection with the plumbing of any house or building, and before the soil pipe is connected with the sewer, the outlets of the soil pipe and openings into it below the top of the stack shall be hermetically sealed; the pipe shall be filled with water to its top and every joint be carefully examined for leaks. Defective pipes discovered must be removed or replaced with sound ones and all defective joints made tight and every part of the work made to conform to this article, and subject to the approval of the plumbing inspector. 
(c)  In cases where plumbing work has been completed in a building before this article became effective, if the plumbing has been done in accordance with this article, permits will be granted for making connections with the sewer as in new work, but in case such plumbing work does not meet with these requirements, alterations shall be made as the plumbing inspector may direct, to make the plumbing safe to the persons in the house, and such as to be no source of injury or stoppage to the sewer. There shall be at least one (1) four-inch stack on each independent connection with a house sewer. This stack shall be in all cases at the end of the longest horizontal line, and where practicable a minor fixture shall be connected between closet opening and riser. Traps are to be ventilated, fixtures and pipes clean, waste and soil pipes to be of accepted materials and to have sufficient fall, all as specified in this article. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the plumber to provide "AS BUILT" plumbing plans for all underground or under slab plumbing work prior to inspection of such work. Plans shall show all waste, vent, and distribution lines; fixtures, appurtenances and sizes of all domestic or commercial plumbing lines; and underground sewer, storm drainage and fire lines. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 6, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 18-2171, §§ 15, 16, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-120. - Sewer connections required. 
Every building in which plumbing fixtures are installed and all premises having drainage piping shall be connected to the public sewer system. If there is no public sewer available, the owner of the building or premises shall request, from the plumbing inspector, special approval to be connected to a private sewage disposal system. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-121. - Open gutter, cesspool, privy vault; not to be connected. 
No open gutter, cesspool or privy vault shall be connected with any sewer or drain. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-122. - Laying pipe over sewer. 
Any person desiring to lay pipes for water, gas, steam or any purpose in any street or alley upon which sewers are laid, shall give at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice to the plumbing inspector before opening the street or alley and the manner of excavating for the laying and backfilling over such pipe shall be subject to the approval of the plumbing inspector. All such work shall be planned and executed so that no injury shall occur to any house or sewer or drain connected therewith, and so that the excavation and backfilling can be completed in daylight hours if possible. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-123. - Same—Enforcing by city. 
The city, acting through the plumbing inspector or other authorized officer, shall have the power to stop and prevent from discharging into the sewer system substances which are liable to injure the sewers or obstruct the flow of the sewage, or interfere with the operations of the lift stations and the sewage treatment plants. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-124. - Old drains, connections thereto. 
Before any old private drains shall be connected with the sewer system the owner of the private drain shall prove to the satisfaction of the plumbing inspector that it is clean and conforms in every respect with this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-125. - House sewer trenches. 
The house sewer trench shall be dug so as to meet the public sewer at the position of the "Y" branch, if there be one so located by the inspector. The material thrown from the trench shall be placed so as not to obstruct and so as to cause the least inconvenience to the public. Proper barriers and lights must be maintained on the banks of the trench which shall be so dug as to avoid accidents during the progress of the work. In backfilling the earth shall be carefully rammed or flooded so as to keep the pipe in proper position and avoid settling, and no stone shall be used in filling until there has been a depth of at least two (2) feet of fine earth placed over the pipe. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-126. - Miscellaneous prohibitions and regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any building or premises within this city to use, or to permit anyone else to use, any privy or water closet on such premises, that is connected with the sewer system of the city, unless the same shall be used in connection with sufficient water flowing into the sewer to keep the pipes connecting such privies or water closets with the sewers free from obstruction. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any building where people reside or are regularly employed within reach of the sewer systems as provided by this article to fail to have at least one (1) water closet connected with the city sewer system; except, where two (2) adjoining buildings are owned and operated by the same person, only one (1) connection is required. The building owner or occupant is required to maintain the minimum number of plumbing facilities as required by the building code at all times. 
(c)  If on account of the distance from the sewer system, any owner is not required to connect with the sewer system as provided in this article, then privies shall be made to conform with city ordinances now in effect or that may be enacted governing sanitation and outdoor privies. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or allow to be thrown, or deposited upon the surface of the ground or in any hole in or under the surface of the ground where such premises are within the distance prescribed to be connected with the sewer, any water which has been used for domestic or manufacturing purposes, or any liquid or solid filth, feces or urine, after such 30-day period following the enactment and legal publication of this article. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to make or have made any connection with the sanitary sewer system of the city that will permit any surface or drain water from the ground or roof of houses, or the overflowing of cisterns or cesspools, to enter any sanitary sewers, directly or indirectly; provided, however, that the drainage of cellars may be connected with said sanitary sewer system when made in accordance with the regulations in this article and by plans and specifications of the plumbing inspector and under his direct supervision. 
(f)  The use or specification of air admittance vents shall only be permitted upon written approval of the building official. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of a building to install a grease interceptor that has not been sized by an architect or engineer and approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 18, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 16-2092, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 14-127. - Plumbing pipe requirements. 
(a)  The plumbing pipe used above or below the floor slab in all buildings in the city shall comply with the Adopted International Plumbing Code and may include cast iron, copper with wiped joints, plastic. 
(b)  All plumbing pipe used in the city shall comply with the schedules established by the Adopted International Plumbing Code. 
(c)  All pipe must have identifying marks that indicate that it is acceptable for use under the building code adopted by this city. 
(d)  All plastic pipe that is used must be stored in a manner that will not alter the appearance and structure of the pipe. Warped, bent, distorted or discolored pipe is not to be used. 
(e)  All plastic pipe shall be made of materials approved by the Adopted International Plumbing Code, including: 
(1)  Acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS). 
(2)  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC). 
(f)  All pipe shall be marked and graded in accordance with the standards contained in the Standard Plumbing Code. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 7, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 17, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-128. - Gas lines. 
Any person desiring to install a gas line shall provide a gas piping plan and sizing calculations. Gas pipe sizing calculations shall include the demand for the entire system including any proposed piping extensions and appliances. The building official shall approve the gas line if it meets all of the following conditions: 
(1)  All requirements of the International Fuel Gas Code adopted in section 14-1 of this chapter; 
(2)  For piping systems designed to carry in excess of seven (7) ounces of pressure then the system must meet the following requirements: 
a.  Underground piping installations shall be sleeved in a conduit of minimum schedule 40 PVC, ABS, or other approved material. The conduit shall be a minimum one (1) pipe size larger than the gas pipe and be sealed on both ends. The installed underground piping shall have a minimum two (2) feet of cover. 
b.  Above ground installations shall be of steel or wrought-iron and shall be of standard weight (schedule 40). Piping shall be supported a maximum every six (6) feet on center. 
c.  Gas piping shall be permanently identified with the designed pressure at both ends and at an interval not to exceed twenty (20) feet. 
d.  Gas piping shall be provided with a permanent shut off valve on the fuel line prior to entering the ground or entering a structure. 
(Ord. No. 08-1889, § 1, 10-20-2008; Ord. No. 15-2080, § 1, 10-5-2015)  
Secs. 14-129—14-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SWIMMING POOLS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 14-141—14-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FENCES 
 
Sec. 14-161. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Swimming pool means and includes any constructed pool used for swimming or bathing over twenty-four (24) inches in depth or with a surface area exceeding two hundred (200) square feet. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-162. - Fence required for swimming pools. 
Every person in possession of land within the city, either in the capacity of owner, purchaser under contract, lessee, tenant or licensee, upon which there is situated a swimming pool shall at all times maintain a fence, wall or other enclosure not less than four (4) feet in height completely surrounding such swimming pool and effectively denying accidental entrance into the pool by any person. During the period of construction, all swimming pools shall be barricaded or safely covered with mesh, netting or other effective covering to deny accidental entrance until the construction is concluded. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-163. - Minimum size of openings. 
No openings, holes or gaps shall be permitted in any fence required by the provisions of this division that would allow the passage of a four-inch diameter sphere. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 18, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-164. - Gates and doors—Latching device required. 
All gates and doors opening directly into any fence required by the provisions of this division shall be equipped with latching devices designed to keep and being capable of keeping such doors or gates securely closed at all times when not in actual use. Such latching device shall be attached not less than three and one-half (3½) feet from the bottom of such gate or door. The door of any dwelling, not including any attached or unattached garage, occupied by human beings and forming any part of a fence or other enclosure required by this division need not be equipped with such latching devices required of this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-165. - Same—Kept fastened or latched. 
Every person in possession of land on which there is situated a swimming pool around which there is situated a fence shall keep the gates or doors thereto securely fastened or latched at all times except whenever such door or gate is being used by such person, his agent, servant, employee or invitee for entrance into such fenced enclosure. Upon such entry into such enclosure or exit therefrom, such person shall keep such gate or door securely fastened or latched. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-166—14-179. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-180. - Definitions. 
Condominium means a single dwelling unit with a recordable deed, incorporated into a building with multiple dwelling units with shared ownership of common areas. 
Rental dwelling means a single-family dwelling, duplex, triplex, or condominium that is being rented or is available to be rented. 
(Ord. No. 18-2171, § 19, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-181. - Amendments to code. 
(a)  The following parts of the Adopted International Property Maintenance Code are hereby deleted: 
(1)  Section 103.5 (Fees) 
(2)  Section 110 (Demolition) 
(3)  Section 111 (Means of Appeal) 
(b)  Sections of the Adopted International Property Maintenance Code are hereby amended as follows: 
(1)  Section 304.7 is amended to add the following: 
304.7.1 Unsafe equipment. Unused, unsafe, or unnecessary equipment shall be removed from all roofs and roofing areas. 
(2)  Section 304.14 Insect Screens is amended to read as: Every door, openable window, and other outside opening required for ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas or any areas where products to be included or used in food for human consumption are processed, manufactured, packaged or stored shall be supplied with approved tightly fitting screens of not less than 16 mesh per inch (16 mesh per 25 mm), and every screen door used for insect control shall have a self-closing device in good working condition. Dwellings shall be provided with insect screens at every openable window. 
(3)  Section 302.3 is amended to read as follows: 
302.3 Sidewalks, driveways, and parking areas. Sidewalks, walkways, stairs, driveways, parking lots and similar areas shall be kept in a proper state of repair and be maintained free from hazardous conditions. 
(c)  Sections of the Adopted International Property Maintenance Code are hereby amended, for rental dwellings only, as follows: 
(1)  Section 108 is amended to add the following: 
108.8. Providing Habitable Units and Structures. Within 24 hours of the building official posting a notice that a structure or unit is uninhabitable, the tenants of the posted structure or unit must be provided with a habitable unit or structure, if available. The tenants must be allowed to stay in the habitable unit or structure until sufficient repairs are made to the posted unit or structure for the building official to remove the notice. If a habitable unit or structure is not available, then the tenant's rent must be abated until the building official removes the notice. 
Exception: 
(a)  When the actions of the tenant cause the unit or structure to be placarded as uninhabitable, the tenant is responsible for finding his own habitable unit or structure to live in. 
(b)  This section does not apply if the unit or structure is not habitable due to a force majeure event such as a fire, hurricane, flood, or tornado. 
108.8.1. This section does not: 
(a)  Other than the abatement of rent, give a tenant a legal right to violate the terms of his lease; 
(b)  Give a tenant in an apartment community the right to be moved to a structure or unit in a different apartment community; 
(c)  Amend or extend the tenant's lease for the uninhabitable unit or structure, other than allowing the tenant to occupy the habitable unit while the uninhabitable unit or structure is being repaired; 
(d)  State that the owner or operator must give the tenant a new lease for the habitable unit or structure; or 
(e)  Apply if the tenant is in default of the lease for the uninhabitable unit or structure, whether the tenant goes into default before or after being moved to the habitable unit. 
(2)  Section 403 is amended to add the following: 
403.6 All ventilation systems installed in the unit, including central air and air conditioning window units, shall be maintained in working order. (2) Section 403 is amended to add the following: 
403.6 All ventilation systems installed in the unit, including central air and air conditioning window units, shall be maintained in working order. Air conditioning units must be capable of cooling all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms to a temperature of 82ºF or less. Temperature measurements shall be taken from a distance of three (3) feet above floor level. The owner and operator must repair or cause to be repaired the air conditioning system within 72 hours from the time the owner or operator is notified. If repairs cannot be made within 72 hours, the owner and operator must submit a timeline for the repairs to the building official. The timeline must be submitted within the 72 hours. 
(3)  Section 505.4 is amended to add the following: 
505.4.1 Maintenance of Boilers and Water Heaters. Notification must be given to the city within 24 hours of loss of hot water. Boiler systems and hot water heaters must be repaired within 72 hours. If repairs cannot be made within 72 hours, a timeline for the repairs must be submitted to the building official within 48 hours of the loss of hot water. Any changes to the timeline must be approved by the building official. 
Exception: This section does not apply if the failure of the boiler systems or loss of hot water is due to a loss of utilities that is not the fault of the property's operator or owner. 
(4)  Section 602.3 Heat supply is amended to read as: Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling units or sleeping units on terms either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof shall supply heat to maintain a temperature of not less than 68°F (20°C) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and toilet rooms. 
602.3.1 All heating systems installed in the unit shall be maintained in working order. 
602.3.2 The temperature measurements shall be taken from a distance of three (3) feet above floor level. 
Exceptions: 
When the outdoor temperature is below the winter outdoor design temperature for the locality, maintenance of the minimum room temperature shall not be required provided that the heating system is operation at its full design capacity. The winter outdoor design temperature for the locality shall be as indicated in Appendix D of the International Plumbing Code. 
(1)  In areas where the average monthly temperature is above 30°F (-1°C) a minimum temperature of 65°F (18°C) shall be maintained. 
(5)  Section 602.4 Work spaces able to be occupied is amended to read as. Indoor work spaces shall be supplied with heat to maintain a temperature of not less than 65°F (18°C) during the period the spaces are occupied. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  Processing, storage and operation areas that require cooling or special temperature conditions. 
(2)  Areas in which persons are primarily engaged in vigorous physical activities. 
(6)  Section 704.2 is amended to add the following: 
704.2.1 Smoke alarms to be tested. Smoke alarms and/or fire alarms shall be tested at least once every 12 months. A record of the testing of the smoke alarms shall be kept on property and available to the fire marshal's office or building official upon request. An owner or operator may be exempted from testing the alarms of a specific unit if that tenant gives the owner or operator a letter stating that they refuse entry for the purposes of testing the alarms. 
702.2.1.1 This section does not impose a duty on owners or operators to protect tenants that fail to comply with Ch. 92, Subchapter F (Smoke Alarms and Fire Extinguishers) of the Texas Property Code. 
(7)  Section 705 Carbon Monoxide Alarms in is added as follows: 
705. Property owners who rent or lease dwelling units shall supply and install carbon monoxide alarms where the following conditions exist in new or existing rental dwellings: 
1.  The dwelling contains a fuel-fired appliance; or 
2.  The dwelling has an attached garage with an opening that communicates with the dwelling unit. 
705.1. Maintenance of the carbon monoxide alarm shall be the responsibility of the owner and the occupants. 
705.2. Location. Carbon monoxide alarms in dwelling units shall be installed outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of the bedrooms. Where a fuel-burning appliance is located within a bedroom or its attached closet or bathroom, a carbon monoxide alarm shall be installed within the bedroom. 
705.3. Listings. Carbon monoxide alarms shall be listed in accordance with UL 2034. Combination carbon monoxide and smoke alarms shall be listed in accordance with UL 2034 and UL 217. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 11-1959, § 1, 4-18-2011; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 8, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 15-2064, § 19, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 20, 11-19-2018)  
Secs. 14-182—14-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION OF MULTI-FAMILY DWELLING COMPLEXES 
 
Sec. 14-191. - Applicability and administration. 
(a)  This article shall apply to multi-family dwelling complexes with three (3) or more dwelling units. 
(b)  The building official or his designee shall be responsible for administering and enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-192. - Definitions. 
Landlord means the owner, operator, lessor, management company, managing agent, or on-site manager of a multi-family dwelling complex. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-193. - Registration required. 
(a)  The landlord of a multi-family dwelling complex with three (3) or more dwelling units shall annually register the complex by January 1 of each calendar year. 
(b)  A registration is valid for one calendar year, unless the ownership of the complex changes. 
(c)  If a change in ownership of the complex occurs during period the calendar year, the landlord of the complex shall have thirty (30) days from the date of change of ownership to file a new registration. 
(d)  The registration shall be on a form prescribed by the building official and shall at a minimum contain the following information about the complex: 
(1)  The trade name, physical address, business mailing address and total number of units; 
(2)  The names of designated employees or authorized representatives who shall be assigned to respond to emergency conditions and a telephone number where said employees can be contacted during any 24-hour period. Emergency conditions shall include fire, natural disaster, flood, burst pipes, collapse hazard and violent crime; 
(3)  The names, addresses, and telephone numbers of the owner, property manager, resident manager, and registered agent; 
(4)  The type of business entity that owns the complex; 
(5)  The number and type of security systems and fire alarm systems maintained on the premises and the names and telephone numbers of the alarm companies which respond to alarms or relay alarms to emergency services. 
(e)  The landlord commits an offense if he or she operates a multi-family dwelling complex with three (3) or more dwelling units which is not currently registered with the building official. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-194. - Multi-family dwelling complex inspection fee. 
(a)  A multi-family dwelling complex inspection fee of two dollars ($2.00) per unit per month will be charged to each complex. 
(b)  There is no inspection fee for first and second inspections. 
(c)  There shall be a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for third and subsequent inspections. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-195. - Inspections. 
(a)  To determine compliance with minimum building and property maintenance standards in accordance with the International Property Maintenance Code and other applicable city codes and to determine compliance with this article, the building official may conduct: 
(1)  Periodic inspections; 
(2)  Follow-up inspections; and 
(3)  Inspections based on indications of code violations, including complaints filed with the building official. 
(b)  The following areas of a multi-family dwelling complex shall be subject to periodic inspection by the building official: 
(1)  All building exteriors; 
(2)  All exterior and interior common areas; 
(3)  Vacant dwelling units; and 
(4)  Comparative sample of occupied dwelling units upon receipt of consent by the unit's tenant. 
(c)  A report listing all vacant units must be provided to the building official upon request. 
(d)  Vacant units that have not been inspected within a one-year period or that have been damaged must be inspected by the building official prior to being occupied. If the building official does not respond to the request for a vacant unit inspection within five (5) business days, the unit may be rented. If extenuating circumstances exist, the building official may shorten the above-mentioned time frame from five (5) business days to seventy-two (72) hours. 
Exception: All units will be inspected upon immediate request by the building official if the building official is able to do so. The building official reserves the right to have up to seventy-two (72) hours to inspect the unit before move in for extenuating circumstances . 
(e)  The landlord that fails a periodic inspection shall eliminate all violations identified at the time of the periodic inspection. The landlord must allow follow-up inspections by the building official after a reasonable period of time to determine if the violations have been abated. 
(f)  If entry is refused, the building official is authorized to pursue recourse as provided by law, including all rights and authority granted under Article 18.05 of the Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 11-1959, § 1, 4-18-2011)  
Sec. 14-196. - Posting. 
Each multi-family unit described herein shall have prominently displayed in a conspicuous, publicly accessible area on the premises of the complex: 
(1)  Current and valid registration certificates. 
(2)  Signs posted by the owner or owners representative showing the names of designated employees or authorized representatives who shall be assigned to respond to emergency conditions and a telephone number where said employees can be contacted during the 24-hour period. 
(3)  A notice for reporting code violations to the city as follows: TO REPORT UNRESOLVED VIOLATIONS OF CITY PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE, CONTACT THE BUILDING OFFICIAL AT (979) 415-2430. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-197. - Enforcement. 
(a)  A violation of this article is a Class C misdemeanor. 
(b)  Nothing in this article prevents the city from pursuing civil and criminal remedies concurrently or availing itself of any other remedy allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-198—14-215. - Reserved.
