ARTICLE IX. - RESIDENTIAL CODE 
 
Sec. 14-217. - Amendments to code. 
(a)  The following parts of the Adopted International Residential Code are hereby deleted: 
(1)  In Section R105.2, permit exception numbers 1-3, 5 and 10, which are permit exceptions for one-story detached accessories, fences, retaining walls, sidewalks and driveways, and decks. 
(2)  Section R112 (Board of Appeal). 
(b)  Sections AJ.102.2, AJ.201, AJ.301 and AJ.501.3 (Existing Buildings and Structures) of the Adopted International Residential Code are hereby supplemented as follows: 
(1)  If, within any twelve (12) months period, alterations or repairs costing in excess of fifty (50) percent of the then physical value of the building are made to an existing building, such building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
(2)  If an existing building is damaged by fire or otherwise in excess of fifty (50) percent of its then physical value before such damage is repaired, it shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
(3)  If the cost of such alterations or repairs within any twelve (12) month period or the amount of such damage as referred to in paragraph 2 is more than twenty-five (25) but not more than fifty (50) percent of the then physical value of the building the portions to be altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings to such extent as the building official may determine. 
(4)  For the purpose of this section physical value of the buildings shall be determined by the Building Official. 
(5)  Section R314.2.2 is amended as follows: Alterations, repairs, and additions. Where alterations, repairs, or additions require a permit and involve the removal or installation of sheetrock, the smoke alarms shall be installed and the smoke alarms shall be located in the same locations as is required for new buildings. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Work involving the exterior surfaces of dwellings, such as the replacement of roofing or siding, the addition or replacement of windows or doors, or the addition of a porch or deck. 
2.  Installation, alteration or repair of plumbing or mechanical systems. 
3.  Interior work that does not require the removal or installation of sheetrock such as kitchen cabinet replacements, kitchen islands, and bathroom remodels. 
(c)  Section 1004 of the Adopted International Building Code is hereby referenced and supplemented as follows: 
(1)  For purposes of this section: 
(a)  Square footage of a single-family residential dwelling will be based on the square footage of living area on record with the county appraisal district. 
(b)  Occupant means any person who occupies a single-family dwelling as that person's principal place of residence, i.e., where such person usually sleeps. 
(c)  Owner means any person or entity that has legal title, whether singly or jointly, to the single family residential dwelling, or a person who has a right to possession of the single family residential dwelling due to tenancy or other agreement with the legal title owner. 
(2)  The number of occupants allowed in a single family residential dwelling is one per 200 square feet. For example, for a 2,400 square foot house, no more than twelve (12) occupants are allowed. 
(3)  The building official shall give written notice, either through certified mail or hand delivery, to the owner and/or any occupant over the age of 18, of a violation of this section. The notice shall contain a date when the violation must be corrected. If the violation is not corrected, any person to whom the building official gave a written notice of violation may receive a citation. Each occupant in excess of the maximum number of occupants allowed shall be considered a separate violation. 
(4)  Variance. An owner that wishes to exceed the maximum number of occupants allowed may appear before city council to request a variance to this section. Factors to be considered by city council include but are not limited to parking, traffic, noise, age of occupants, and number of complaints in the past year related to the single family dwelling and to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 13-2022, § 10, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 15-2078, §§ 20, 21, 4-7-2015; Ord. No. 18-2171, §§ 22—25, 11-19-2018)  
Secs. 14-218—14-225. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XI. - IRRIGATION CODE 
 
Sec. 14-231. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Installation means fabrication of an irrigation system using components that include piping, fittings, valves, sprinkler heads and pumps; replacement, repair, alteration or maintenance of a lawn sprinkler system component; or lawn sprinkler system site preparation including digging, trenching, vibratory flow operation, and final grading. 
Irrigation system means an assembly of component parts that is permanently installed for the controlled distribution and conservation of water to irrigate any type of landscape vegetation in any location, and/or to reduce dust or control erosion. 
Irrigator means a person who sells, designs, offers consultation regarding, installs, maintains, alters, repairs, services or supervises the installation of an irrigation system, including the connection of such system to a private or public raw or potable water supply system or any water supply. 
(Ord. No. 09-1915, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 14-232. - License required. 
An irrigator must hold a license issued under Ch. 37 of the Texas Water Code and Ch. 1903 of the Texas Occupational Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-1915, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 14-233. - Permit and inspection requirements. 
(a)  All irrigators, prior to performing any irrigation system installation in the territorial limits or the extra-territorial jurisdiction of the city, shall apply for and be issued an irrigation permit. Application for irrigation systems must include system specifications, plans, and a current copy of the site survey. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall be given notice when any work is ready for inspection, and all work must be left uncovered and convenient for examination until inspected and approved. Such inspection shall be made within twenty-four (24) hours after notification is received. 
(c)  The irrigator shall remove and repair any defective material or labor when so ordered by the plumbing inspector. 
(d)  The irrigator shall provide an "AS BUILT" drawing of all underground irrigation lines and systems. 
(Ord. No. 09-1915, § 1, 10-19-2009; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 27, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-234. - Minimum standards and specifications. 
The installation shall be built in accordance with Ch. 1903 of the Texas Occupations Code and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) rules as codified in Vol. 30, Ch. 344 of the Texas Administration Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-1915, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Sec. 14-235. - Exceptions. 
This article does not apply to: 
(1)  An on-site sewage disposal system, as defined by Ch. 366 of the Health and Safety Code; or 
(2)  An irrigation system: 
a.  Used on or by an agricultural operation as defined in Ch. 251 of the Agriculture Code; or 
b.  Connected to a groundwater well used by the property owner for domestic use. 
(Ord. No. 09-1915, § 1, 10-19-2009)  
Secs. 14-236—14-300. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS AND DISTRESSED PROPERTIES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, adopted November 19, 2007, enacted provisions intended for use as article XVI, §§ 14-301—14-345. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as article XI, §§ 14-301—14-345. Additionally, former Art. XI was renumbered as Art. XII, at the discretion of the editor, to facilitate inclusion of a new Art. XI, as set out by Ord. No. 09-1915, § 1, adopted Oct. 19, 2009. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-301. - Purpose of this article. 
This article is adopted pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 54 and 214, to protect the health, safety and welfare, and to preserve the good government, order, and security of the City of Lake Jackson and its inhabitants. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-302. - Definitions. 
Building official means the building official or his duly authorized representative. 
City means the City of Lake Jackson. 
Cleaning an unoccupied building shall include clearing the lot so that it is free and clear of garbage, trash, debris, rubbish, waste, wood and metal scrap, inoperative or abandoned appliances, and furniture. 
DSDB means the dangerous structure determination board. 
Dangerous building means a building or structure that is: 
(1)  Dilapidated, substandard, or unfit for human habitation and a hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare; or 
(2)  Vacant; or 
(3)  Unsecured from unauthorized entry to the extent that it could be entered or used by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children; or 
(4)  Boarded up, fenced, or otherwise secured in any manner if: 
a.  The building constitutes a danger to the public even though secured from entry; 
b.  The means used to secure the building are inadequate to prevent unauthorized entry or use of the building by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children; or 
Vacant means the building has not been legally occupied for one year or more and at least one of the following has occurred throughout the period of non-occupancy: 
(1)  The utilities have been turned off or are not in use; or 
(2)  The doors and windows have been boarded up or secured against entry; or 
(3)  The building is in disrepair to a state that it is visibly not habitable; or 
(4)  The building is not in compliance with the maintenance and security requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 28, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-303. - Declaration of nuisance. 
Any dangerous building is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, is illegal, and shall be abated according to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-304. - Inspection by building official. 
(a)  The building official may inspect all public buildings, schools, halls, churches, theaters, hotels, apartment complexes, tenement, commercial buildings, manufacturing buildings, loft buildings, flea markets, and tents to determine whether any condition exists which would render any such place a dangerous building within this article. 
(b)  The building official, based on a reasonable suspicion standard, may also inspect buildings under the following conditions: 
(1)  A complaint is filed by any person alleging that a premises or a building, wall, or structure is in violation of this article; or 
(2)  A city employee alleges that a premises or a building, wall, or structure is in violation of this article. 
(c)  The building official may enter a building to perform an inspection: 
(1)  With the express consent of a person in control of the property; 
(2)  In accordance with Article 18.05 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure; or 
(3)  If a building is unsecured to the extent that it could be entered by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-305. - Placarding. 
(a)  In emergency situations, the building official shall post the following notice upon each entrance to a dangerous building: 
DANGEROUS BUILDING 
DO NOT ENTER 
Any person who trespasses upon this property shall be prosecuted for criminal trespass under section 30.05 of the Texas Penal Code. 
(b)  Such notice shall remain posted until after the DSDB public hearing and until all orders issued by the DSDB are completed. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to enter any property that contains the notice depicted in subsection (a). 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the notice depicted in subsection (a). 
(e)  The building official shall also post other warning notices that the building official deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-306. - Other proceedings not affected. 
This article does not affect the ability of the city to pursue any other legal remedies allowed by law, including prosecution in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-307. - Minimum standards. 
(a)  In this article, a building meets minimum standards if it is not dangerous and a hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(b)  The following conditions violate minimum standards: 
(1)  Whenever any door, aisle, passageway, stairway, or other means of exit is not of sufficient width or size or is not so arranged as to provide safe and adequate means of exit in case of fire or panic. 
(2)  Whenever the walking surface of any aisle, passageway, stairway, or other means of exit is so warped, worn, loose, torn, or otherwise unsafe as to not provide safe and adequate means of exit in case of fire or panic. 
(3)  Whenever the stress in any material, member or portion thereof, due to all dead and live loads, is more than one and one-half (1½) times the working stress or stresses allowed in the building code for new buildings of similar structure, purpose, or location. 
(4)  Whenever any portion thereof has been damaged by fire, earthquake, wind, flood, or by any other cause, to the extent that structural strength or stability thereof is materially less than it was before such catastrophe and is less than the minimum requirements of the building code for new buildings of similar structure, purpose, or location. 
(5)  Whenever any portion, member, or appurtenance thereof is likely to fail, or to become detached or dislodged, or to collapse and thereby injure persons or damage property. 
(6)  Whenever any portion of a building, any member, appurtenance, or ornamentation on the exterior thereof is not of sufficient strength or stability, or is not so anchored, attached or fastened in place so as to be capable of resisting a wind pressure of one and one-half (1½) times that specified in the building code for new buildings of similar structure, purpose, or location without exceeding the working stress permitted in the building code for such buildings. 
(7)  Whenever the building or structure, or any portion thereof, because of: (i) dilapidation, deterioration, or decay; (ii) faulty construction; (iii) the removal, movement, or instability of any portion of the ground necessary to support such building; (iv) the deterioration, decay, or inadequacy of its foundation; or (v) any other cause, is likely to partially or completely collapse. 
(8)  Whenever, for any reason, the building or structure, or any portion thereof, is unmistakably unsafe for the purpose for which it is being used. 
(9)  Whenever the exterior walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity does not fall inside the middle one-third ( 1/3 ) of the base. 
(10)  Whenever the building or structure, exclusive of the foundation, shows thirty-three (33) percent or more damage or deterioration of its supporting members, or fifty (50) percent damage or deterioration of its non-supporting members, or fifty (50) percent damage or deterioration of enclosing or outside walls or coverings. 
(11)  Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind, earthquake, or flood, or has become so dilapidated, deteriorated or neglected so as to become a harbor for vagrants or criminals. 
(12)  Whenever any building or structure has been constructed, exists, or is maintained in violation of the city's minimum housing standards or technical building codes, to the extent violation poses a threat or potential threat to life, health, safety, or property. 
(13)  Whenever a building or structure is used for dwelling purposes, because of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, decay, damage, faulty construction, arrangement, inadequate light, air, or sanitation facilities, is determined by the health inspector to be unsanitary, unfit for human habitation, or in such a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease. 
(14)  Whenever any building or structure, because of obsolescence, dilapidated condition, deterioration, damage, inadequate exits, lack of sufficient fire-resistive construction, faulty electric wiring, gas connections, or heating apparatus, or other mechanical, structural, or social cause, is determined by the fire marshal or building official to be a fire hazard. 
(15)  Whenever any building or structure is in such condition as to constitute a public nuisance known to the common law or in equity jurisprudence. 
(16)  Whenever any portion of a building or structure remains for a period of time on a site after the demolition or destruction of the building, unless such structure has been approved for partial demolition by the dangerous structure determination board or the department of building inspections in its permitting process. 
(17)  Whenever any building or structure, regardless of its structural condition, is unoccupied by its owners, lessees, or other invitees and is unsecured from unauthorized entry to the extent that it could be entered or by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered by children. 
(18)  Whenever any building or structure is secured by a means inadequate to prevent unauthorized entry or use in the manner described in subsection (17). 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-308—14-315. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS STRUCTURE DETERMINATION BOARD 
 
Sec. 14-316. - Dangerous structure determination board established. 
The dangerous structure determination board (DSDB) is hereby established, and shall consist of five (5) members, as follows: the city engineer, one member appointed by the city council that is either a medical doctor or a registered nurse, and three (3) members appointed by the city council from among the following professions: architecture, real estate, building construction, framing, contracting or engineering. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-317. - DSDB functions. 
(a)  The DSDB shall act as authorized under this article and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 54 and 214. 
(b)  The DSDB may: 
(1)  Order that a building be vacated, secured, repaired, removed, or demolished by the owner within a the timeframe established in this article; 
(2)  Order that the occupants of a building be relocated within a reasonable time; 
(3)  Order, in appropriate cases, the immediate removal of persons or property found on private property, and order entry onto private property to secure the removal if it is determined that conditions exist on the property that constitute a violation of an ordinance, and order action to be taken as necessary to remedy, alleviate, or remove any dangerous building found to exist; 
(4)  Issue orders or directives to any peace officer of the state, including a sheriff or constable or the chief of police of the city, to enforce and carry out the lawful orders or directives of the DSDB; and 
(5)  Determine the amount and duration of a civil penalty the city may recover as provided in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.017 and issue an order in accordance with such determination. 
(c)  The DSDB may only meet if at least four (4) members are present. 
(d)  DSDB actions require the following: 
(1)  Deliberation and discussion of any matter within the board's jurisdiction require a motion and a second. 
(2)  Orders for demolition require the affirmative vote of four (4) members. 
(3)  All other orders require the affirmative vote of three (3) members. 
(e)  The DSDB shall devise its administrative procedures, review and adjust such procedures annually, and make available a copy of such procedures to any interested persons. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-318—14-325. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 14-326. - Commencement of proceedings. 
(a)  Whenever the building official has determined that a building or structure is a dangerous building, he shall obtain a date and time for a public hearing before the DSDB to determine whether the building complies with the building codes adopted in this chapter. The building official may seek voluntary compliance with this chapter before seeking a hearing before the DSDB. If the building official receives voluntary compliance, the building official need not ask for a hearing before the DSDB. 
(b)  Meetings of the DSDB shall be held at the call of the chairman and at other times as determined by the DSDB. All meetings of the DSDB are open to the public. The chairman, or acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-327. - Notice of hearing. 
(a)  On or before the tenth day before the date fixed for the hearing, notice shall be: 
(1)  Sent by personal delivery, by certified mail with return receipt requested, or by delivery by the United States Postal Service using signature confirmation service to the owner and each lienholder and mortgagee, as can be ascertained through a diligent effort; 
(2)  Posted on the front door of each improvement situated on the affected property or as close to the front door as practicable; and 
(3)  Published in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Lake Jackson on one (1) occasion. 
(b)  The notice of the hearing may also be filed in the official public records of real property for Brazoria County, Texas. The filing of the notice is binding on subsequent grantees, lienholders, or other transferees of an interest in the property who acquire such interest after the filing of the notice, and constitutes notice of the hearing on any subsequent recipient of any interest in the property who acquires such interest after the filing of the notice. 
(c)  The notice must contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner of the affected property, if that information can be determined; 
(2)  A legal description of the affected property; 
(3)  A description of the hearing; 
(4)  The date, time, and place of the hearing; and 
(5)  A statement that the owner, lienholder, or mortgage shall be required to present proof at the hearing of the scope of any work that may be required to comply with this article and the time it will reasonably take to perform the work. 
(d)  A diligent effort shall mean a search of the following records: 
(1)  County real property records of Brazoria County; 
(2)  Appraisal district records of Brazoria County; 
(3)  Records of the secretary of state; 
(4)  Assumed name records of Brazoria County; 
(5)  City of Lake Jackson tax records; and 
(6)  City of Lake Jackson utility records. 
(e)  If the notice is returned as "refused" or "unclaimed", the validity of the notice is not affected and the notice is considered delivered. 
(f)  If the DSDB opens a properly noticed public hearing, it may then continue the public hearing to another date without following the above notice requirements. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-328. - Public hearing. 
(a)  At the public hearing, the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee has the burden of proof to demonstrate the scope of any work that may be required to comply with this article and the time it would reasonably take to perform the work. 
(b)  At the hearing, the building official shall present evidence of the condition of the building and may recommend a course of action. Personnel of other departments or appropriate agencies may also present facts bearing on the condition of the building. 
(c)  At the hearing, the owner, lienholder, mortgagee, or any other interested person may present evidence on any relevant issue. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-329. - Standards for repair, vacation, or demolition; DSDB review of demolition settlement. 
The following standards shall guide the building official in his discretion in ordering a hearing to repair, vacate, secure, and/or demolish a dangerous building and these shall be observed and applied by the hearing officers who comprise the DSDB: 
(1)  If the alleged dangerous building can be feasibly repaired or the condition remedied so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article, it shall first be ordered remedied or repaired by the hearing officers. Demolition shall be regarded as a remedy of last resort. 
(2)  If the building is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health or safety of its occupants, it shall be ordered by the hearing officers to be vacated. 
(3)  In any case where a dangerous building is fifty (50) percent or more damaged or decayed or deteriorated in its structure, or fifty (50) percent or more diminished in its value due to damage, decay, or deterioration, a presumption shall arise that the building cannot be repaired. Such presumption may be appropriately rebutted by the weight of the evidence. 
(4)  Principles of sound engineering practices shall be respected. 
(5)  In all cases of settlement in which a responsible party enters into a voluntary demolition agreement to accept city serviced demolition, all settlement agreements shall be reviewed by the DSDB prior to execution by the duly authorized city official possessing settlement authority. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-330. - DSDB orders. 
(a)  After the public hearing, if a building is found to be a dangerous building, the DSDB shall require the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee to, within thirty (30) days: 
(1)  Secure the building from unauthorized entry; or 
(2)  Repair, remove, or demolish the building, unless the owner or lienholder establishes at the hearing that the work cannot reasonably be performed within thirty (30) days. 
(b)  If the DSDB allows the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee more than thirty (30) days to repair, remove, or demolish the building, the DSDB shall establish specific time schedules for the commencement and performance of the work and shall require the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee to secure the property in a reasonable manner from unauthorized entry while the work is being performed. 
(c)  The DSDB may not allow the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee more than ninety (90) days to repair, remove, or demolish the building or fully perform all work required to comply with the order unless the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee: 
(1)  Submits a detailed plan and time schedule for the work at the hearing; and 
(2)  Establishes at the hearing that the work cannot reasonably be completed with[in] ninety (90) days because of the scope and complexity of the work. 
(d)  If the DSDB allows the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee more than ninety (90) days to complete any part of the work required to repair, remove, or demolish the building, the DSDB shall require the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee to regularly submit progress reports to the building official to demonstrate compliance with the time schedules established for commencement and performance of the work. The order may require that the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee appear before the DSDB to demonstrate compliance with the time schedules. If the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee owns property, including structures or improvements on property, within the municipal boundaries that exceeds one hundred thousand ($100,000.00) in total value, the DSDB may require the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee to post a cash or surety bond in an amount adequate to cover the cost of repairing, removing, or demolishing a building under this subsection. In lieu of a bond, the DSDB may require the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee to provide a letter of credit from a financial institution or a guaranty from a third party approved by the municipality. The bond must be posted, or the letter of credit or third party guaranty provided, not later than the 30th day after the date the municipality issues the order. 
(e)  The DSDB, by order, may assess and recover a civil penalty against the property owner in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day for each violation or, if the owner shows that the property is the owner's lawful homestead, in an amount not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each violation, if the city proves: 
(1)  The property owner was notified of the requirements of this article and the owner's need to comply with the requirements; and 
(2)  After notification, the property owner committed an act in violation of this article or failed to take an action necessary for compliance with this article. 
(f)  The DSDB may also order a civil penalty that the city may assess if the owner fails to repair, remove or demolish the building in accordance with the board's order. Such penalty shall not exceed the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day that the building is out of compliance with the order. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-331. - Post hearing notice. 
(a)  Within ten (10) days after the date the order is issued, the city shall file a copy of the order in the city secretary's office and publish once in a newspaper of general circulation within the city a notice of: 
(1)  The street address or legal description of the property; 
(2)  The date of the hearing; 
(3)  A brief statement of results of the hearing; and 
(4)  Instructions stating where a complete copy of the order may be obtained. 
(b)  After the hearing, the city will mail by certified mail with return receipt requested, deliver by the United States Postal Service using signature confirmation service, or personally deliver a copy of the order to the owner of the building and to any lienholder or mortgagee of the building. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-332. - Post hearing actions. 
(a)  If the building is not vacated, secured, repaired, removed, or demolished, or the occupants are not relocated within the allotted time, the municipality may: 
(1)  Vacate, secure, remove, or demolish the building or relocate the occupants at its own expense; or 
(2)  Assess a civil penalty against the owner of the building for failure to comply with the DSDB order. Notice of the civil penalty shall be sent by certified mail return receipt requested to the owner and each lienholder and mortgagee. 
(b)  If the city incurs expenses or assesses a civil penalty under this section, the city may assess expenses and file a lien against the property, unless it is homestead property protected by the Texas Constitution. The notice of lien filed with the county clerk's office must contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner, if known; 
(2)  A legal description of the property; 
(3)  The amount of expenses incurred by the city; and 
(4)  The amount owed to the city. 
(c)  If notice is given to the mortgagee and lienholder, as authorized under this article, then the lien is a privileged lien, subordinate only to tax liens. 
(d)  This section does not limit the ability of a municipality to collect on a bond or other financial guaranty that may be required by section 14-330. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-333. - Obstruction of official action. 
It is unlawful for any person to obstruct or interfere with any officer, employee, contractor or authorized representative of the city whenever such officer, employee, contractor or authorized representative is engaged in the work ordered by the DSDB or is engaged in any act that is preliminary to or incidental to such work. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Secs. 14-334—14-340. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ADDITIONAL ENFORCEMENT MEASURES 
 
Sec. 14-341. - Securing buildings. 
The city may secure and clean a building, regardless of its structural condition, that is unoccupied by its owners, lessees, or other invitees and is unsecured from unauthorized entry to the extent that it could be entered or used by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be entered or used by children. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-342. - Notice of secured building. 
(a)  Before the eleventh day after the date the building is secured and/or cleaned pursuant to section 14-341, the city will give notice to the owner of the building by either: 
(1)  Personally serving the owner with written notice; 
(2)  Mailing the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested; or 
(3)  If personal service cannot be obtained and the owner's post office address is unknown: 
a.  Publishing the notice at least twice within a ten-day period in the official newspaper of the city; or 
b.  Posting the notice on or near the front door of the building. 
(b)  The notice will contain: 
(1)  An identification of the building and the property on which it is located; 
(2)  A statement that the city has secured and/or cleaned the building; 
(3)  The amount of expenses that shall be assessed against the property; and 
(4)  The owner's right to request a hearing about any matter relating to the city's securing and/or cleaning of the building. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-343. - Hearing of secured building. 
(a)  If, within thirty (30) days after the date the city secures and/or cleans a building pursuant to section 14-341, the owner files with the city a written request for a hearing, the DSDB will conduct a hearing at which the owner may testify or present witnesses or written information about any matter relating to the city's securing and/or cleaning of the building. 
(b)  The DSDB will conduct the hearing within twenty (20) days after the date the request is filed. 
(c)  After the hearing, the DSDB shall enter an order stating that: 
(1)  The city's securing and/or cleaning of the building was necessary and stating the amount of expenses that shall be assessed against the property; or 
(2)  The city's securing and/or cleaning of the building was not necessary and state that the city shall not recover any expenses. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-344. - Procedure after secured building hearing. 
After the hearing before the DSDB, the city will provide notice of the order in the same manner provided for in section 14-331. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007)  
Sec. 14-345. - Emergency abatement by city officials. 
(a)  In order to preserve the health, safety, and welfare of the city and its inhabitants, if the building official or fire marshal determine that one or more structural conditions threaten the structural integrity of a building or structure and that the building or structure pose a clear and imminent danger to the life, safety or property of any person, the city manager and either the building official or fire marshal shall order the immediate vacation, and demolition or repair of such building or structure. In the case of demolition, concurrence of the building official is required. 
(b)  The foregoing emergency abatement action shall be executed not later than seventy-two (72) weekday hours, exclusive of weekends and holidays, after the official views the subject building or structure. 
(c)  After the building is vacated and either repaired or demolished, the official taking action shall immediately provide notice to the DSDB and to the owner and the lienholder/mortgagees of said dangerous building in the manner provided in section 14-327. 
(d)  All costs, including asbestos and special or hazardous waste removal/disposal, grading, leveling, and clearance of such emergency vacation, repair, or demolition shall be collected in the manner provided in section 14-332. 
(e)  If, within thirty (30) days after the date the city vacates, repairs or demolishes a building pursuant to subsection 14-345(a), the owner files with the city a written request for a hearing, the DSDB will conduct a hearing in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 14-343. 
(f)  Upon ordering and executing emergency abatement by demolition, the building official shall execute an affidavit describing his actions. Copies of the affidavit shall be maintained among the official records of the building official's department and in the minute records of the DSDB for two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 07-1872, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 18-2171, § 29, 11-19-2018)  
Sec. 14-346. - Emergency abatement for safety of first responders. 
(a)  If the building official or fire marshal determines that one or more structural conditions threaten the immediate safety of first responders, the building official or fire marshal shall order the immediate vacation of the building or structure, and shall demolish or repair the building or structure or portions thereof to the extent that it no longer poses such a hazard. 
(b)  After the building or structure is vacated and either repaired or demolished, the procedure set forth in section 14-345 shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 18-2171, § 30, 11-19-2018)  
Chapter 18 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - DONATION DROP BOXES 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning.] 
Donation drop box means any unattended outdoor container, receptacles, or similar device used for soliciting and collecting donations such as clothing, toys, or other salvageable personal property. 
Property owner means the person that has care and control of the parking area where the donation drop box is placed. 
Operator means a person who manages the organization for which the donations are solicited or the person who applies for the donation drop box permit. 
(Ord. No. 13-2014, § 1, 8-5-2013)  
Sec. 18-2. - Permit required. 
(a)  Operators of donation drop boxes are prohibited from placing donation drop boxes on all public and private property in the city without first obtaining a permit from the building official. The permit must be renewed annually. 
(b)  To obtain a permit, the operator must pay a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee and show: 
(1)  A sketch indicating the spot where the donation drop box will be placed; 
(2)  The dimensions of the donation drop box; 
(3)  The signage that will be on the donation drop box; 
(4)  Written consent from the property owner, property manager, or person who has a right to possession of the property, indicating that the donation drop box may be placed on their property and acknowledging that they will be held responsible for maintenance of the area around the donation drop box; and 
(5)  That the donation drop box will comply with all requirements in this article. 
(c)  The operator may not transfer the permit to any other person or organization. 
(d)  The operator shall affix a copy of the permit to the donation drop box in a manner that ensures that it will not [be] damaged by rain. 
(Ord. No. 13-2014, § 1, 8-5-2013)  
Sec. 18-3. - Permit revocation. 
(a)  The building official may revoke the permit for failure of the operator or property owner to comply with the requirements in this article. The operator may appeal the revocation to the city manager or his designee within seventy-two (72) hours of the revocation notice. 
(b)  The donation drop box must be removed within seven (7) days of the permit revocation. If not removed within seven (7) days, the city shall have it removed and the operator shall be billed the removal and storage costs. 
(Ord. No. 13-2014, § 1, 8-5-2013)  
Sec. 18-4. - Construction and placement. 
(a)  Donation drop boxes may not be placed on any residentially zoned property with the exception of R-4. 
(b)  Donation drop boxes must: 
(1)  Be constructed of metal, fiber glass or wood; 
(2)  Have a sign or label indicating the name, address, and telephone number of the organization; 
(3)  Be secured at all times, except when they are being emptied; 
(4)  Have a lid or a top to protect the contents from the weather; and 
(5)  Be no larger than one hundred two (102) cubic feet. 
(c)  Donation drop boxes may not be placed so that they block driveways, interfere with traffic flow or visibility, are on minimum required parking spaces, are in front, rear, or side yard setback, or on a required landscape area. 
(d)  Only one (1) donation drop box may be placed on a platted lot. 
(Ord. No. 13-2014, § 1, 8-5-2013)  
Sec. 18-5. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The area around the donation drop box shall be kept free of debris and shall be emptied often enough so that the donations do not overflow. 
(b)  Donation drop boxes shall not have structural damage, holes, or visible rust. 
(c)  The city shall give the property owner seventy-two (72) hours written notice to clear the debris. If the debris is not cleared, the city shall clear the debris and bill the property owner for the clean-up costs. 
(Ord. No. 13-2014, § 1, 8-5-2013)  
Sec. 18-6. - Existing donation drop boxes. 
(a)  Operators of existing donation drop boxes shall be given oral notice that they have thirty (30) days to obtain a permit. If the operators do not apply for a permit, the operators and the property owners have thirty (30) days to remove the donation drop boxes or the property owners may give the city permission to remove the donation drop boxes. 
(b)  If an operator cannot be reached, a letter will be mailed to the address on the donation drop box, if available, and posted on the donation drop box itself. The operator shall have thirty (30) days from the day the letter is mailed or posted on the box. 
(c)  If the city removes the donation drop box, the property owner or the operator shall be billed the removal and storage costs. 
(Ord. No. 13-2014, § 1, 8-5-2013)  
Secs. 18-7—18-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ITINERANT PRECIOUS METALS, CRAFTED PRECIOUS METALS, GEMS, AND SEMIPRECIOUS STONES DEALERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Crafted precious metals, dealer purchase and disposition, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 9009a. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, adopted Feb. 16, 2010, amended Art. II, Div. 1, to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, Div. 1, §§ 18-26—18-32, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 81-785, § 1, adopted Apr. 6, 1981; and Code 1958, §§ 14-29(b), (f), (g) and (i). 
 
Sec. 18-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Crafted precious metal means jewelry, silverware, an art object, or another object, other than a coin or commemorative medallion, made in whole or in part from precious metal. 
Itinerant dealer means a person who engages in the business of purchasing and/or selling crafted precious metal or gems or semiprecious stones from a building, structure or any part thereof that the person has leased, occupied, or used for a period or term of less ninety (90) days or from a motor vehicle. For the purposes of this article, any person conducting such business from a hotel or motel room shall be presumed to be an itinerant dealer. 
Precious metal means gold, silver, platinum, palladium, iridium, rhodium, osmium, ruthenium, or an alloy of those metals. 
Gems or semiprecious stones shall mean any natural or industrially produced gem of some value whether of precious or semiprecious quality, customarily used in jewelry or ornamentation. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-27. - Applicability of subchapter. 
This subchapter applies only to the sale and/or purchase of precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, and semiprecious stones that have been used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes and that is sold to itinerant dealers. It does not apply to dental or pharmaceutical applications; liquidations, government, or judicial sales; pawnshops; or dealer to dealer sales. This article does not replace V.T.C.A., Occupations Code Ch. 1956, which regulates the sale and purchase of precious metals. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-28. - Permit. 
(a)  No itinerant dealer may purchase or sell precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, or semiprecious stones in the City of Lake Jackson without an itinerant precious metals dealers permit issued by the chief of police. The information provided on the permit application shall include: 
(1)  A copy of the registration statement required under state law to be filed with Texas Department of Public Safety; 
(2)  The name and address and local contact phone number of the itinerant dealer; 
(3)  The location where business is to be conducted within the city; 
(4)  If the itinerant dealer is an association, the name and address of each member of the association; 
(5)  If the itinerant dealer is a corporation, the name and address of each officer and director of the corporation; 
(6)  Driver's license number of the itinerant dealer and employees who will be working in Lake Jackson; 
(7)  Whether or not the itinerant dealer or any employee of the itinerant dealer, has been found guilty of any criminal offense by any court of competent jurisdiction and, if so, the venue of such offense and penalty imposed; 
(8)  Whether or not the itinerant dealer has been or is currently a party of any civil litigation arising out of sales or purchases or any goods or services and if so, the identity of other parties to the suit, the location of the suit, and the outcome of the suit; 
(9)  Whether the itinerant dealer has ever before engaged in business under an assumed name, and if so, the name assumed by such business; and 
(10)  Any other information deemed necessary by the chief of police. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued to an itinerant dealer if he has been convicted of, in the past three (3) years, a crime involving theft or a violation of V.T.C.A., Occupations Code Ch. 1956. 
(c)  A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid before the permit is issued. 
(d)  The permit is nontransferable and shall be kept publicly displayed at the itinerant dealer's place of business. 
(e)  The permit shall expire thirty (30) days after it has been issued. However, if the itinerant dealer changes the location within the city where business is to be conducted, the itinerant dealer must apply for a new permit. 
(f)  Itinerant dealers may apply for another permit no earlier than seven (7) days before the initial permit expires. There is no limit on the number of permits that an itinerant dealer may apply for. 
(g)  The permit may be revoked by the chief of police if the itinerant dealer is found guilty of a criminal offense of theft or if the itinerant dealer has violated this article. Within ten (10) days of such revocation by the chief of police, the permit holder shall have the right of appeal to the city council whose decision shall be final. Once a permit is revoked, the itinerant dealer may not apply for another permit. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-29. - Seller information required; filing. 
(a)  Before the itinerant dealer may accept any of a seller's property, the seller must file with the itinerant dealer a list describing all of the seller's precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, and semiprecious stones to be accepted by the itinerant dealer. The list must contain: 
(1)  The seller's name, address, and age; 
(2)  A complete and accurate description of the articles, including weight and names, letters, numbers, and/or other identifying marks appearing on the items; and 
(3)  The seller's certification that the information is true and complete. 
(b)  The itinerant dealer shall record the seller's driver's license number, or personal identification number, military ID number or passport number upon physical presentation of the license or personal identification certificate by the seller. The record must accompany the list. 
(c)  The list shall be submitted to the chief of police not later than forty-eight (48) hours after the information is given to the itinerant dealer. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-30. - Report; filing. 
(a)  In addition to the abovementioned list, the itinerant dealer must also file a report with the chief of police stating: 
(1)  The amount paid or sold for the article. 
(2)  A concise description of the article including make, model, brand name and physical description. 
(b)  The report shall be filed with the chief of police not later than 48 hours after the item is purchased or sold. 
(c)  The itinerant dealer shall retain a copy of the report until the third anniversary of the date the report is filed. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-31. - Required retention of precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, and semiprecious stones. 
(a)  An itinerant dealer may not melt, deface, alter, or dispose of precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, or semiprecious stones that are the subject of the list required by this article before the twenty-first day after the date the list is filed unless: 
(1)  The chief of police to whom the report is submitted authorizes disposition of the articles; or 
(2)  The itinerant dealer obtains the name, address, and description of the buyer and retains a record of that information. 
(b)  Within the twenty-one-day period, the itinerant dealer may not make or cause to be made any change to the item purchased. If the chief of police has reasonable suspicion that the item is stolen or to believe that the information furnished by the seller is false, the retention period may be extended for a reasonable amount of time for the police to conduct an investigation. 
(c)  An itinerant dealer who retains information under subsection (a)(2) shall make that information available for inspection by any peace officer. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-32. - Inspection of precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, and semiprecious stones by peace officer. 
An itinerant dealer shall make precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, and semiprecious stones purchased by the itinerant dealer available for inspection by a peace officer during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-33. - Purchase from minor. 
An itinerant dealer may not purchase precious metal, crafted precious metal, gems, or semiprecious stones from a person younger than 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 18-34. - Violation. 
A violation of this division shall be a Class C misdemeanor and the penalty for violating this article shall be as provided for in section 1-5 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Lake Jackson. Each and every item acquired in violation of this article shall be deemed a separate transaction and each failure of an itinerant dealer to keep a record of each transaction as required by this article or to comply with any other provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10-1931, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Secs. 18-35—18-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 18-46. - Required. 
No itinerant dealer or dealer regularly licensed to do business in the city may purchase gold, silver, platinum, gems or semiprecious stones without a license, nor shall any dealer hold himself out by advertising or otherwise as a purchaser located in the city without first obtaining a license. Such advertising prior to the granting of the license shall constitute cause for its denial. Such application shall be made on a form prescribed by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 81-785, § 1, 4-6-81; Code 1958, § 14-29(a))  
Sec. 18-47. - Fee and procedures. 
(a)  Licenses required by this division shall be issued by the chief of police to any applicant able to produce satisfactory evidence of good character who has not been convicted of a crime as described in applicable provisions of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. arts. 6252-13c and 6252-13d within the immediate past seven (7) years, upon payment of the required fees, posting of the required bonds and compliance with all other requirements of this section. Application for such license shall be made on forms prescribed by the chief of police, the information upon which shall include the applicant's full name, any aliases, address, age, sex, social security number, criminal record if any, fingerprints and photograph, and the name, address and telephone number of the applicant's employer or proposed employer. 
(b)  The license shall designate the premises on which the licensee shall conduct his business and specify the date or dates upon which the business may be conducted. The license shall be issued on a twelve-month basis; except that itinerant dealer licenses shall be valid for the period of time stated in the application or one (1) year, whichever is shorter. 
(c)  A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day shall be charged to itinerant dealers and a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per year shall be charged to dealers regularly licensed to do business in the city. 
(Ord. No. 81-785, § 1, 4-6-81; Code 1958, § 14-29(c))  
Sec. 18-48. - False statements. 
Any false statements made on the application form for a license under this division void the license from its inception. 
(Ord. No. 81-785, § 1, 4-6-81; Code 1958, § 14-29(e))  
Sec. 18-49. - Nontransferable and display. 
The license issued under this division shall be a personal privilege and shall not be transferable, nor shall there be any abatement of the tax upon such license by reason of the fact that the licensee shall have exercised the privilege for any period of less than that for which it was granted. The license shall at all times be kept publicly exposed by the licensee on his business premises. 
(Ord. No. 81-785, § 1, 4-6-81; Code 1958, § 14-29(d))  
Sec. 18-50. - Bond. 
Every itinerant dealer licensed under this division shall at the time of license and before the same shall be operative, enter with either one (1) corporate or two (2) personal sufficient sureties into a joint and several recognizance to the city in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) conditioned upon due observance of the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 81-785, § 1, 4-6-81; Code 1958, § 14-29(h))  
Secs. 18-51—18-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK CAFES 
 
Sec. 18-76. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, certain words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means a person who makes an application for a permit for a sidewalk cafe. 
City manager means the city manager or his designee, including code enforcement officers. 
Contiguous restaurant means a restaurant that adjoins the area where the sidewalk cafe will be located and in which food preparation, sanitation and related services for the sidewalk cafï¿½1/21/2 shall be performed. 
Downtown means the triangular area bounded by State Highway 332, Oyster Creek Drive, and Oak Drive. 
Permittee means a person who receives a permit to operate a sidewalk cafï¿½1/21/2. 
Public necessity means any lawful need or use of property by a governmental body including needs created by a change in circumstances affecting pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
Public street means the entire width of a way which is held by the city in fee or by easement or dedication that has a part open for public use for vehicular travel. 
Restaurant means a food service establishment where food is served in individual portions for consumption on the premises. This term shall not include an establishment which operates exclusively as a caterer, a mobile food unit, a retail food store or a temporary food service establishment. 
Roadway means that portion of a public street which is improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the curb, berm, or shoulder. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a public street which is between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, that is improved and designed for or is ordinarily used for pedestrian travel. 
Sidewalk cafe means an outdoor dining area located on a public sidewalk and containing removable tables, chairs, plants, and related appurtenances. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-77. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, vend, operate, maintain or serve any item from a sidewalk cafe without a valid permit. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-78. - Permit application. 
(a)  Application for a sidewalk cafe permit shall be made in writing to the city manager. 
(b)  Sidewalk cafes shall be permitted only when such are abutting and contiguous to a restaurant in the downtown area in which food preparation, sanitation and related services for the sidewalk cafe shall be performed. 
(c)  The following shall be included in the application: 
(1)  Proof of general liability insurance as further described in this article; 
(2)  Proof of ownership of the property that adjoins the area where the sidewalk cafe will be located, or written permission from the owner of such property for the applicant to operate a sidewalk cafe; and 
(3)  A sketch showing the proposed layout of the site, including sidewalk dimensions; location of existing fixtures; number, size, and location of tables and chairs; location and size of barriers; and location of entrances and exits to the contiguous restaurant. 
(d)  Prior to issuance of the permit, adjacent properties shall be notified of the application. The property owners and tenants shall be given fourteen (14) calendar days to contact the city manager with any concerns or questions. The city manager may take the concerns into account when deciding whether to issue the permit. 
(e)  If the permit is denied, the applicant may appeal the denial to the city council within fourteen (14) calendar days of the denial. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-79. - Operational requirements. 
(a)  Sidewalk cafes may only be open during the hours the contiguous restaurant is open. 
(b)  The permittee must clean the area and adjacent sidewalk and street of spills and litter each night after the sidewalk cafe is closed. 
(c)  If a sidewalk cafe uses disposable or paper plates or napkins, the sidewalk cafe shall provide an outdoor trash receptacle for patrons. 
(d)  All sidewalks shall be pressure washed when directed to do so by the city manager. 
(e)  Neither food nor beverages shall be served to a patron at a sidewalk cafe unless that patron is seated at a table. 
(f)  Alcohol may be served in glasses or mugs only. It may not be served in bottles or cans. 
(g)  The city manager may impose additional requirements not addressed in this article to protect against health hazards related to sidewalk cafe operation and may modify requirements for physical facilities when health, safety or welfare concerns arise. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-80. - Insurance and indemnification. 
(a)  The permittee's insurance policy shall be issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. The insurance shall meet or exceed the following minimum amounts: two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for each person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for each single occurrence for bodily injury or death and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each single occurrence for injury to or destruction of property. The city shall be an additional insured on each such policy and such policy shall include a provision to the effect that the city will be notified in writing by the insurance company thirty (30) days prior to the cancellation of such policy. The permittee shall then have ten (10) days to replace that coverage or the permit shall be deemed revoked without further action on the part of the city. 
(b)  The permittee shall bear all risk of loss or damages to permittee's property and will indemnify and hold harmless the city for all liabilities arising out of the operation of the sidewalk cafe. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-81. - Encroachment; barriers; obstructions. 
(a)  Sidewalk cafes shall not encroach in whole or in part upon any sidewalk or public walkway in such a manner that it significantly impedes or inconveniences pedestrians. 
(b)  No sidewalk cafe may be enclosed by fixed walls. 
(c)  Sidewalk cafe boundaries must be outlined by the use of temporary barriers such as balustrades, planters, cordons or railings unless a barrier outlining the area already exists. Temporary barriers must be easily removed and shall not be affixed to the sidewalk or to any permanent structure. 
(d)  All sidewalk cafes shall be open to the air, but canopies are permitted. 
(e)  Sidewalk cafes shall in no way obstruct the ingress to or egress from any other building or business. 
(f)  All sidewalk cafes and their attendant facilities or improvements shall comply with clearances required for structures in relation to utility lines. 
(g)  Sidewalk cafes shall not obstruct access to hydrants, street lights, or mailboxes. 
(h)  Tables, chairs, and barriers do not need to be removed nightly. However, all table umbrellas must be closed every night. 
(i)  The permittee is responsible for the condition of the sidewalk and the making of repairs to the sidewalk area. Repairs shall be made within thirty (30) days notice from the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-82. - Lighting. 
Sidewalk cafes shall provide and maintain adequate lighting so as allow pedestrians to observe and avoid obstructions. Additionally all lighting shall be in compliance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Lighting shall not be located or affixed in a manner which shall interfere with or obscure the vision of vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Lighting shall be shaded and directed in such a way that it is not obtrusive to adjacent property owners. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-83. - Hours of operation. 
A sidewalk cafe may operate only during the normal and regularly operated hours of the restaurant to which it is adjacent. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-84. - Permit length and fees. 
Permits shall expire on March 31 of each year. The initial permit fee shall be twenty-four dollars ($24.00), calculated on a pro rata basis. The permit renewal fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-85. - Permit revocation. 
(a)  Sidewalk cafe permits constitute a privilege, not a right and as such are subject to demands to remove, either temporarily or permanently, any and all facilities, without liability, upon notice by the city manager that public necessity exists. 
(1)  Written notice shall be provided as promptly as possible. 
(2)  The notice shall provide the reason or reasons for removal. 
(b)  Aside from public necessity, the following shall be grounds for revocation of the sidewalk cafe permit: 
(1)  Three (3) violations of this article within a twelve-month span; 
(2)  Disturbance of the peace; 
(3)  Risk to public safety; or 
(4)  Allowing alcohol to leave the premises. 
(c)  Prior to revocation for the reasons listed in subsection (b), the permittee shall give ten (10) days' written notice. If the permittee requests a hearing prior to the expiration of that ten-day notice period, the city council shall hold a hearing to determine if the permit shall be revoked. If the permittee fails to request such a hearing, the revocation shall become effective upon the expiration of the ten-day notice period. If operations under a permit granted under this section are revoked, all tables, chairs and other appurtenances used as a part of the sidewalk cafe shall be immediately removed from the sidewalk. 
(d)  A new sidewalk cafe permit shall not be issued for one (1) year following revocation, unless the ownership of the sidewalk cafe changes. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Sec. 18-86. - Bond requirement. 
No sidewalk cafe permit shall be issued until an applicant has provided a cash bond or surety bond, with permittee as the principal and a corporate bonding company licensed to do business in the State of Texas as a surety, in an amount sufficient to cover the costs of removal of the facilities or improvements by the city or any public utility under any of the provisions of this article. Should permittee fail to timely remove its facilities upon request or demand, said permittee shall reimburse the city or any public utility in the event that the city or public utility removes the facilities pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-1924, § 1, 1-4-2010)  
Secs. 18-87—18-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-101. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, certain words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Achromatic means colorless or lacking in saturation or hue. The term includes, but is not limited to, grays, tans, and light earth tones. The term does not include white, black, or any bold coloration that attracts attention. 
Adult bookstore/adult video store means a commercial establishment or enterprise which has as a significant or substantial portion of its stock in trade, or which derives a significant or substantial portion of its revenues or devotes a significant or substantial portion of its interior business or advertising, or maintains a substantial section of its sales or display space for sale or rental, or any form of consideration any one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals, or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motions pictures, video cassettes, digital video discs, or video reproductions, slides, or other visual representations which depict or describe "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas"; or 
(2)  Instruments, devices, toys, novelties, or paraphernalia which are designed for use in connection with "specified sexual activities". 
Adult cabaret means a restaurant or similar commercial establishment that regularly features: 
(1)  Persons who appear in a state of nudity; or 
(2)  Live performances which are characterized by the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or by "specified sexual activities"; or 
(3)  Films, motions pictures, video cassettes, digital video disc, or video reproductions, slides, or other visual representations which depict or describe "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas". 
Adult motel means a hotel, motel, or similar commercial establishment that: 
(1)  Offers a sleeping room for rent for a period of time that is less than ten (10) hours; or 
(2)  Allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to subrent the room for a period of time that is less than ten (10) hours; or 
(3)  Offers a sleeping room with films, motions pictures, video cassettes, digital video disc, or video reproductions, slides, or other visual representations which depict or describe "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas". 
Designated operator means an individual who is in control of the operations of a sexually oriented business, including, but not limited to a manager, assistant manager, floor manager, or shift manager. 
Nude or seminude means the showing of one (1) or more "specified anatomical areas" with less than a full opaque covering or a state of dress which fails to completely and opaquely cover one (1) or more "specified anatomical areas". 
Operate or cause to be operated means to cause to function or to put or keep in operation, regardless of whether that person is an owner, part owner, licensee or manager of the establishment. 
Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, or any type of business entity. 
Residential area means any area zoned E-1, R-1, R-2, R-2A, R-3, R-4, PURZ, MH-1, or MH-2, or the residential areas within a planned unit development (PUD). 
Sexually oriented business means any commercial establishment or enterprise which as one (1) of its principal business purposes offers a product or service that is intended to provide sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to a customer, and that is distinguished by or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" or where the employer, employees, or customers in the presence of another adult, may be nude, partially nude, or have "specified anatomical areas" not covered. This term shall include, but not be limited to, adult video arcades, adult bookstores, adult video stores, adult cabarets, adult movie theaters, sex parlors, massage parlors, nude modeling studios, love parlors, adult tanning salons, topless or nude bars, or topless carwashes. 
Specified anatomical areas means one (1) or more of the following: Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region or pubic hair, buttock, female breast or breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola, or any combination of the foregoing; or human male genitals in a discernibly erect state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means the depiction or display of, in person or by picture of, one (1) or more of the following: human genitals in a discernible state of sexual stimulation or arousal; acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region or pubic hair, buttock or female breast or breasts; or any combination of the foregoing. 
(Ord. No. 11-1974, § 1, 10-17-2011)  
Sec. 18-102. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  Based on the studies of secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses conducted in Los Angeles, California; Palm Beach County Florida; Daytona Beach, Florida; Toledo Ohio; Austin, Texas; Amarillo, Texas; and by the Texas City Attorneys Association; and based on the paper "Rural Hot Spots: The Case of Adult Businesses" by Richard McLeary; and based on findings from the Report of the Attorney General's Working Group On The Regulation Of Sexually Oriented Businesses (June 6, 1989, State of Minnesota); and based upon the public hearing that council held on August 2, 2010, the council finds that: 
(1)  The Legislature of the State of Texas has determined that unrestricted operation of sexually oriented businesses may be detrimental to the public health, safety, and welfare of a community by contributing to the decline of neighborhoods and contributing to the growth of criminal activity; and 
(2)  There is convincing documented evidence that sexually oriented businesses, because of their very nature, have a deleterious effect on both the existing businesses around them and the surrounding residential areas adjacent to them, causing increased crime, such as the possession or use of controlled substances, the proliferation of drug-related activity, prostitution, disorderly conduct, vandalism, robberies, and assaults; and 
(3)  Regulating the appearance of the premises of sexually oriented businesses and regulating the signage of such businesses preserves the value of neighboring properties and protects minors from exposure to sexual materials; and 
(4)  Licensing sexually oriented businesses is a legitimate and reasonable means of regulation to ensure that operators of sexually oriented businesses do not knowingly allow their establishments to be used as places of illegal activities; and 
(5)  Charging a fee for a sexually oriented business license is necessary to offset costs of inspections, investigations, and enforcement; and 
(6)  Sexually oriented businesses, due to their nature, have serious objectionable operational characteristics, particularly when they are located in close proximity to each other, thereby contributing to urban blight and downgrading the quality of life in the adjacent area. 
(b)  Further, the council hereby states that the purpose of this article is to regulate sexually oriented businesses in order to control their negative secondary effects in the community. The purpose is not to deny access to or deny expression of materials protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or the Article I, section 8 of the Texas Constitution; and 
(c)  Further, the Texas legislature, by enacting V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Chapter 243, allow cities to regulate sexually oriented businesses. 
(Ord. No. 11-1974, § 1, 10-17-2011)  
Sec. 18-103. - Location. 
(a)  A sexually oriented business shall be located at least one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet from the property line of any residential area, and one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet from the property line of any church, public or private school, park, licensed day care, or from another sexually oriented business. Further, because the commercial establishments along Highway 288 and Highway 332 attract or are oriented towards families with young children, and in as much as the city is dependent on the continuation of this family oriented atmosphere for its economy and continuing health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, no sexually oriented business may be located within one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet of commercial establishments on Highway 332 between Highway 288 and FM 2004 and on Highway 288 between Highway 332 and This Way. 
(b)  Measurements shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening objects or structures, from the nearest portion of the building or structure used or to be used as a sexually oriented business to the nearest property line of the residential area, church, public or private school, park, licensed day care or commercial establishments on Highway 332 between Highway 288 and FM 2004 and on Highway 288 between Highway 332 and This Way. 
(c)  A sexually oriented business may only be located in a free-standing building. A sexually oriented business may not be located in an indoor or outdoor shopping center, shopping plaza, strip mall, or similar type of building. 
(Ord. No. 11-1974, § 1, 10-17-2011)  
Sec. 18-104. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 18-105. - License. 
(a)  It is unlawful for a person to operate, or cause to be operated, a sexually oriented business without a valid sexually oriented business license. 
(b)  The application fee for a new or a renewed sexually oriented business license is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). This fee is nonrefundable. 
(c)  The sexually oriented business license shall be displayed at all times in an open and conspicuous place on the premises of the sexually oriented business for which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 11-1974, § 1, 10-17-2011)  
Sec. 18-106. - Application for license. 
(a)  Not later than sixty (60) days before filing an application for a sexually oriented business license, the applicant must comply with the notice by sign requirement contained in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.0075. Not later than five (5) days after the date of the sign's posting, the applicant must notify the chief of police, by either certified mail or hand delivery, of the posting. The notification must be in the form of a sworn statement indicating the location of the sign and the date it was posted. 
(b)  An application for a license must be made on a form provided by the chief of police. The application must be accompanied by a sketch or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of total floor space occupied by the business. The sketch or diagram need not be professionally prepared but must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with marked dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six (6) inches. See section 18-129 for additional diagram requirements for sexually oriented businesses that show adult films or videos. 
(c)  Only a person who is an officer of or who has an ownership interest in a sexually oriented business may apply for a license for the business. Each applicant must be qualified according to the provisions of this article. 
(d)  If an applicant who wishes to operate a sexually oriented business is an individual, he must sign the application for a license as the applicant. If an applicant is other than an individual, each individual who is an officer of the business or who has a twenty (20) percent or greater ownership interest in the business must sign the application for a license as an applicant. The application must be sworn to be true and correct by each applicant. Each applicant must be qualified under this article, and each applicant shall be considered a licensee if a license is granted. 
(e)  The application must identify those persons required to sign the application under subsection (c) and the application must identify all parent and related corporations or entities of any person who will own or operate the sexually oriented business and include the names of the officers of each parent or related corporation or entity. 
(f)  The application must include the name, address, and telephone number of one (1) or more designated operators who will be present on the premises of the sexually oriented business during any hours of operation. The licensee shall maintain a current list of designated operators with the chief of police. Before a person may serve as a designated operator of the sexually oriented business, the person must be named in the license application, or a supplement or amendment to the license application, and not be disqualified to operate a sexually oriented business under this article. 
(g)  The application must include a current official Texas criminal history report with a fingerprint card (issued within the preceding twelve (12) months) for the applicant, the applicant's spouse, and each licensee and designated operator showing that they are not disqualified to operate a sexually oriented business under this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-1974, § 1, 10-17-2011)  
Sec. 18-107. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  The chief of police shall approve the issuance of a license to an applicant within sixty (60) days after receipt of an application unless the chief of police finds one (1) or more of the following to be true: 
(1)  An applicant is under the age of 18. 
(2)  An applicant or an applicant's spouse is overdue in payment to the city for taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against or imposed upon the applicant or the applicant's spouse in relation to a sexually oriented business. 
(3)  An applicant has failed to provide information required under this article or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form. 
(4)  An applicant, an applicant's spouse, a licensee, or a designated operator has been convicted of a violation of a provision of this article within two (2) years immediately preceding the application. 
(5)  Any fee required by this article has not been paid.
