Public swimming pools 	125.00 
 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-49. - Two or more non-mobile establishments. 
If a person or entity owns or operates two (2) or more establishments, the person shall complete separate applications and pay separate fees for each establishment. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-50. - Posting of license. 
Permanent food service establishments must post the license in a place that is seen from the front door. Temporary and mobile food service establishments must post the license within immediate view of customers. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-51. - Transferability of license. 
A license is valid only for the location specified on the license and it may not be transferred from place to place or from establishment to establishment. Mobile food service establishments may retain the same license when moving from place to place as long as the vehicle remains the same. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-52. - Renewals. 
Each food service establishment shall apply to renew its license and pay its renewal fees no later than March 31 of each year. A ten (10) percent late fee will be assessed during the period within one (1) to thirty (30) days following the renewal date. A fifty dollar ($50.00) late fee will be assessed if the application and/or payment are thirty one (31) to sixty (60) days late. Any establishment that is more than sixty (60) days late with the application for payment, shall meet all building and application requirements for new food service establishments. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-53. - Denial of issuance. 
If the application for a license does not conform to the requirements of this article or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the regulatory authority shall return the application and documents to the applicant and give a written reason for the license denial. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Secs. 50-54, 50-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION 
 
Sec. 50-56. - Suspension. 
(a)  Whenever a food service establishment is required under the provisions of this article to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until such time as the regulatory authority determines that conditions responsible for the requirement to cease operations no longer exist. 
(b)  The city may, without warning, notice or hearing, suspend any license to operate a food service establishment if the holder of the license does not comply with the requirements of this article, if the operation of the food service establishment constitutes a substantial hazard to public health, or if the person in charge refuses to allow the regulatory authority to inspect the establishment. 
(c)  Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by section 50-59. The holder of the license may request a hearing within ten (10) days of notice of suspension. The city shall hold the hearing within twenty (20) days of the request. If no written request for a hearing is filed within the ten (10) days, the suspension is sustained. 
(d)  The regulatory authority may end the suspension at any time if the reasons for suspension no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-57. - Revocation. 
The regulatory authority may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, revoke a license for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this article or for interference with the regulatory authority in the performance of its duties. Prior to revocation, the city shall notify the holder of the license, or the person in charge, in writing, of the reason for which the license is subject to revocation and that the license shall be revoked at the end of such ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written request for a hearing is filed with the city within the ten-day period. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the revocation of the license becomes final. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-58. - Reapplication after revocation. 
The holder of a revoked license may apply for a new license. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-59. - Service of notices. 
A notice provided for in this article is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the license or the person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of the license. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Sec. 50-60. - Hearings. 
The hearings provided for in this article shall be conducted by a committee appointed by the city manager at a time and place designated by the committee. Based upon the recorded evidence of such hearing, the city shall make a final finding, and shall sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the license. 
(Ord. No. 16-2091, § 1, 2-16-2016)  
Secs. 50-61—50-79. - Reserved.  
Chapter 51 - PUBLIC SWIMMING POOLS AND SPAS  
ARTICLE I. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 51-1. - Adopted. 
The Texas Administrative Code, Title 25 Health Services, Part I Texas Department of Health, Chapter 265 General Sanitation, Subchapter K Standards for Public Pools and Spas is hereby adopted, and shall be attached to, and made a part of, this Code for all purposes. A copy of the standards shall be available in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-2. - Scope and purpose of these rules. 
The rules outlined in this chapter address minimum standards for design and construction of pools and spas. These rules also establish minimum operating standards for pools and spas to assure proper filtration, chemical, and general maintenance of water and safety to users. These standards are based in part on the American National Standards Institute and the National Spa and Pool Institute "Standards for Public Swimming Pools" (ANSI/NSPI-1, 1991) and the American National Standards Institute and National Spa and Pool Institute "Standards for Public Spas" (ANSI/NSPI-2, 1992). These rules are in addition to any municipal or federal laws applicable to pools and spas. These rules implement V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code, Title 5, Subtit. A, § 341.064(g) and are considered good public health engineering and safety practices. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-3. - Definitions. 
Definitions shall be as defined in the Texas Administrative Code 265.182, Texas Department of Health Standards for Public Swimming Pool and Spa. Any terms not defined herein, the definition shall be determined by the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, unless another agency or unit of government is specified. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-4. - Construction, remodeling or conversion of public pool or spa. 
(a)  Submission of plans. Whenever a public pool or spa is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a public pool or spa, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or conversion shall be submitted to the city for review and approval before construction, remodeling or conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical plans and construction materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The city shall approve the plans and specifications if they meet the requirements of this article. No public pool or spa shall be constructed, extensively remodeled or converted except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city. 
(b)  Preoperational inspection. Whenever plans and specifications are required by subsection (a) above to be submitted to the city, the city shall inspect the public pool or spa prior to its beginning operation to determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the requirements of this article and other pertinent laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-5. - Inspections of public pools and spas. 
(a)  Inspection frequency. An inspection of a public swimming pool or spa shall be performed at least two (2) times per year. Additional inspections of the pool or spa shall be performed as often as necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
(b)  Access to public pools or spas. Agents of the city, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any public pool or spa at any reasonable time, for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this article. This shall include any areas used for the storage of equipment or supplies used in the operation or maintenance of the pool or spa. The agent shall be permitted to examine the records of the public pool or spa to obtain information pertaining to supplies purchased, received or used, maintenance required or performed, or persons employed. 
(c)  Report of inspection. Whenever an inspection of a public swimming pool or spa is made the findings shall be recorded on the inspection report on file with the city. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this article. Inspection remarks shall refer to the violation of this article and shall state the correction to be made. A copy of the inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the public pool or spa at the conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public document that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. 
(d)  Correction of violations. 
(1)  The inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the violations found, and corrections of the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance with the following provisions: 
a.  If an imminent health hazard exists, the public pool or spa shall immediately cease operation. Operations shall not be resumed until authorized by the regulatory authority. 
b.  All other violations shall be given a period of time for correction of not less than twenty-four (24) hours nor greater than ninety (90) days. The regulatory authority to confirm correction shall conduct a follow-up inspection. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-6. - Certified operator required. 
Every public pool or spa must have at least one (1) person who has a valid and current registered pool operator certification, available at all times as may be reasonably necessary to maintain and operate the pool or spa in accordance with this article. Such operator shall be in full charge of the operation, maintenance and sanitation and shall have authority to enforce all rules of safety in the absence of a lifeguard. 
(1)  Valid license. No person shall operate a public swimming pool or spa who does not have a valid license, issued to him or her by the regulatory authority. 
(2)  Application. Any person desiring a public pool operator's license shall make written application on forms provided by the regulatory authority. All applications for a public pool operator's license shall be accompanied by the appropriate fee as set forth in section 51-24 of this article. 
(3)  Training course required. All persons desiring a public pool operator's license shall provide proof of completion of a course of training in pool management, operations and maintenance as approved by the regulatory authority, within the previous three (3) years. 
(4)  Issuance of license. The city shall issue a public pool operator's license to any person who satisfactorily completes the requirements set forth in this article. 
(5)  Renewal of license. The registered pool operator certification license expires one (1) year from the date of issuance. It shall be the responsibility of the operator to renew his license prior to the expiration date. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-7. - Licensed operator variance. 
Pools operated by off premise management companies may utilize pool maintenance companies whose field employees are certified registered pool operators, by requesting in writing and being granted a variance by the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-8. - Penalties for article violations. 
All persons, companies, corporations or other entities that are not in compliance with this article shall be subject to the penalties provided herein, in addition to any state or federal penalties that are applicable. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Secs. 51-9—51-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS, LICENSES AND CERTIFICATES 
 
Sec. 51-21. - Required; general conditions. 
No person, company or corporation shall operate a public pool or spa who does not have a separate valid permit license or certificate issued to him or her by the city for each and every pool or spa. Only a person, company or corporation who complies with the requirements of this section shall be entitled to receive or retain such a permit, license or certificate. Permits, licenses or certificates are not transferable. A valid permit, license or certificate shall be posted in each and every public pool or spa. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-22. - Application. 
(a)  Contents. Any person, company or corporation desiring to operate a public pool or spa shall make written application for a permit, license or certificate on forms provided by the city. Such application shall include the name and address of each applicant, the location and the type of proposed public pool or spa, the signature of each applicant and any other information as deemed necessary by the regulatory authority. 
(b)  Pool operator certification. A photocopy of the pool operator's certification must be submitted with the permit application or renewal. Operator's certification must be verified through department records. 
(c)  Inspection of pool or spa. Prior to the approval of an application for a permit, license or certificate, the city shall inspect the proposed pool or spa to determine compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-23. - Issuance. 
The city shall issue a permit, license or certificate to the applicant if the inspection reveals that the proposed public pool or spa complies with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-24. - Fees. 
(a)  The following fee schedule shall be applicable to permits, licenses and certificates issued under this article. 
Description 	Fee 
Public swimming pool 	$125.00 
Public spa 	$125.00 
 
(b)  No fee shall be charged to any swimming pool or spa operated by a governmental agency, independent school district, church or an institute of purely public charity (i.e., Red Cross, Salvation Army). However, such establishments shall comply with all other requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 19-2179, § 1, 5-6-2019)  
Sec. 51-25. - Two or more pools and/or spas. 
If a person, company or corporation owns or operates two (2) or more public pools and/or spas, each pool and/or spa shall be permitted separately by listing the name and address of each pool and/or spa on separate application forms. Separate permits are required for each and every pool and/or spa even if they are located upon the same property. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-26. - Posting of permit. 
The permit shall be posted conspicuously at the property on which the public pool or spa is located. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-27. - Transferability of permit. 
A permit is not transferable upon change of ownership of the pool or spa. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-28. - Renewals. 
Each public pool and/or spa issued a permit, license or certificate shall renew said permit, license or certificate annually, no later than May 31 of that calendar year. A renewal shall be issued provided the public pool or spa has paid all renewal fees and has maintained compliance with the provisions of this article. A ten (10) percent late fee will be assessed during a grace period within one (1) to thirty (30) days following the renewal date. In case of failure to renew a permit, license or certificate within the grace period of one (1) to thirty (30) days following the renewal date, the holder will be subject to all the requirements of obtaining a new permit, license or certificate. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-29. - Refusal 
of issuance. 
If the application for a permit, license or certificate and the accompanying contract documents describing the work or operations do not conform to the requirements of this article or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the city shall not issue a permit, license or certificate but shall return the application and documents to the applicant with a refusal to issue the permit, license or certificate. Such refusal shall, when requested, be in writing and shall contain the reason for refusal. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-30. - Suspension. 
(a)  The city may without warning, notice or hearing suspend any permit, license or certificate to operate a public pool or spa if the holder of the permit, license or certificate does not comply with the requirements of this article, or if the operation of the pool or spa does not comply with the requirements of this article, or if the operation of the pool or spa does not comply with the requirements of this article, or if the operation of the pool or spa does not comply with the requirements of this article, or if the operation of the pool or spa constitutes a substantial hazard to public health. Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by section 51-33. When a permit, license or certificate is suspended, the pool or spa shall be secured to prevent access by the public and a notice of the closure placed in a conspicuous location. Whenever a permit, license or certificate is suspended, the holder of the permit, license or certificate shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing before the city manager within twenty (20) days of a receipt for a hearing. 
(b)  Whenever a permit, license or certificate is suspended, the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, shall be notified in writing that the permit, license or certificate is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the city by the holder of the permit, license or certificate within ten (10) days. If no written request for a hearing is filed within the ten (10) days, the suspension is sustained. The city may end the suspension at any time if the reasons for the suspension no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-31. - Revocation. 
The city may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, revoke a permit, license or certificate for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this article or for interference with the city in the performance of its duties. Prior to revocation, the city shall notify the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, in writing, of the reason for which the permit, license or certificate is subject to revocation and that the permit, license or certificate shall be revoked at the end of the ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written request for a hearing is filed with the city by the holder of the permit, license or certificate within such ten-day period. If no request for a hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the revocation of the permit, license or certificate becomes final. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-32. - Reapplication after revocation. 
Whenever a revocation of a permit, license or certificate has become final, the holder of the revoked permit, license or certificate may make written application for a new permit, license or certificate. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-33. - Service of notices. 
A notice provided for in this article is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of the permit, license or certificate. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-34. - Hearings. 
A committee appointed by the city manager at a time and place designated by the committee shall conduct the hearings provided for in this article. Based upon the recorded evidence of such hearing, the city shall make a final finding and shall sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit, license or certificate by the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Secs. 51-35—51-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - POOL YARD ENCLOSURES 
 
Sec. 51-46. - Adopted. 
The V.T.C.A., Texas Health and Safety Code, Ch. 757, Pool Yard Enclosures is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Secs. 51-47—51-66. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SINGLE-FAMILY DWELLING 
 
Sec. 51-67. - International Building Code for Swimming Pools adopted. 
The International Building Code for Swimming Pools are hereby adopted as the single family swimming pool code of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, for regulating the design, construction, management and operation of a swimming pool or spa of a single-family dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-68. - Definitions. 
Definitions shall be as defined in the International Building Code for Swimming Pools. For any terms not defined herein, the definition shall be as determined by the City of Lake Jackson, Texas, unless another agency or unit of government is specified. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-69. - Building permit required. 
Whenever a swimming pool or spa for a single-family dwelling is constructed or extensively remodeled, a building permit must be obtained from the city prior to any construction or remodeling taking place. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 51-70. - Maintained in a safe and sanitary manner. 
All single-family dwelling swimming pools and/or spas must be maintained in such a manner as to not create a health or safety hazard. 
(Ord. No. 02-1694, § 1, 6-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Chapter 54 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Department of police, § 4.02. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 22; courts, ch. 26; emergency services, ch. 34; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98; authority of police to direct traffic, § 98-3. 
State Law reference— Municipal civil service, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143; police force of home rule municipality, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.003; law enforcement services provided through cooperation of local governments, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 362.001 et seq.; commission on law enforcement officer standards and education, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 415.001 et seq.; "police officer" defined, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 11; procedure upon arrest for traffic violation, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 147 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Appointment, term, powers, duties of chief of police. 
The office of chief of police is hereby made an appointive office and the chief of police shall be appointed by the city manager and shall hold his office at the pleasure of the city manager. The chief of police to have all of the powers and duties set forth in Section 4.02 of the Home Rule Charter of the city. 
(Ord. No. 281, § 1, 8-20-62; Code 1958, § 16-6) 
State Law reference— Police department generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.003.  
Sec. 54-2. - Arrests without warrant by city police. 
(a)  Those duly commissioned police officers of the city shall have the authority to arrest without warrant, in order to be detained to answer for their actions: 
(1)  Persons found in suspicious places and under circumstances which reasonably show that such persons have been guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or threaten, or are about to commit some offense against the laws; 
(2)  Persons who the police officer has probable cause to believe have committed an assault resulting in bodily injury to another person and the police officer has probable cause to believe that there is danger of further bodily injury to that person; 
(3)  Persons who the police officer has probable cause to believe have committed the offense defined by V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 25.08 (violation of protective order), if the offense is not committed in the presence of the police officer; or 
(4)  Persons who the police officer has probable cause to believe have committed an assault resulting in bodily injury to a member of the person's family or household. 
(b)  As used in this section, "probable cause" means facts and circumstances, sufficiently strong in themselves, that would warrant a cautious man in his belief that the suspect is actually guilty of the offense, or is about to commit a violation of a state law or city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 66-340, § 1, 9-19-66; Code 1958, § 16-7) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 14.03.  
Secs. 54-3—54-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - POLICE RESERVE FORCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Special police, § 4.02(d). 
State Law reference— Police reserve force, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.012. 
 
Sec. 54-26. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established a police reserve force for the City of Lake Jackson. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 1, 10-18-55; Ord. No. 71-451, § 1, 10-11-71; Code 1958, § 16-1; Ord. No. 16-2090, § 1, 2-1-2016)  
Sec. 54-27. - Membership. 
The police reserve force shall consist of a maximum of twelve (12) members. The members shall be appointed by the chief of police and shall serve under his direction and supervision, or that of his designee. The chief of police shall have the right to remove the reserve police officers from office, and he shall appoint new members to the reserve force as vacancies occur. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 2, 10-18-55; Ord. No. 71-451, § 2, 10-11-71; Ord. No. 83-910, § 1, 12-19-83; Code 1958, § 16-2; Ord. No. 16-2090, § 1, 2-1-2016)  
Sec. 54-28. - Qualifications. 
All persons appointed to the police reserve force must: 
(1)  Be over the age of twenty-one (21); 
(2)  Live within a thirty (30) minute response radius of the City of Lake Jackson Police Department; and 
(3)  Be licensed by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 71-451, § 3, 10-11-71; Code 1958, § 16-2.1; Ord. No. 16-2090, § 1, 2-1-2016) 
State Law reference— Commission on law enforcement officer standards and education, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 415.  
Sec. 54-29. - Uniforms. 
The city shall issue uniforms to each member of the police reserve force. The uniforms shall be returned to the chief of police when the person ceases to be a member of the police reserve force. The uniforms shall be worn at all times when on duty unless otherwise directed by the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 3, 10-18-55; Ord. No. 71-451, § 4, 10-11-71; Code 1958, § 16-3; Ord. No. 16-2090, § 1, 2-1-2016)  
Sec. 54-30. - Powers and duties. 
Police reserve officers shall act only upon the request of the chief of police or his designee. When on duty, the members shall have all powers of a City of Lake Jackson Police Officer, including the power to make arrests. After city council approval of the appointment, a member may carry a weapon when discharging official duties as a peace officer or when authorized by the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 4, 10-18-55; Ord. No. 71-451, § 5, 10-11-71; Code 1958, § 16-4; Ord. No. 16-2090, § 1, 2-1-2016)  
Sec. 54-31. - Remuneration. 
Members of the police reserve force serve without compensation. However, members of the police reserve force who actively participate for at least sixteen (16) hours per month and whose job performance gains the approval of the city manager and the chief of police, shall be recognized for their service in an amount equal to the annual payment of the basic garbage, water and sewer bill for residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 5, 10-18-55; Ord. No. 71-451, § 6, 10-11-71; Ord. No. 73-514, § 1, 11-5-73; Code 1958, § 16-5; Ord. No. 16-2090, § 1, 2-1-2016)  
Chapter 56 - LEASING AND CONTRACTING CITY-OWNED FACILITIES FOR COMMERCIAL ENTERPRISES OR CONVENIENCE 
 
Sec. 56-1. - City leases and contracts. 
With the approval of the city council as reflected in its minutes, the city may enter into leases and contracts by which city facilities are leased for commercial enterprises or for the convenience of public entities. 
(Ord. No. 01-1652, § 1, 3-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 56-2. - Criteria. 
All leases under this chapter shall be made under the following criteria: 
(1)  Control of the government facility shall be maintained by the city. 
(2)  The governmental use of the facility is not interfered with. 
(3)  No governmental powers are bartered away. 
(4)  There is a municipal or public purpose served. 
a.  Money received in exchange satisfies the public purpose requirement. 
(5)  The lease is for at least fair market value. 
(6)  The lease is not exclusive as long as space is available. 
(7)  The lease or contract is in writing. 
(8)  The lease must comply with all applicable city ordinances, including the telecommunications, zoning and building codes (including windstorm provisions). 
(9)  If there are antennas or other appurtenances mounted, there shall be an inspection report prepared by a registered professional engineer certifying the structural integrity of the mounted items. 
(10)  The term of the lease shall be for no more than twenty-five (25) years. 
(11)  The lease termination clause shall provide the city with the right to terminate the lease. 
(12)  There shall be no assignment or subletting without consent/approval by the city. 
(13)  Any improvements must be approved by the city. 
(14)  The lessee shall indemnify the city. 
(15)  There shall be no hazardous substances introduced to a city facility. 
(16)  Insurance shall be carried by lessee in amounts required by the city. 
(17)  Lessee shall maintain the leased facilities in a manner that meets city approval. 
(18)  In monitoring the premises, the lessee shall not in any manner injure or damage the facilities. 
(19)  The city council authorizes by minute order the proper official to enter into the contract. 
(Ord. No. 01-1652, § 1, 3-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 56-3. - Lease facilities to other entities. 
(a)  The city shall be able to lease facilities to other entities for commercial enterprises as permitted under Texas law. 
(b)  Certain facilities such as park land, recreation area, scientific area, wildlife refuge or historic site cannot be leased for a different use or purpose without public notice and a public hearing under Chapter 26 of the Parks and Wildlife Code. 
(c)  Lease of a municipal hospital or swimming pool is subject to Section 253.006 of the Local Government Code and must. 
(1)  Be authorized by ordinance or resolution adopted by the governing body; 
(2)  Be executed on behalf of the municipality by the mayor and the municipal secretary or clerk; 
(3)  Be impressed with the municipal seal; and 
(4)  Cover a period of not more than fifty (50) years. 
(Ord. No. 01-1652, § 1, 3-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 56-4. - Distribution of automated information systems software. 
The city shall be able to sell, lease, market or engage in other distribution of computer software that it develops. Any release of municipally developed automated information systems software must be under a contract that provides that the municipality will receive a royalty, license right, or other appropriate compensation for developing the software as specified under V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 253.007. In this section "automated information systems software" means any procedure or software that is designed, operated, or maintained to collect, record, process, store, retrieve, display or transmit information. 
(Ord. No. 01-1652, § 1, 3-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 56-5. - City able to purchase, acquire or lease property with the county. 
(a)  The city shall be able to purchase, acquire or lease property within the county as necessary, upon the approval of the city council, for any purpose listed in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 273.001 et seq. and for any other purpose not prohibited by law. 
(b)  The city may maintain, improve, sell and lease the property, and the improvements on the property. 
(c)  When necessity requires, the city, upon approval of the city council, may purchase, acquire, lease or use property as necessary to engage in proprietary or commercial enterprises as long as a governmental or public purpose is served and the use is not prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 01-1652, § 1, 3-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Sec. 56-6. - Violation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm, company, corporation, nonprofit organization or any other entity to use a city facility for commercial purposes without obtaining the permission of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01-1652, § 1, 3-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Chapter 58 - TEMPORARY HOUSING AND MANUFACTURED HOMES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 18; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 50; signs, ch. 78; solid waste, condition and use of premises, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 90; taxation, ch. 94; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98; utilities, ch. 102; zoning, ch. 110.

ARTICLE I. - TEMPORARY HOUSING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, adopted June 4, 2018, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former Art. I, §§ 58-1—58-6, pertained to temporary post-disaster housing, and derived from Ord. No. 17-2147, § 1, adopted Oct. 2, 2017. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 58-1. - Purpose 
The purpose of this article is to allow people to live close to their homes during times of repair due to emergencies such as hurricanes or fires. This article shall be used only when no other housing options are available. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency means an event that renders a house uninhabitable, such as a fire. 
State of disaster means a situation that causes the mayor or mayor pro tem to make an official declaration that activates the city's emergency management plans and authorizes the furnishing of aid and assistance. 
Temporary housing means a prefabricated structure mounted on a permanent chassis, including, but not limited to, manufactured homes, recreational vehicles and travel trailers. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-3. - Liability. 
The city and its officers, agents, and employees shall have no liability of any nature for any personal injury or injury to property on the site of the temporary housing. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Secs. 58-4, 58-5. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MULTI-FAMILY ZONES 
 
Sec. 58-6. - Location. 
For multi-family zones, temporary housing may only be placed on sites that have adequate water, sewer, and power for the number of people to be housed. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-7. - Request. 
(a)  The owner of the site must file a written request with the city manager for the installation of temporary housing. The request must contain the following: 
(1)  A site plan; 
(2)  Pictures of the site and the proposed housing; 
(3)  An explanation of why the temporary housing is needed; 
(4)  The length of time the temporary housing will be on the site; and 
(5)  An explanation of how the owner will take care of water, sewage, power, solid waste and security needs. 
(b)  If the request is complete, the city manager shall submit the request to the city council at the next regular meeting. The city manager or his designee may inspect the plans and the site before city council discusses the request. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-8. - Criteria for approval. 
(a)  City council may grant the request if the housing is needed due to recovery and relief efforts related to events during a state of disaster. 
(b)  If city council grants the request, the owner of the site must ensure that the following standards are met: 
(1)  The temporary housing is not rundown, dilapidated, or unsafe; 
(2)  The chassis for each unit of temporary housing is safe for travel; 
(3)  All solid waste is stored and disposed of in a manner that will not create a health or fire hazard; 
(4)  An adequate and safe sewer system is provided for storage and disposal of all sewage; and 
(5)  At least one (1) ADA compliant unit of temporary housing is available for every five (5) units installed. 
(c)  City council may impose other reasonable standards, such as a limited time period for the housing to be on the site. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-9. - Removal. 
After the initial time period has ended or upon an order by city council, the temporary housing shall be removed from the site. The site shall be cleaned and all solid waste removed. City council may order that the temporary housing be removed if any of the standards set forth in this article are not met. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-10. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SINGLE-FAMILY ZONES 
 
Sec. 58-11. - Location. 
In single-family zones, temporary housing may only be placed in the driveway or in the backyard of a lot that has an uninhabitable home that is undergoing repairs. The site must have adequate water, sewer, and power for the number of people to be housed. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-12. - Request. 
(a)  The owner of the property must file a written request with the city manager for the installation of temporary housing. The request must contain the following: 
(1)  Pictures of the property and the proposed housing; 
(2)  A site survey showing setbacks, easements, and planned location of the temporary housing; 
(3)  An explanation of why the temporary housing is needed; 
(4)  The length of time the temporary housing will be needed; 
(5)  A schedule of the repairs needed to make the home habitable; 
(6)  The reason that the owner or tenant cannot stay elsewhere; 
(7)  An explanation of how the owner will take care of water, sewage, power, solid waste and security needs; 
(8)  A letter of approval from the property owners or lessees that are next to and across the street from the uninhabitable home; and 
(9)  Other information that the city manager needs to evaluate the request. 
(b)  If the request is complete, the city manager shall grant or deny the request. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-13. - Criteria for approval; standards. 
(a)  The city manager may grant the request if: 
(1)  The housing is needed due to recovery and relief efforts related to events during a state of disaster or for an emergency that renders the home uninhabitable, such as a fire; and 
(2)  There are no other housing options available. 
(b)  If the city manager grants the request, the owner of the site must ensure that the following standards are met: 
(1)  The temporary housing is not rundown, dilapidated, or unsafe; 
(2)  The chassis for the temporary housing is safe for travel; 
(3)  All solid waste is stored and disposed of in a manner that will not create a health or fire hazard; and 
(4)  An adequate and safe sewer system is provided for storage and disposal of all sewage. 
(c)  The city manager may impose other reasonable standards, such as a limited time that the housing may be on the property. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Sec. 58-14. - Removal. 
(a)  After the initial time period has ended, the temporary housing shall be removed from the site. The site shall be cleaned and all solid waste removed. 
(b)  If the owner or tenant needs to remain in the temporary housing past the initial time period, the owner must request an extension of time from city council. 
(c)  The city manager may order that the temporary housing be removed if any of the standards set forth in this article are not met. 
(Ord. No. 18-2159, § 2, 6-4-2018)  
Secs. 58-15—58-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 58-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Internal street means a common access route or private way which affords principal means of access to individual mobile home lots or auxiliary buildings. 
Licensee means an individual, firm, business association or corporation licensed to operate and maintain a mobile home park. 
Mobile home means a moveable or portable dwelling constructed to be towed by a motor vehicle on its own chassis over state roads and highways under special permit, connected to utilities, and designed without a permanent foundation for yearround living. It may consist of one (1) or more units that can be telescoped when towed and expanded later for additional capacity, or of two (2) or more units separately towable but designed to be joined into one (1) integral unit. 
Mobile home park means a unified development of mobile home spaces arranged on a tract of land under individual, firm, business association or corporate ownership, meeting all requirements for the construction and development of a mobile home park. 
Mobile home space means a plot of ground within a mobile home park designed for the accommodation of one (1) mobile home. This term shall also include the terms "lot" and "site." 
Natural barrier means an abutting lake or creek; a drainage area having a minimum width of fifty (50) feet in which no structures are located; an airport enclosed by a fence or wall; a densely wooded area having a minimum width of fifty (50) feet in which no structures are located; and vacant land having a minimum width of one hundred (100) feet. Property shall cease to be considered a natural barrier when the stated conditions change and the property is developed with structures. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 1, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-27. - Penalty. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or who shall build, alter, occupy or use any building or property in violation of any statement or plan submitted and approved hereunder shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in any sum not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day such violation shall be continued or shall be allowed to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The owner of any building or property or part thereof where anything in violation of this article shall be placed or shall exist, and any architect, builder, contractor, agent, attorney or other person employed in connection therewith, and who has assisted in the commission of such violations, but is not primarily responsible therefor, shall be guilty of a separate offense, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in any sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  In addition to the remedies provided for in this section the enforcing officer may, in case any buildings or structures are erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure or land is used in violation of this article, institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use to restrain, correct or abate such violation, to prevent the occupancy of such building, structure, or land, or to prevent any illegal act, conduct of business or use in or about such premises. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 7, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-7)  
Sec. 58-28. - Permits. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued for the construction or occupancy of a permanent residential structure in any mobile home park, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  One (1) existing residential structure may be retained or one (1) new residential structure may be constructed for the occupancy of the owner or operator of the park. 
(2)  An existing residence may be converted into a clubhouse, community center or service building of a mobile home park. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to construct, alter or extend any mobile home park within the limits of the city without a valid permit therefor issued by the building inspector for the specific construction, alteration or extension proposed. 
(c)  The application for and issuance of a permit shall be governed by section 110-9. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 2, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-2)  
Sec. 58-29. - Mobile home park license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a mobile home park within the city without a valid license therefor issued annually by the building official for the specific park. All applications for licenses shall be made in writing on forms furnished by the building official, who shall issue a license upon compliance by the applicant with provisions of this article. The building official shall not issue a license unless the applicant is a valid holder of a certificate of occupancy. When a certificate of occupancy is revoked, the license is automatically void. 
(b)  Application for the original license shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, and accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the application and by the deposit of the required license fee, and shall contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the park. 
(3)  A site or plot plan of the park showing applicable locations, dimensions and specifications for all mobile home spaces, streets, walkways, service buildings and facilities, utility easements and systems, and drains and drainage structures. 
(4)  Before the original license or renewal license is issued, the city building official shall obtain the approval of the fire chief on the firefighting appliances, water supply, accessways, or other applicable conditions as meeting fire safety requirements. 
(c)  Application for renewal of license shall be made in writing by the licensee on forms furnished by the building inspector, on or before December 20 of each year. Such application shall contain any change in the information occurring after the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted. 
(d)  All original license applications or renewals thereof shall be accompanied by a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus one dollar ($1.00) for each mobile home space in a mobile home park. The original fee shall be prorated on the nearest quarterly basis between the date of the original license and January 1 of that calendar year. Renewal fees shall be due on January 1 of each year. 
(e)  An additional license fee of three dollars ($3.00) per month for each mobile home in a mobile home park shall be paid quarterly in advance within ten (10) days after the first day of January, April, July and October of each year and shall be based on the number of mobile homes in a park on the first day of each quarterly period. 
(f)  Every mobile home park licensee shall give notice in writing to the building official within seventy-two (72) hours after having sold, transferred, given away or otherwise disposed of his interest in or control of a mobile home park. Upon application by the new prospective licensee, in writing, to the building official, for transfer of the license, the building official shall determine that the park is in compliance with all applicable provisions of this article before transferring the license. Such application for transfer of license shall be made within seven (7) calendar days after notification of the change covered in sentence one of this subsection. Within fifteen (15) days after receipt of such application, the city shall notify the applicant of the decision on his application for license transfer. 
(g)  All applications for license transfers shall be accompanied by a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(h)  Whenever, upon inspection of any mobile home park, the building official, after consultation with the city official he deems competent to judge, finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this article, he shall give notice in writing to the licensee that unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in such notice, the license shall be suspended. At the end of such period of time, the building official shall reinspect such park, requesting assistance from other city departments as may be required, and if such conditions or practices have not been corrected, he shall suspend the license and give notice in writing of such suspension to the licensee. Upon receipt of notice of such suspension, the licensee shall cease operation of such park. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 4, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-4)  
Sec. 58-30. - Inspection of mobile home parks. 
(a)  Not less than once every three (3) months, the building official, health officer, fire chief, police chief and collector of taxes shall inspect every mobile home park within the city to determine compliance with this article and to assure that such park shall not become a menace to public health, morals, safety or welfare. 
(b)  The building official and other city officials shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this article. 
(c)  The building official and the collector of taxes shall have the power and authority in discharging their official duties to inspect the register containing a record of all residents of the mobile home park. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of every occupant of a mobile home park to give the licensee, his agent, or authorized employee access to any part of such park at reasonable times for the purpose of making such repair or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 5, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-5)  
Sec. 58-31. - Notices, hearings and orders. 
(a)  Whenever it is determined that there are grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this article, the building official shall give notice of such alleged violation to the licensee or his agent. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance; 
(3)  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of the act it requires; 
(4)  Be served upon the licensee or his agent; provided that such notice or order shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such licensee or agent when a copy thereof has been sent by mail to his last known address, or when he has been served with such notice by any method authorized or required by the laws of this state; and 
(5)  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this article, by the building official may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city council provided that such person shall file within ten (10) days after the day the notice was served in the office of the city manager, a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds therefor. The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of the notice and of the suspension. Upon receipt of such petition, the city manager shall forward such petition to the city secretary who shall request the city council to set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At such hearing the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show why such notice should be modified or withdrawn. 
(c)  After such hearing, the building official shall issue an order in writing sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the notice. Upon failure to comply with an order by the building official sustaining or modifying a notice, the occupancy permit and the license of the park affected by the order shall be revoked. 
(d)  Whenever the building official finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health and safety, he may without notice or hearing issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that action be taken as he may deem necessary to meet the emergency. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon written petition to the city manager shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. The provisions of this subsection shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 6, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-6)  
Secs. 58-32—58-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MH-1, MOBILE HOME PARK ZONE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— MH-1, mobile home park zoning district, § 110-83. 
 
Sec. 58-41. - Established, compliance. 
There is hereby created a new residential zone to be known as MH-1, mobile home park. In a zone so designated and approved according to the provisions of this division, within the city, or within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city for subdivision purposes, a mobile home park may be developed, redeveloped, altered or expanded, provided it meets with the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3)  
Sec. 58-42. - Location. 
A mobile home park shall be located only in areas having a zoning classification of MH-1, mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(A))  
Sec. 58-43. - Area requirements. 
(a)  The minimum area which may be developed or used for mobile home park purposes shall be ten (10) acres. 
(b)  Within a mobile home park, mobile home spaces shall be established to comply at any stage of park development with the following requirements: 
(1)  At least ten (10) percent of the total number of mobile home spaces shall have minimum front width of fifty (50) feet and provide a minimum area of five thousand (5,000) square feet, inclusive of public utility easements. 
(2)  At least forty (40) percent of the total number of mobile home spaces shall have a minimum front width of forty-five (45) feet and provide a minimum area of four thousand (4,000) square feet, inclusive of public utility easements. 
(3)  All other mobile home spaces shall have a minimum front width of forty (40) feet and provide a minimum area of three thousand six hundred (3,600) square feet, inclusive of public utility easements. 
(c)  There shall be constructed and maintained a permanent screening device not less than six (6) feet in height, on all sides of a mobile home park, except where natural barriers exist to form all or part of such screen. A screening device may consist of a solid masonry or wooden wall or fence, a woven wire or chain-link fence with metal strips woven through the mesh to form a solid screen, a woven wire or chain-link fence with evergreen shrubs forming a sight screen, or a solid evergreen hedge forming a sight screen. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(B))  
Sec. 58-44. - Open space requirements. 
(a)  The minimum front yard setback shall be ten (10) feet from the nearest corner of the mobile home to the front line of the mobile home space. 
(b)  No mobile home shall be closer than ten (10) feet to the property line of a mobile home park, nor closer than twenty-five (25) feet to the property line of a mobile home park adjoining a public street. 
(c)  For other structures on each space the minimum front yard setback shall be at least ten (10) feet. 
(d)  The minimum distance between mobile homes shall be twenty (20) feet on the side and twenty (20) feet at the rear. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(C))  
Sec. 58-45. - Height regulations. 
(a)  The height limit for any structure in the mobile home park shall be thirty-five (35) feet. 
(b)  The average height of the mobile home frame above the ground elevation measured at ninety (90) degrees to the frame shall not exceed three (3) feet. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(D))  
Sec. 58-46. - Soil and ground cover. 
Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every mobile home park shall be paved, covered with stone, screening or other solid material, or protected with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating dust. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(E))  
Sec. 58-47. - Design and location of storage facilities. 
Unless provided in current mobile home models, storage facilities with a minimum capacity of one hundred fifty (150) cubic feet per mobile home space shall be provided on the space, or in compounds located within one hundred (100) feet of each space. Storage facilities shall be designed in a manner that will enhance the appearance of the park, shall be faced with masonry, baked enamel steel or other material equal in fire resistance, durability and appearance, and shall be securely affixed to the ground. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(F))  
Sec. 58-48. - Mobile home stands. 
(a)  The area of the mobile home space upon which the mobile home is located shall be improved to provide adequate support for the mobile home by either of the following methods: 
(1)  Two (2) reinforced concrete runners on which to place a mobile home may be constructed having a minimum width of eighteen (18) inches and having a minimum length of fifty (50) feet. Each runner shall be at least four (4) inches thick. 
(2)  Precast reinforced concrete blocks having minimum dimensions of two (2) feet square by four (4) inches thick may be utilized as blocking pads for a mobile home. Blocking pads shall be placed for support on each side of a mobile home and spaced at minimum intervals of ten (10) feet. 
(b)  Tiedowns shall be provided with each mobile home stand. Each tiedown shall be embedded to a depth of four (4) feet and shall be of auger type. Such tiedowns shall be spaced at a minimum of ten-foot intervals on each side of the home and shall have at least two thousand five hundred (2,500) pounds test capacity each. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(G))  
Sec. 58-49. - Streets, parking and traffic circulation. 
(a)  Internal streets shall be privately owned, built and maintained, and shall be designed for safe and convenient access to all spaces and to facilities for common use of park residents. 
(b)  An internal street shall have a minimum width of twenty-seven (27) feet. On-street parking shall be permitted only on one side of an internal street. Internal streets shall be continuous and connect with other streets within the park or with public streets, or shall be provided with a cul-de-sac having a minimum diameter of ninety-five (95) feet. No internal street ending in a cul-de-sac shall exceed five hundred (500) feet in length. 
(c)  Internal streets shall permit unobstructed access to within at least two hundred (200) feet of any portion of each mobile home. 
(d)  Internal streets shall be constructed of concrete to standard specifications established by the city and shall be maintained free of cracks, holes and other hazards. All such streets shall be provided with concrete curb and gutter. 
(e)  Off-street parking shall be provided on each mobile home space in the ratio of two (2) parking spaces for each mobile home space. A parking space shall be a minimum of nine (9) feet in width by eighteen (18) feet in length located within the boundary of the mobile home space. Each parking space shall be paved with concrete and located to eliminate interference with access to parking areas provided for other mobile homes or for public parking within the park. 
(f)  Either a centralized parking area, or decentralized parking areas, shall be provided within a mobile home park for parking and storing trailers, visitor's vehicles and vehicles in excess of two (2) per mobile home space. Such parking area shall be hard-surfaced and shall contain a total minimum area of thirty (30) square feet per mobile home space. 
(g)  Within each mobile home park, all streets shall be named and mobile homes numbered to conform with block numbers on adjacent public streets. All street name signs shall be privately owned and maintained, shall be of reflective material, and shall be of standard size and placement to facilitate location by emergency vehicles. 
(h)  Interior streets shall intersect adjoining public streets at ninety (90) degrees and at locations which eliminate or minimize interference with traffic on those public streets. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(H))  
Sec. 58-50. - Street lighting. 
Street lighting within the mobile home park shall be provided along all interior streets and shall conform to or exceed existing ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(I))  
Sec. 58-51. - Public telephone. 
All telephone lines shall be installed underground. The park licensee shall provide a public telephone in a well-lighted area, accessible twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(J))  
Sec. 58-52. - Fire safety standards. 
(a)  No liquefied petroleum gas nor flammable liquid may be stored, handled or dispensed within a mobile home park except as provided by applicable ordinances or regulations of the city or statutes of this state. 
(b)  Approaches to all mobile homes shall be kept clear for firefighting purposes. 
(c)  The mobile home park licensee or agent shall provide an adequate system for the collection of and safe disposal of garbage and rubbish. 
(d)  The mobile home park licensee or agent shall be responsible for maintaining the entire area of the park in a neat and orderly condition, and free of dry brush, weeds and leaves. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(K))  
Sec. 58-53. - Recreation area. 
(a)  All mobile home parks shall have at least one (1) recreation area. 
(b)  Recreation areas and facilities such as playgrounds, swimming pools, and community buildings shall be provided which in the judgment of the park licensee will meet the anticipated needs of the clientele the park is designed to serve. 
(c)  Not less than five (5) percent of the gross site area of the mobile home park shall be devoted to recreational facilities. Recreation area includes space for community buildings and community use facilities such as adult recreation and child play areas, swimming pools, and drying yards, but not including vehicle parking areas. 
(d)  When playground space is provided it shall be so designated and shall be protected from traffic, thoroughfares and parking areas. Such space shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and free of safety hazards. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(L))  
Sec. 58-54. - Water supply and distribution system. 
(a)  An accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water shall be provided in all mobile home parks. Connection shall be made to the public supply of water. 
(b)  The water supply system of the mobile home park shall be connected to all mobile homes, buildings and other facilities requiring water. 
(c)  Except as otherwise specifically provided, all water mains, service lines, connections, fixtures and appurtenances shall conform to and be designed, constructed, installed, tested, inspected and maintained in accordance with applicable ordinances or regulations of the city or statutes of this state. 
(d)  Individual water riser pipes shall be located within the confined area of the outside perimeter walls of the mobile home at a point where the water connection will approximate a vertical position. 
(e)  Water riser pipes shall extend at least four (4) inches above ground elevation. The pipe shall be at least three-quarters (¾) inches. The water outlet shall be capped when no mobile home occupies the lot. 
(f)  Adequate provisions shall be made to prevent freezing of service lines, valves and riser pipes, and to protect risers from heaving and thawing actions of ground during freezing weather. Surface drainage shall be diverted from the location of the riser pipe. 
(g)  A shutoff valve below ground level shall be provided near the water riser pipe on each mobile home space. 
(h)  Underground stop and waste valves shall not be installed on any water service. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(M))  
Sec. 58-55. - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  An adequate and safe sewer system shall be provided in all mobile home parks for conveying and disposing of all sewage. Connection shall be made to the public sewer system. 
(b)  The use of septic tanks within a mobile home park shall not be permitted. 
(c)  Except as otherwise specifically provided, all sewer main lines or laterals, and all individual mobile home sewer lines, connections, fixtures and appurtenances shall conform to and be designed, constructed, installed, tested, inspected and maintained in accordance with applicable ordinances or regulations of the city or statutes of this state. 
(d)  Each mobile home stand shall be provided with at least a four-inch diameter sewer riser pipe. The sewer riser pipe shall be so located on each stand that the sewer connection to the mobile home drain outlet will approximate a vertical position. 
(1)  The sewer connection from the mobile home to the sewer riser pipe shall have a nominal inside diameter of at least three (3) inches and the slope of any portion thereof shall be at least one-fourth (¼) inch per foot. The sewer connections shall consist of one (1) line only without any branch fittings. All joints shall be watertight. 
(2)  Provision shall be made for plugging the sewer riser pipe when no mobile home occupies the lot. Surface drainage shall be diverted away from the riser. The rim of the riser pipe shall extend at least four (4) inches above ground elevation. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(N)) 
Cross reference— Plumbing code generally, § 14-156 et seq.; sewer service, § 102-131 et seq.  
Sec. 58-56. - Electrical distribution system. 
(a)  An adequate and safe electrical distribution system shall be provided in all mobile home parks. 
(b)  A mobile home space having one (1) side immediately adjacent to the perimeter of a mobile home park, except where such perimeter abuts a public road or street, may receive electrical service from an overhead distribution system. All other mobile home spaces within a mobile home park shall receive electrical service by means of an underground distribution system. Service buildings and other park facilities may receive electrical service by means of an overhead distribution system if such building or facility is located within fifty (50) feet from the perimeter of the mobile home park. The location of all underground distribution lines shall be clearly marked by surface signs. 
(c)  Except as otherwise specifically provided, all electrical systems, installations, wiring, connections, fixtures, equipment and appurtenances shall conform to and be designed, constructed, installed, tested, inspected and maintained in accordance with applicable ordinances or regulations of the city or statutes of this state. 
(d)  Individual electrical connections: 
(1)  Each mobile home space shall be provided with an approved disconnecting device and overcurrent protective equipment. The minimum service per outlet shall be 120/240 volts AC, sixty (60) amperes. 
(2)  Outlets, receptacles or pressure connectors shall be housed in a weatherproof outlet box and shall be located not more than twenty-five (25) feet from the over-current protective device in the mobile home. A three-pole, four-wire grounding type shall be used. 
(3)  Connectors, if not substituted by more than one (1) receptacle, shall be provided where the calculated load of the mobile home is more than fifty (50) amperes. 
(4)  The mobile home shall be connected to the outlet box by an approved type of flexible supply cord with a male attachment plug or with pressure connectors. If the distance involved exceeds three (3) feet the cord shall be installed underground. 
(e)  All exposed noncurrent metal parts of mobile homes and all other equipment shall be grounded by means of an approved grounding conductor with branch circuit conductors or other approved method of grounded metallic wiring. The neutral conductor shall not be used as an equipment ground for mobile homes or other equipment. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(O)) 
Cross reference— Electrical code generally, § 14-56 et seq.; electric service, § 102-196 et seq. 
State Law reference— Electric metering in mobile homes, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1446d.  
Sec. 58-57. - Service buildings and other park service facilities. 
(a)  The requirements of this section shall apply to service buildings, recreation buildings and other park service facilities such as: 
(1)  Management offices, repair shops and storage areas; 
(2)  Sanitary facilities; 
(3)  Laundry facilities; 
(4)  Indoor recreation areas; and 
(5)  Commercial uses supplying essential goods or services for the benefit and convenience of park occupants. 
(b)  All portions of a service building, structure or facility shall be properly protected from damage by ordinary uses and by decay, corrosion, termites and other destructive elements. Exterior portions shall be of such materials and be so constructed and protected as to prevent entrance or penetration of moisture and weather. 
(c)  All rooms containing sanitary or laundry facilities shall: 
(1)  Have sound-resistant walls extending to the ceiling between male and female sanitary facilities. Walls and partitions around showers, bathtubs, lavatories and other plumbing fixtures shall be constructed of dense, nonabsorbent, waterproof material or covered with moisture resistant materials. 
(2)  Have at least one (1) window or skylight facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum aggregate gross area of windows for each required room shall be not less than ten (10) percent of the floor area served by them. 
(3)  Have at least one (1) window which can be opened easily, or mechanical device which will adequately ventilate the room. 
(d)  Toilets shall be located in separate compartments equipped with self-closing doors. Shower stalls shall be of the individual type. The rooms shall be screened to prevent direct view of the interior when the exterior doors are open. 
(e)  Illumination levels shall be maintained as follows: 
(1)  General seeing tasks, five (5) footcandles. 
(2)  Laundry room work area, forty (40) footcandles. 
(3)  Toilet room, in front of mirror, forty (40) footcandles. 
(f)  Hot and cold water shall be furnished to every lavatory, sink, bathtub, shower and laundry fixture; and cold water shall be furnished to every water closet and urinal. 
(g)  Service buildings shall be maintained at a comfortable temperature by heating equipment permitted by city regulations, between October 1 and May 1. 
(h)  Cooking shelters, barbecue pits, fireplaces and woodburning stoves shall be so located, constructed, maintained and used as to minimize fire hazards and smoke nuisance both on the property on which used and on neighboring property. No open fire shall be permitted except in facilities provided. No open fire shall be left unattended. No fuel shall be used and no material burned which emits dense smoke or objectionable odors. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(P))  
Sec. 58-58. - Refuse and garbage handling. 
(a)  The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the mobile home park shall be so conducted as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, accident or fire hazards, or air pollution. 
(b)  All refuse shall be stored in flytight, watertight, rodentproof containers which shall be located at each mobile home site. Containers shall be provided in sufficient number and capacity to store properly all refuse. 
(c)  Centrally located refuse containers having a capacity of three (3) cubic yards or larger may be provided. If provided, such containers shall be so designed as to prevent spillage, container deterioration and to facilitate cleaning around them. Refuse and garbage shall be removed from the park at least twice each week. 
(d)  The park licensee or agent shall insure that containers at mobile home spaces are emptied regularly and maintained in a usable, sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(Q)) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, condition and use of premises, ch. 82.  
Sec. 58-59. - Insect and rodent control. 
(a)  Grounds, buildings and structures shall be maintained free of insects and rodent harborage and infestation. Extermination methods and other measures to control insects and rodents shall conform with the requirements of the city health officer. 
(b)  Parks shall be maintained free of accumulations of debris which may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
(c)  The growth of brush, weeds and grass shall be controlled to prevent harborage of noxious insects or other pests. Parks shall be so maintained as to prevent the growth of noxious weeds detrimental to health. Open areas shall be maintained free of heavy undergrowth of any description. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(R))  
Sec. 58-60. - Fuel supply and storage. 
(a)  An adequate and safe underground natural gas distribution system shall be provided in all mobile home parks. 
(b)  Each mobile home space provided with natural gas shall have an approved manual shutoff valve installed upstream of the gas outlet. The outlet shall be equipped with an approved cap to prevent accidental discharge of gas when the outlet is not in use. 
(c)  All natural gas main lines, and all individual mobile home service lines, connections, fixtures and appurtenances shall conform to and be designed, constructed, installed, tested, inspected and maintained in accordance with applicable ordinances or regulations of the city or statutes of this state. 
(d)  No common liquefied petroleum gas system shall be installed in a mobile home park. 
(e)  Individual liquefied petroleum gas containers installed on an individual mobile home space to serve only that mobile home shall be securely, but not permanently fastened to prevent accidental overturning, and shall have a capacity of no more than sixty (60) U.S. gallons gross. All liquefied petroleum gas piping outside of a mobile home shall be installed underground and protected against mechanical injury. Undiluted liquefied petroleum gas in liquid form shall not be conveyed through piping equipment and systems in mobile homes. 
(f)  No liquefied petroleum gas container shall be stored or located outside of or beneath any storage cabinet, carport, mobile home, or any other structure, unless such installations are approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(S)) 
Cross reference— Gas service, § 102-241 et seq. 
State Law reference— Submetering for natural gas in mobile home parks, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6053, § 1a; liquefied petroleum gas in mobile home park, exception from license requirement, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 113.081(c).  
Sec. 58-61. - Miscellaneous requirements. 
(a)  The management of each mobile home park shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  All responsibilities set out elsewhere in this article. 
(2)  The licensee or his agent shall operate the park in compliance with this and other applicable ordinances and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(3)  The licensee or agent shall, in the event of damage to or destruction of mobile homes or facilities within the park by any natural disaster, restore the park to a neat and orderly condition as soon as reasonably practicable after the occurrence of such disaster. 
(4)  The licensee or agent shall notify park occupants of all applicable provisions of this article and inform them of their duties and responsibilities under this article. 
(5)  The licensee or agent shall maintain a register of park occupancy which shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of park residents. 
b.  Mobile home registration data, including make, length, width, year of manufacture and identification number. 
c.  Location of each mobile home within the park by space or lot number, and street address. 
d.  Date of arrival and departure. 
A new register shall be initiated on January 1 of each year, and the old register may thereafter be retired, but shall be retained on the premises for at least three (3) years following its retirement. Registers shall be available for inspection at all reasonable times by any official of the city whose duties may necessitate access to the information contained therein. 
(6)  The licensee or agent shall furnish to the collector of taxes, within ten (10) days after January 1 of each year, a list of all mobile home residents in the park on January 1.
