The list shall contain the owner's name and address; make, length, width, year of manufacture and identification number of the mobile home; and the address or location description of such mobile home within the park. Such lists shall be prepared using forms furnished by the collector of taxes. 
(7)  Within ten (10) days after the first day of April, July and October of each year, the licensee or agent shall furnish the collector of taxes the same data required in subsection (6) of this section on all residents who have moved into the park after January 1 or the previous quarterly report, whichever is later. 
(b)  Each occupant of a mobile home park shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  All responsibilities set out elsewhere in this article. 
(2)  The park occupant shall comply with all requirements of this article and shall maintain his mobile home space, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(3)  The park occupant shall be responsible for proper placement of his utility connections in accordance with the instructions of the park management. 
(4)  Fire resistant skirting shall be required around all mobile homes in mobile home parks and shall be installed by the park occupant within sixty (60) days after placement of the mobile homes. Such skirting shall be uniform throughout the mobile home park and shall be affixed in such manner as to prevent access beneath the mobile home by domestic and wild animals. 
(5)  Skirtings, porches, awnings and other additions, when installed, shall be maintained in good repair. The use of space immediately underneath a mobile home for storage shall be permitted only under the following conditions: 
a.  The storage area shall have a base of impervious material. 
b.  Stored items shall not interfere with the underneath inspection of the mobile home. 
(Ord. No. 71-429, § 3, 5-3-71; Code 1958, § 12A-3(T))  
Secs. 58-62—58-64. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MH-2, MANUFACTURED HOME ZONE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— MH-2, manufactured home zoning district, § 110-84. 
 
Sec. 58-65. - Definitions. 
(a)  HUD code manufactured home means a structure, constructed on or after June 15, 1976, according to the rules of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, transportable in one (1) or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight (8) body feet or more in width or forty (40) body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is three hundred twenty (320) or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designated to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. The term does not include a recreational vehicle as that term is defined by C.F.R. § 3282.8(g). 
(b)  Mobile home means a structure that was constructed before June 15, 1976, transportable in one (1) or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight (8) body feet or more in width or forty (40) body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is three hundred twenty (320) or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems. 
(c)  Additional terms. Other terms herein shall have the meaning defined in other ordinances of the city, except where the context clearly requires otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-66. - Prohibited locations; exceptions. 
(a)  No manufactured home used as a residence shall be located in the City of Lake Jackson outside of the following zones: MH-1 and MH-2. 
(b)  No manufactured home, regardless of use, shall be located in the city and outside of the following zones: MH-1 and MH-2. However, a manufactured home may be located in a planned unit development zone or a planned unit residential zone with the prior approval of the city council. 
(c)  However, the following exceptions are allowed: 
(1)  A manufactured home may be located temporarily in any zone for construction use as provided and regulated by this division. 
(2)  A manufactured home in transit may be located in the city in any zone for not more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
(d)  No manufactured home subdivision shall be located outside of an MH-2 zone. 
(e)  No manufactured home subdivision shall be developed, built, altered, expanded, redeveloped, or rebuilt, except according to this division. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-67. - Inspection. 
Officials of the city may enter the premises of any proposed or existing manufactured home subdivision or of any place where a manufactured home subdivision or of any place where a manufactured home is located, in order to inspect for compliance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-68. - Nonliability. 
The city and its officers, agents, and employees shall have no liability of any nature for any actions, omissions, or other matters in any way concerning the subject matter of this division. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-69. - Other ordinances and laws. 
All other ordinances of the city and all other laws shall apply according to the terms to the subject matter of this division, except as this division expressly and specifically contradicts said ordinances or laws. The fact that this division specifically invokes some other laws and other ordinances shall not mean that still other laws and ordinances not specifically invoked do not apply. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-70. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person who commits any of the following shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00): 
(1)  Any violation of this division; or 
(2)  Providing false information to a city official concerning licensing under this division or compliance with this division. 
Each day or portion of a day during which any violation occurs or continues shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-71. - Site plan required. 
Any person, entity or association that desires to establish, maintain or operate a manufactured home subdivision within the limits of the City of Lake Jackson shall first file a site plan and obtain approval of a site plan from the city planning commission. Said site plan shall meet the requirements of chapter 110 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-72. - Building permits. 
No person shall install any manufactured home, or erect, construct, add to, enlarge, improve, alter, repair, convert, extend, improve, or demolish any manufactured home subdivision, manufactured home site, building, or structure, or any part thereof, or install any plumbing, electrical, or mechanical equipment as a part of such subdivision, site, building, or structure, or cause the same to be done, without first obtaining a building permit from the building inspection department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-73. - Regulations for all manufactured homes. 
These regulations apply to all manufactured homes, wherever located, except as expressly stated otherwise. The standards for construction and installation of manufactured housing within the city are governed by the Texas Manufactured Housing Code. Any standard for construction and installation contained in this division which is different from the standards for construction and installation contained in the Texas Manufactured Housing Code is null and void. All manufactured housing must be installed in compliance with the standards, rules, regulations or administrative orders of the Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-74. - Site requirements. 
(a)  All manufactured homes shall comply with all parking, setback, area, spacing, location, and all other requirements of all other laws and ordinances, including the requirements for slab homes. 
(b)  All manufactured homes shall be elevated to two (2) feet above the center of the street and also above the base flood elevation and be securely anchored to comply with the requirements of the designated FEMA flood zones and the Lake Jackson Flood Hazard Prevention Ordinance. 
(c)  The average height of the bottom of a manufactured home frame above the ground elevation shall not exceed three (3) feet. 
(d)  Manufactured homes shall be installed on a permanent foundation as defined by the Texas Manufactured Home Code, 16 TAC § 69.52, and shall be constructed of concrete. 
(e)  All manufactured homes and manufactured home components shall be installed in compliance with the Texas Manufactured Home Code. "Installation" means: 
(1)  The transporting of manufactured homes or manufactured home components to the place where they will be used by any person other than one registered with the Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs as a manufactured home manufacturer, retailer, broker, salesperson, or installer; 
(2)  The construction of the foundation system; and 
(3)  The placement and erection of a manufactured home or manufactured home components on the foundation system, and includes supporting, blocking, leveling, securing, anchoring, and proper connection of multiple or expandable sections or components, the installation of air conditioning, and minor adjustments. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-75. - Fire safety hazards. 
(a)  No liquefied petroleum gas or flammable liquid may be stored, handled, or dispensed within a manufactured home subdivision or on the premises where a manufactured home is used as a residence, except as provided in this division. 
(b)  Approaches to manufactured homes shall be kept clear for fire fighting purposes, and shall be kept in a neat and orderly condition, free of dry brush, weeds and leaves. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-76. - Water supply and distribution system. 
(a)  All structures in a manufactured home subdivision, and all manufactured homes wherever located, requiring water shall be connected to the public water supply in conformity with the Lake Jackson Plumbing Code and all applicable law. 
(b)  All manufactured home subdivisions shall provide fire hydrants, hydrant locations and water mains in accordance with the Code, to provide fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-77. - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  Septic systems are prohibited in the city. 
(b)  An adequate and safe sewer system shall be provided for conveying and disposing of all sewage from manufactured homes and manufactured home subdivisions shall be connected to the public sewer system. 
(c)  Each manufactured home site and each manufactured home subdivision shall have and install plumbing, sewer service lines and water service lines that confirm to the plumbing code. 
(d)  Any sewer rise pipe shall be plugged when no manufactured home occupies the site. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-78. - Electrical. 
(a)  Each manufactured home shall be provided with an approved minimum electrical service of 100 amp 110/220 volts. However, under no circumstances shall electrical service be provided to a manufactured home that does not meet or exceed the requirements of the manufacturer's installation instructions for the manufactured home to which electrical services are to be provided. 
(b)  All exposed, noncurrent, metal parts of each manufactured home and all other equipment shall be grounded by means of an approved grounding conductor. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-79. - Refuse and garbage. 
Manufactured home subdivisions shall comply with the current city requirement to use plastic bags. Any and all refuse and garbage shall be stored and disposed of in a manner such that it will create no health hazard, rodent harborage, insect breeding, accident hazard, fire hazard, or air pollution and shall be flytight and watertight. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-80. - Fuel supply. 
(a)  Each manufactured home site in a manufactured home subdivision shall be provided with adequate natural gas. Each manufactured home or site with any natural gas supply shall have an approved manual shutoff valve installed upstream from the gas meter four inches above grade, and shall be equipped with an approved cap to prevent accidental discharge of gas when the outlet is not in use. 
(b)  Any individual liquefied petroleum gas containers installed on an individual home site shall serve only that home and shall be securely fastened to prevent accidental overturning, and shall have a gross capacity of no more than sixty (60) WS gallons. All liquefied petroleum gas piping outside of a manufactured home shall be installed underground and protected against mechanical injury. Undiluted liquefied petroleum gas in liquid form shall not be conveyed through piping equipment and systems in a manufactured home. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-81. - Management and responsibility for compliance. 
(a)  The following applies to manufactured home subdivisions: 
(1)  The subdivider shall be responsible for the compliance of all aspects of the manufactured home subdivision with this division and all applicable laws and shall be subject to the penalties provided herein for any noncompliance in said manufactured home subdivision. If the subdivider in fact delegates this duty to any other person or persons, either in fact or by delegation on the license application, then both the subdivider and said person or persons shall bear said responsibility and be subject to said penalties. This paragraph is cumulative and in no way relieves any other person of any responsibility under this division. 
(2)  The manufactured home subdivision shall be composed of individual lots to be occupied by individual manufactured home owners, who shall form an association of home owners to implement the rules of this division and shall serve in the shoes of the original subdivider. 
(3)  In the event of damage or destruction of facilities within the subdivision, the association of home owners shall either close the subdivision or restore the subdivision to compliance with this division as soon as reasonable practicable after the occurrence of such damage or destruction. 
(b)  Each adult owner or occupant of each manufactured home in a manufactured home subdivision shall be responsible for maintaining skirting, porches, awnings, and other additions, when installed, in good repair. Storage items shall not interfere with the underneath inspection of areas beneath the home. The following are acceptable types of skirting: 
(1)  Masonry; 
(2)  Vinyl to compliment the exterior of the manufactured home; 
(3)  Aluminum to compliment the exterior of the manufactured home; 
(4)  Wood to compliment the exterior of the manufactured home. 
(c)  Each adult owner or occupant of a manufactured home, whether located in a manufactured home subdivision or not, shall be responsible for compliance with this division concerning the home and its facilities and premises. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-82. - Site requirements for manufactured home subdivisions. 
(a)  The minimum area which may be developed or used for a manufactured home subdivision shall be five (5) acres. 
(b)  Within a manufactured home subdivision, manufactured home spaces or sites shall be established to comply at all stages of subdivision development with the following requirements: 
(1)  At least ten (10) percent of the total number of manufactured home spaces shall have a minimum front width of fifty (50) feet and provide a minimum area of five thousand (5,000) square feet, inclusive of public utility easements. 
(2)  At least forty (40) percent of the total number of manufactured home spaces shall have a minimum front width of forty-five (45) feet and provide a minimum area of four thousand (4,000) square feet, inclusive of public utility easements. 
(3)  All other manufactured home spaces shall have a minimum front width of forty (40) feet and provide a minimum area of three thousand six hundred (3,600) square feet, inclusive of public utility easements. 
(c)  There shall be constructed and maintained a permanent screening device, not less than six (6) feet in height, on all sides of a manufactured home subdivision, except where natural barriers exist to form all or part of such a screen. A screening device shall consist of a solid masonry or wooden wall or fence, a woven wire or chainlink fence with evergreen shrubs forming a sight screen, or a solid evergreen hedge forming a sight screen. 
(d)  No manufactured home or other structure on a manufactured home site shall be closer than ten (10) feet to the front line of the space or site. 
(e)  No manufactured home shall be closer than ten (10) feet to the property line of the manufactured home subdivision, nor closer than twenty-five (25) feet to the right-of-way line of a public street. 
(f)  No manufactured home or other structure on a manufactured home space shall be located closer than seven (7) feet to the rear line of the space, or closer than five (5) feet to the side line of the space. 
(g)  In addition to all setback requirements, the minimum distance between manufactured homes shall be twenty (20) feet on the side and twenty (20) feet at the rear. 
(h)  The height limit of each structure in the manufactured home subdivision shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet above the ground. 
(i)  Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every manufactured home subdivision shall be paved or covered with stone, screening, or other solid material capable of preventing soil erosion and of preventing dust. 
(j)  Storage facilities with a minimum capacity of one hundred fifty (150) cubic feet per manufactured home space shall be provided on the space or in compounds located within one hundred (100) feet of each space. Storage facilities shall be designed in a manner that will enhance the appearance of the subdivision, shall be faced with masonry, baked enamel, steel or other material equal in fire resistance, durability, and appearance, and shall be securely affixed to the ground. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-83. - Streets, parking and traffic circulation. 
(a)  Streets inside manufactured home subdivisions shall be privately owned, built and maintained, and shall provide safe and convenient access to all spaces and to facilities for common use of park residents. "Interior street" refers to any street in a manufactured home park. 
(b)  Each interior street shall have a minimum width of twenty-seven (27) feet. Interior streets shall be continuous and shall connect to other streets within the subdivision or with public streets, or shall be provided with a cul-de-sac having a minimum diameter of ninety-five (95) feet. No interior street ending in a cul-de-sac shall exceed five hundred (500) feet in length. 
(c)  Interior streets shall be constructed of concrete to the specifications established by the city and shall be maintained free of cracks, holes and other hazards. All such streets shall be provided with concrete curbs and gutters. 
(d)  Two (2) off-street parking spaces shall be provided on each manufactured home space. A parking space shall be a minimum of nine (9) feet wide by eighteen (18) feet long, and shall be located within the boundary of the manufactured home space. Each parking space shall be paved with concrete and located to eliminate interference with access to parking spaces provided for other manufactured homes or parking. 
(e)  A centralized parking area or areas shall be provided within a manufactured home subdivision for parking and storing trailers, visitors' vehicles, and vehicles in excess of two (2) per space. Such parking area or areas shall be hard-surfaced and shall contain a total minimum area of thirty (30) square feet per manufactured home space. 
(f)  Within each manufactured home subdivision, all streets shall be named, and manufactured home spaces numbered to conform with the block numbers on adjacent public streets. Street signs shall be privately installed, owned and maintained, and shall be of reflective material, and of standard size and placement to facilitate location by emergency vehicles. 
(g)  Streets that intersect adjoining public streets shall do so at ninety-degree angles and at locations which will eliminate or minimize interference with traffic on public streets. 
(h)  Street lighting within the manufactured home subdivision shall be provided along all the streets therein and shall conform to all applicable ordinances and laws. 
(i)  All telephone lines shall be installed underground. The subdivision licensee shall provide a public telephone in a well lighted area accessible at all times. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-84. - Recreation area. 
(a)  Each manufactured home subdivision shall have at least one (1) recreation area. Not less than five (5) percent of the gross site area of each manufactured home subdivision shall be devoted to recreational facilities. Recreation areas shall not include parking areas. 
(b)  Any playground space shall be so designated and shall be protected from traffic, thoroughfares and parking areas. Any such space shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and free of safety hazards. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-85. - Service buildings and other subdivision service facilities. 
(a)  All portions of each service building, structure, or facility shall be protected from damage by ordinary uses and by decay, corrosion, termites and other destructive elements. Exterior portions shall be of such materials and be so constructed and protected as to prevent entrance or penetration by moisture or weather. 
(b)  All rooms containing sanitary or laundry facilities shall have sound resistant walls extending to the ceiling between the male and female facilities. Walls and partitions around showers, bathtubs, lavatories, and other plumbing fixtures shall be constructed of dense, nonabsorbent, waterproof material or covered with moisture resistant materials. 
(c)  Each room containing sanitary or laundry facilities shall have at least one (1) window or skylight facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum aggregate gross area of windows for each such room shall not be less than ten (10) percent of the floor area of such room. 
(d)  Each room containing sanitary or laundry facilities shall have at least one (1) window which can be opened easily, or a mechanical device which will adequately ventilate the room. 
(e)  Toilets in service buildings shall be located in separate compartments equipped with self-closing doors. Shower and toilet stalls shall be of individual type and shall be screened to prevent visibility of the interior of the stall when the exterior doors of the room are open. 
(f)  The lighting level shall be at least: 
(1)  Forty (40) footcandles in front of any mirrors and in laundry room work areas; and 
(2)  Five (5) footcandles in other areas. 
(g)  Hot and cold water shall be furnished to every lavatory, sink, bathtub, shower and laundry fixture, and cold water shall be furnished to every water closet and urinal. 
(h)  Service buildings shall be air conditioned and heated with equipment conforming to all applicable law. 
(i)  No fuel that emits smoke or objectionable odors shall be permitted. No open fire shall be permitted except in lawful facilities, as permitted by other law. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-86. - Records. 
(a)  The licensee shall maintain a register of subdivision occupancy, which shall contain the name and address of subdivision occupants, manufactured home registration data, including make, length, width, year of manufacture and identification number, and location of each home within the subdivision by lot or street address. 
(b)  Registers shall be available for inspection at reasonable times by any official of the City of Lake Jackson who deems access to the information contained therein helpful in the performance of his or her official duties. 
(c)  The licensee shall furnish to the tax department for the City of Lake Jackson, within ten (10) days after the first day of January of each year, a list of all home occupants in the subdivision, together with all items contained in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-87. - Temporary construction use. 
Manufactured homes may be located temporarily in any zone during the construction of a permitted or otherwise authorized improvement, if the manufactured home is used in the construction of the improvement. This section includes a manufactured home used as sales offices of the property where such manufactured home is located, but only during construction. Manufactured homes in place under this provision shall not be used as residences or sleeping quarters. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Sec. 58-88. - Unoccupied and unsafe manufactured homes. 
A manufactured home that becomes rundown, dilapidated, unsafe, or a fire hazard shall be considered to be in violation of this Code. The city administrator, fire marshal, or building inspector may cite the operator of the mobile home subdivision or the owner or renter of a manufactured home that becomes rundown, dilapidated, unsafe, a fire hazard, or a nuisance to the welfare of the manufactured home subdivision or the city in general. 
(Ord. No. 99-1593, § 3, 3-15-99)  
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city to make and enforce police regulations, § 2.01. 
Cross reference— Civil emergencies, ch. 22; emergency services, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Preemption of criminal offenses by Penal Code, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 1.08; homosexual conduct, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.06; assault, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 22.01; aiding suicide, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 22.08; criminal mischief, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.03; reckless damage or destruction, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.04; criminal trespass, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 30.05; theft, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 31.03; theft of service, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 31.04; presumption for theft by check, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 31.06; issuance of bad check, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 32.41; bail jumping and failure to appear, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 38.11; disorderly conduct, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.01; public intoxication, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.08; prostitution, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.02; obscene display or distribution, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.22; gambling, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 47.02. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Sale of alcoholic beverages near certain institutions. 
(a)  Under the terms and by the authority vested in cities in V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 109.33, it shall be unlawful for any dealer to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages when the sale is from a place of business located within three hundred (300) feet of a church, public school or public hospital. 
(b)  The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the church or public hospital shall be along the property lines of the street fronts and from the front door to front door, and in direct line across intersections. The measurement of the distance between the place of business where alcoholic beverages are sold and the public schools shall be in a direct line from the property line of the public school to the property line of the place of business, and in a direct line across intersections. 
(Ord. No. 87-1051, § 1, 11-2-87; Ord. No. 00-1638, § 1, 10-2-2000; Code 1958, § 14-1.2)  
Sec. 62-2. - Drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases, when used in this section, shall, for the purposes of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Cocaine spoon means a spoon with a bowl so small that the primary use for which it is reasonably adapted or designed is to hold or administer cocaine, and which is so small as to be unsuited for the typical, lawful uses of a spoon. A cocaine spoon may or may not be merchandised on a chain and may or may not be labeled as a "cocaine" spoon or "coke" spoon. 
(2)  Controlled substance means a substance, including a drug and an immediate precursor, listed in schedules I through V or penalty groups 1 through 4 of the Texas Controlled Substances Act (V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 481.001 et seq.). 
(3)  Marijuana or hashish pipe means a pipe characterized by a bowl which is so small that the primary use for which it is reasonably adapted or designed is the smoking of marijuana or hashish, rather than lawful smoking tobacco, and which may or may not be equipped with a screen. 
(4)  Paraphernalia means an empty gelatin capsule, hypodermic syringe or needle, cocaine spoon, marijuana pipe, hashish pipe or any other instrument, implement or device which is primarily adapted or designed for the administration or use of any controlled substance. 
(b)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, display, furnish, supply or give away any empty gelatin capsule, hypodermic syringe or needle, cocaine spoon, marijuana pipe, hashish pipe, or any other instrument, implement or device which is primarily adapted or designed for the administration or use of any controlled substance. 
(c)  Exceptions. The prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to manufacturers, wholesalers, jobbers, licensed medical technicians, technologists, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, clinical laboratories, medical doctors, osteopathic physicians, dentists, chiropodists, veterinarians, pharmacists or embalmers in the normal lawful course of their respective businesses or professions, nor to common carriers or warehousers or their employees engaged in the lawful transportation of such paraphernalia, nor to public officers or employees while engaged in the performance of their official duties, nor to persons suffering from diabetes, asthma or any other medical condition requiring self injection. 
(Ord. No. 80-732, § 2, 3-3-80; Code 1958, § 14-1.4) 
State Law reference— "Controlled substance" defined, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 481.002(5).  
Sec. 62-3. - Firearms, discharge in city—Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases shall have the following meanings ascribed to them in, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air gun or air rifle means any gun that discharges a pellet, BB, or paintball by means of compressed air, gas propellant, or a spring. 
Archery means the art, practice, or skill of propelling arrows with the use of a bow. 
Arrow means a missile shot from a bow and usually having a slender shaft, a pointed head, and feathers at the butt. 
Bow means a weapon that is made of a strip of flexible material (as wood) with a cord connecting the two (2) ends and holding the strip bent and that is used to propel an arrow or a bolt and includes crossbows and compound bows. 
Crossbow means a weapon consisting of a bow fixed transversely on a stock having a trigger mechanism to release the bowstring, and often incorporating or accompanied by a mechanism for bending the bow. 
Firearm means any device designed, made, or adapted to expel a projectile through a barrel by using the energy generated by an explosion or burning substance or any device readily convertible to that use. Firearm includes, but is not limited to, guns, pistols, revolvers, rifles, shotguns and air guns. 
(Ord. No. 159, §§ 1, 3, 8-17-54; Code 1958, § 14-8; Ord. No. 07-1842, § 1, 4-16-2007; Ord. No. 14-2030, § 1, 1-21-2014) 
Cross reference— Shooting on, along or across public roads, § 62-11. 
State Law reference— Discharge of firearm in public place, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.01(a)(9), (11).  
Sec. 62-3.1. - Firearms, discharge in city prohibited, exceptions. 
(a)  With the exception of subsections (b), (c), and (d), it shall be unlawful for any person to fire, shoot, or discharge within the city, any gun, pistol, revolver, rifle, BB gun, air gun, air rifle or firearm of any description. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the discharge of any firearm by any peace officer in the performance of his official duties. 
(c)  A shotgun, air rifle or pistol, or BB gun may be discharged in an area annexed into the City of Lake Jackson after September 1, 1981, if: 
(1)  The tract of land on which the weapon is discharged is ten (10) acres or more; 
(2)  The discharge is more than one hundred fifty (150) feet from a residence or occupied building located on another property; and 
(3)  The discharge is made in such a manner that it is not reasonably expected to cause a projectile to cross the boundary of the tract. 
(d)  A center fire or rim fire rifle or pistol of any caliber may be discharged in an area annexed into the City of Lake Jackson after September 1, 1981, if: 
(1)  The tract of land on which the weapon is discharged is fifty (50) acres or more; 
(2)  The discharge is more than three hundred (300) feet from a residence or occupied building located on another property; and 
(3)  The discharge is made in such a manner that it is not reasonably expected to cause a projectile to cross the boundary of the tract. 
(e)  This section is not intended to apply to any act prohibited in V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.01. 
(Ord. No. 14-2030, § 2, 1-21-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-2030, § 2, adopted Jan. 21, 2014, supplied provisions to be added to this Code as § 62-4. In so much as § 62-4 already exists in the Code, at the direction of the city, said provisions have redesignated as § 62-3.1 to read as set out.  
Sec. 62-3.2. - Arrows, discharge in city prohibited, exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot an arrow from a bow or crossbow within the city limits, unless: 
(1)  Shot during an archery class approved by the parks director; 
(2)  Shot in an area designated for archery purposes by the parks director; or 
(3)  The tract of land on which the arrow is shot is ten (10) acres or more, the arrow is shot more than one hundred fifty (150) feet from a residence or occupied building located on another property, and the arrow is shot in such a manner that it is not reasonably expected to cross the boundary of the tract. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution that the bow was a toy bow designed to be used by children. 
(Ord. No. 14-2030, § 3, 1-21-2014) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 14-2030, § 3, adopted Jan. 21, 2014, supplied provisions to be added to this Code as § 62-5. In so much as § 62-5 already exists in the Code, at the direction of the city, said provisions have redesignated as § 62-3.2 to read as set out.  
Sec. 62-4. - Ice boxes, refrigerators; abandoned, safety precautions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any warehouse, or storage room, or any unoccupied or abandoned dwelling, building or any other structure, under such circumstances as to be accessible to children, any ice box, refrigerator or other airtight, or semiairtight container which has a capacity of one and one-half (1½) cubic feet or more, and an opening of fifty (50) square inches or more, and which has a door or lid equipped with a latch, or other fastening device, capable of securing such door or lid shut, without first removing such door or lid, snap lock or other locking device from such ice box, refrigerator or container. 
(Ord. No. 81-792, § 1, 6-15-81; Code 1958, §§ 10-5(g)(5), 14-11) 
Cross reference— Storage of solid waste, § 82-68. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.011 et seq.  
Sec. 62-5. - Personal property; use without consent. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to, in any manner, interfere with, take up or use any personal property of any other person without the consent of the owner thereof, or other person in charge of such property. 
(Code 1958, § 14-16)  
Sec. 62-6. - Trespassing on city property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon, enter into or upon any of the property owned or controlled by the city without the consent of the city or some authorized officer, agent or employee of the city; provided, that the word "property," as used in this section, shall not be construed to mean any public highway, street, park or public place in the city. 
(Code 1958, § 14-17) 
State Law reference— Trespass upon state-owned property, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 601b, § 4.12.  
Sec. 62-7. - Damage done by children—Parental responsibility. 
(a)  The parents, parent or legal guardian of a child or children who, in a disposition hearing under the Texas Family Code, is placed on probation or adjudicated a delinquent or who is found guilty in the municipal court arising out of involvement in the destruction, injury, disfigurement, loss, waste or defacement of any public or private property, real, mineral or personal, in the city, without the consent of the owner or person having custody of such property shall be financially liable and responsible for restitution in an amount not to exceed the dollar amount of the damage, as appraised at replacement cost, and to the same extent that said child would be civilly liable under and by virtue of the laws of the state were the child a fully competent adult; provided, that recovery for damage caused by wilful and malicious conduct is limited to actual damages, not to exceed $15,000.00 per act, plus court costs and reasonable attorneys' fees. 
(b)  Involvement in such destruction shall include, but is not limited to, actions by cutting, tearing, breaking, burning, marking, painting, drawing, stamping, stomping, watering, soiling, unscrewing or detaching any object or with any object including, but not limited to, an automobile, any other vehicle or marker, tool, implement, or the human hand or foot when such actions are intended to have the effect of causing damage to property, or results in cost or expense to any person or the public, including water loss from fire hydrants. Any parent or legal guardian herein shall be subject to an order of the judge of the municipal court to make restitution for the damage and destruction caused by the child, herein, when the court, after a full hearing, determines that restitution should be made. Any parent or legal guardian who is ordered to make restitution and fails to comply with the order of the court shall be deemed to be in violation of this Code and shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 1-5 per day, for each day that he is in violation. 
(Ord. No. 78-650, § 1, 2-20-78; Ord. No. 78-660, § 1, 7-17-78; Code 1958, § 14-19.1) 
State Law reference— Liability of parents for conduct of child, V.T.C.A., Family Code § 33.01 et seq.  
Sec. 62-8. - Same—Written notice to parents. 
In the case of an unemancipated minor accused or involvement in destruction under section 62-7, the department of police shall within three (3) days notify the parent or legal guardian in writing, either by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, that such minor has been accused of involvement in destruction, and that said parent or legal guardian may be held financially responsible for restitution resulting from such involvement. 
(Ord. No. 78-650, § 1, 2-20-78; Code 1958, § 14-19.2)  
Sec. 62-9. - Failure to give proper name and address. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he intentionally refuses to report or gives a false report of his name and residence address to a peace officer who has lawfully stopped him and requested the information. 
(b)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 74-520, § 18, 2-4-74; Code 1958, § 14-24)  
Sec. 62-10. - Vandalizing trees, flowers, shrubbery or other beautification projects; reward, appropriation for reward fund. 
(a)  There shall be paid a reward of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the arrest and conviction of anyone guilty of vandalizing trees, flowers, shrubbery or other beautification projects in the city. Such reward shall be payable to persons securing the apprehension or arrest of any such person and shall be payable upon final conviction. 
(b)  The money already collected from private donations shall be established as a separate municipal account. The funds in such account shall be invested for the maximum interest obtainable, and all that portion of the fund that now or in the future exceeds two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be subject to use by the beautification commission of the city for the purpose of purchasing new plants, trees, shrubbery or replacement of any vandalized object connected with a city beautification project. 
(Ord. No. 77-610, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-77; Code 1958, § 14-26) 
Cross reference— Beautification commission, § 2-206 et seq. 
State Law reference— Crime Stoppers Advisory Council, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 414.  
Sec. 62-11. - Shooting on, along or across public road. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he intentionally or knowingly shoots or discharges any gun, pistol or firearm on, along or across a public road. 
(b)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 74-520, § 6, 2-4-74; Code 1958, § 14-8.1) 
Cross reference— Discharging firearms in city, § 62-3.  
Sec. 62-12. - Criminal trespass. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he enters or remains on property or in a building which is not the home of another without effective consent and he: 
(1)  Had notice that the entry was forbidden; or 
(2)  Received notice to depart but failed to do so. 
(b)  For purposes of this section: 
(1)  "Entry" means the intrusion of the entire body. 
(2)  "Notice" means: 
a.  Oral or written communication by the owner or someone with apparent authority to act for the owner; 
b.  Fencing or other enclosure obviously designed to exclude intruders; or 
c.  Signs posted to be reasonably likely to come to the attention of intruders. 
(c)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 74-520, § 2, 2-4-74; Code 1958, § 14-18)  
Sec. 62-13. - Failure to appear. 
(a)  A person lawfully released from custody, with or without bail, on condition that he subsequently appear commits an offense if he intentionally or knowingly fails to appear in accordance with the terms of his release. 
(b)  This section does not apply to appearances incident to probation or parole. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the actor has a reasonable excuse for his failure to appear in accordance with the terms of his release. 
(d)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor if the offense for which the actor's appearance was required is punishable by fine only. 
(Ord. No. 74-520, § 19, 2-4-74; Code 1958, § 14-25)  
Sec. 62-14. - Illegal smoking products and ingestion devices. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases, when used in this section, shall, for the purposes of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Illegal smoking product means: 
(1)  Any of the following substances or chemicals, or any plant or other substance, whether described as tobacco, herbs, incense, spice, or any blend thereof, regardless of whether the substance is marketed for the purpose of being smoked, which includes any one (1) or more of the following substances or chemicals: 
Compound 	Chemical Name 
JWH-018 	1-Pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole JWH-073 1-Butyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole 
JWH-200 	1- (N-morpholin-4-yl)ethyl-3-naphthoylindole JWH-250 1-pentyl-3-(2-methoxyphenylacetyl)indole 
JWH-015 	(2-Methyl-1-propyl-1H-indol-3-yl)-1-naphthalenylmethanone 
JWH-081 	4-methoxynaphthalen- 1-yl- (1-pentylindol- 3-yl)methanone 
JWH-133 	(6aR,10aR)-3-(1,1-Dimethylbutyl)-6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydro -6,6,9-trimethyl-6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran 
JWH-147 	1-hexyl-2-phenyl-4-(1-naphthoyl)pyrrole 
JWH-171 	1-([(1E)-3-pentylinden-1-ylidine]methyl)naphthalene 
HU-308 	[(1R,2R,5R)-2-[2,6-dimethoxy-4-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)phenyl]-7,7-dimethyl-4-bicyclo[3.1.1]hept-3-enyl] methanol 
L-759,633 	(6aR,10aR)-1-methoxy-6,6,9-trimethyl-3-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)-6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydrobenzo[c]chromene 
WIN-55,212 	-2 (R)-(+)-[2,3-Dihydro-5-methyl-3-(4-morpholinylmethyl)pyrrolo[1,2,3-de)-1,4-benzoxazin-6-yl]-1-napthalenylmethanone 
 
(2)  Any products sold, distributed or possessed in the form of incense or herbal smoking blends under the names such as "K-2," "K-2 Summit," "K-2 Sex," "Genie," "Spice," "Dascents," "Zohai," "Sage," "Pep Spice," "Solar Flare," "K-O Knockout 2," "Spice Gold," "Spice Diamond," "Spice Cannabinoid," "Yucatan Fire," or "Fire N Ice"; 
(3)  Salvinorin A; or 
(4)  Any synthetic cannabinoid. 
Ingestion device means any equipment, product, material or object used or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing an illegal smoking product into the human body, including: 
(1)  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipe with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or punctured metal bowl; 
(2)  A water pipe; 
(3)  A carburetion tube or device; 
(4)  A smoking or carburetion mask; 
(5)  A chamber pipe; 
(6)  A carburetor pipe; 
(7)  An electric pipe; 
(8)  An air-driven pipe; 
(9)  A chillum; 
(10)  A bong; or 
(11)  An ice pipe or chiller. 
Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, wholesaler, retailer or any licensed or unlicensed business. 
(b)  Illegal smoking product. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, possess, buy, sell, offer for sale, barter, give, publicly display, deliver, or transfer any illegal smoking product. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, inhale, ingest, or otherwise introduce into the human body any illegal smoking product. 
(3)  Any product containing any of the chemical compounds listed in the definition of "illegal smoking product" shall be subject to the provisions of this section, regardless of whether the product is marketed under names other than those listed in the definition of "illegal smoking product". 
(c)  Ingestion devices. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess an ingestion device with the intent to inject, inhale, ingest, or otherwise introduce into the human body any illegal smoking product. 
(d)  Defenses. 
(1)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that an illegal smoking product or ingestion device was: 
a.  In the possession of a peace officer, or a person acting under the authority of a peace officer, acting in the performance of official duties; 
b.  In the possession of or being used by a governmental entity for a health, research, education, or similar program; 
c.  In the possession of or used by a person under a prescription issued by a licensed physician or dentist authorized to prescribe controlled substances in the State of Texas; or 
d.  In the possession of a person using the illegal smoking product or ingestion device for a religious undertaking or activity of a religious denomination in which they have long standing historic membership supported by documentation from clergy or a spiritual leader. 
(Ord. No. 10-1950, § 1, 10-18-2010)  
Sec. 62-15. - Garage sales. 
(a)  Garage sale means a sale of merchandise conducted on a residential property to the general public. This term includes yard sales, estate sales, neighborhood sales, or any other similar activity. 
(b)  A garage sale may be conducted from a residence twice a year. A garage sale may not last more than three (3) consecutive days. 
(c)  The merchandise may be exhibited or displayed on the private property where the residence is located, but not closer than five (5) feet to the front or side property lines. 
(d)  Garage sale signs must comply with chapter 78. 
(Ord. No. 16-2121, § 1, 11-21-2016)  
Secs. 62-16—62-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ARSON; REWARD FOR INFORMATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-1930, § 1, adopted Feb. 16, 2010, amended Art. II to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, §§ 62-31—62-34, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 12, §§ 1—4, adopted June 30, 1944; and Code 1958, §§ 14-1—14-5 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
State Law reference— Crime Stoppers Advisory Council, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 414; arson, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.02. 
 
Sec. 62-31. - Arson reward. 
(a)  There shall be paid a reward of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the arrest and conviction of anyone guilty of arson committed in the city. Such reward shall be payable to persons securing the apprehension or arrest of any such person and shall be payable upon final conviction. 
(b)  The reward shall be paid out of the general fund. 
(c)  The city manager shall determine the amount of money rewarded. 
(Ord. No. 10-1930, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 62-32. - Notice of reward. 
(a)  The fire marshal is authorized to provide signs notifying the public of any reward authorized by this section. The signs shall be posted at various locations open to the public and all suspected arson locations. Notices may also be given using other modes of communication that the fire marshal may deem effective. 
(b)  The notice shall include, but is not limited to, the following wording: 
$1,000 REWARD 
A REWARD OF UP TO $1,000 IS HEREBY OFFERED BY THE CITY OF LAKE JACKSON FOR INFORMATION LEADING TO THE ARREST AND CONVICTION OF ANY PERSON OR PERSONS GUILTY OF THE CRIME OF ARSON WITHIN THE CORPORATE LIMITS OF THE CITY OF LAKE JACKSON. 
(Ord. No. 10-1930, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Sec. 62-33. - Persons excepted. 
No person employed by the city, the state or any county thereof whose duty is to detect violations of the law or make arrests for violations of the law shall be entitled to this reward. 
(Ord. No. 10-1930, § 1, 2-16-2010)  
Secs. 62-34—62-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOLICITATION 
 
Sec. 62-61. - Solicit on roadway. 
It is unlawful for a person to stand or sit in a roadway, roadway right-of-way, or roadway median, in order to solicit a ride, contribution, money or other items of value, employment, business or to distribute any material to the occupant of any motor vehicle. In this section, "roadway" means any public street that has a speed limit over thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 01-1675, § 1, 11-5-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003)  
Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; amusements and entertainments, ch. 6; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; public park and street use permits, § 86-61 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 90; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98; zoning, ch. 110. 
State Law reference— Municipal parks and recreation, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1015c et seq.; public improvements, bonds, occupancy tax, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1269j-4.1; city parks, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6081h et seq.; local parks and other recreational and cultural resources, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 315, 331 et seq.; lease of land from state parks and wildlife department, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 13.006; recreational boating fees, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.092. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Curfew in certain parks. 
It is unlawful for any person to be in city parks during the following hours, except when scheduled and authorized by the city: 
(a)  Garland, Jasmine, A. A. MacLean, Suggs, and Madge Griffith Parks from midnight to 5:00 a.m. 
(b)  Wilderness Park trails from thirty (30) minutes after sunset to 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  Wilderness Park boat ramps from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
(d)  All other city parks from thirty (30) minutes after sunset to 5:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 91-1178, § 1, 10-21-91; Code 1958, § 14-27.1; Ord. No. 93-1234, § 1, 3-15-93; Ord. No. 99-1592, § 1, 3-1-99; Ord. No. 07-1836, § 1, 2-19-2007; Ord. No. 15-2076, § 1, 8-17-2015)  
Sec. 66-2. - Swimming restrictions. 
It shall be unlawful to swim in any city-owned water areas such as Shy Pond or any other city-owned ponds, lakes, reservoirs, or other waters with the exception of city-operated swimming pools. 
(Ord. No. 81-790, § 1, 4-20-81; Code 1958, § 14-28; Ord. No. 07-1836, § 1, 2-19-2007)  
Sec. 66-3. - Possessing glass beverage containers in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, throw, use for littering, or dispose of a glass beverage container or containers in any city park. 
(Ord. No. 80-759, § 1, 10-20-80; Code 1958, § 14-27; Ord. No. 07-1836, § 1, 2-19-2007) 
State Law reference— Litter, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 365.  
Sec. 66-4. - Skating under pavilions in certain parks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use a skate, skates, or skateboard, scooter device, bicycle, tricycle or any other human powered device with wheels, as well as any battery, electric or motorized vehicle, skate, skateboard or scooter device under, on or in the pavilions located at MacLean and Dunbar Parks. However, any wheel chair or similar device when operated by a disabled person shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 01-1679, § 1, 12-3-2001)  
Sec. 66-5. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City park or municipal park means an area that is zoned or otherwise designated by the city as a public park for the purpose of recreational activity, including but not limited to the Hike and Bike Trail System and Greenway and Linear Parkways as designated in the Parks and Open Space Master Plan, as it currently exists or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 18-2155, § 1, 2-5-2018) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-2155, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 2018, set out provisions adding § 66-1. To preserve the existing § 66-1, and at the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein as § 66-5.  
Secs. 66-6—66-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OYSTER CREEK[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 66-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Operate means to navigate or otherwise use a vessel. 
Vessel means any watercraft used or capable of being used for transportation on water. 
Wake means the track of waves created by a vessel moving through the water that causes a disturbance to other vessels or surrounding property.

Sec. 66-22. - Slow, no wake zone. 
Oyster Creek is declared to be a "Slow, No Wake" zone. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vessel on Oyster Creek in such a manner that the vessel causes a wake. 
(Ord. No. 10-1938, § 1, 5-17-2010; Ord. No. 18-2155, § 1, 2-5-2018)

Chapter 70 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, adopted Feb. 19, 2019, amended ch. 70 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 70, §§ 70-1—70-5, 70-11—70-14, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 203, §§ 1—10, adopted Feb. 19, 1957; Code 1958, §§ 12-1—12-9; Ord. No. 01-1672, § 1, adopted Oct. 15, 2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, adopted Oct. 6, 2003. 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 18; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Municipal licensing of businesses and occupations, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.075; persons who may be regarded as retailers under the Limited Sales, Excise, and Use Tax Act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 151.024; used oil field equipment dealers, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code ch. 112; home solicitation transactions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 5069-13.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Peddler means any person going upon private residential property to sell or take orders for any goods, merchandise or services. 
Solicitor means any person going upon private residential property for the specific purpose of soliciting funds for a cause, including as political or religious causes. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-2. - Non-applicability. 
This chapter does not prohibit people from going uninvited on private residential property to: 
(1)  Distribute written materials; 
(2)  Discuss or disseminate beliefs or ideas such as religious or political views; and/or 
(3)  Circulate petitions. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-3. - Going uninvited upon private residential premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to go upon private residential property without a permit unless invited so to do by the owner or occupant of the private residence. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-4. - Permissible hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for a peddler or solicitor to go upon private residential property, except during the hours from 8:00 a.m. until thirty (30) minutes after sundown unless invited so to do by the owner or occupant of the private residence. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-5. - Prohibitions. 
No peddler or solicitor shall enter upon private residential property where the property has a sign that indicates peddlers and solicitors are not welcome. Phrases such as "no soliciting" or "no peddlers" are sufficient to notify both peddlers and solicitors that they are prohibited from being on the private property. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Secs. 70-6—70-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 70-11. - Application. 
(a)  A peddler or solicitor must apply to the police department for a permit to go uninvited upon private residential property. The application shall contain: 
(1)  The full name, address, and mobile phone number of applicant; 
(2)  The legal name, physical address, and phone number of the person or company he represents; 
(3)  The number of permits needed; 
(4)  The full name, address, and mobile phone number of any other person who will need a permit if that person is over the age of eighteen (18); 
(5)  The social media site that provides information on the organization or person for whom the peddler or solicitor is working; 
(6)  The type of goods, merchandise or services sought to be sold or the cause for which funds are sought to be solicited; 
(7)  Whether such payment shall be collected at the time of sale or solicitation; 
(8)  The period of time applicant wishes to sell or solicit in the city; 
a.  The applicant's signature; and 
(9)  Any other relevant information that the chief of police requests. 
(b)  A permit shall be issued within three (3) business days. 
(c)  The permit shall expire one (1) year after issuance. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-12. - Carrying of permit. 
(a)  The peddler or solicitor must carry the permit whenever peddling or soliciting and show it to any person who asks to see the permit. 
(b)  The permit is non-transferable. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-13. - Denial or revocation of permit. 
(a)  A permit may be denied if 
(1)  The application is incomplete; 
(2)  The permit fee has not been paid; 
(3)  Any information on the application is false; or 
(4)  The applicant has had a previous peddler or solicitation permit revoked within the past five (5) years. 
(b)  A permit may be revoked if 
(1)  Any information on the application is false; 
(2)  The peddler or solicitor has made, or caused to be made, false statements or misrepresentations in relation to the reason for the peddling or solicitation; or 
(3)  The peddler or solicitor violates any of the provisions in this chapter; 
(c)  An applicant may appeal the denial or revocation of a permit by giving written notice of the appeal to the city manager within seven (7) days of the denial or revocation. The city manager shall render a decision within seven (7) days of the notice. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 70-14. - Fees. 
The fee for a permit required by this article shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Any person under this article who conducts business through one (1) or more agents or employees shall, in addition to such fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional agent or employee if they are above the age of eighteen (18). The fees are non-refundable. 
(Ord. No. 19-2177, § 1, 2-19-2019)
