ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 98-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  All terms used in this chapter, unless specifically defined otherwise, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by the Texas Transportation Code. 
(b)  The following terms are specifically defined. 
All day school zone hours, K—4th grade, means from the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:15 p.m. 
All day school zone hours, 5th—8th grade, means from the hours of 6:45 a.m. to 4:15 p.m. 
Commercial vehicle means a vehicle that is designed to carry primarily property behind its passenger area, and that either (1) has a gross combination weight rating that exceeds twenty-six thousand (26,000) pounds or (2) is a truck tractor or a combination truck tractor and semi-trailer. 
Downtown means the triangular area bounded by State Highway 332, Oyster Creek Drive, and Oak Drive. 
Electric personal assistive mobility device means a two-wheeled, self-balancing device that is propelled by an electric propulsion system with an average power of seven hundred fifty (750) watts or one (1) horsepower, i.e. Segways and electric bicycles. 
Motor assisted scooter means a self-propelled device with at least two (2) wheels in contact with the ground, a braking system, a gas or electric motor not exceeding forty (40) cubic centimeters, a deck designed to allow the operator to stand or sit, and the ability to be propelled by human power alone. 
Neighborhood electric vehicle means a vehicle that can attain a maximum speed of thirty-five (35) mph and complies with all federal motor vehicle safety laws. 
Passenger motor vehicle means a passenger car, light truck, sport utility vehicle, motorcycle, or passenger van designed to transport fifteen (15) or fewer passengers, including the driver. 
Pocket bike or minimotorbike means a self-propelled vehicle that is equipped with an electric motor or internal combustion engine having a piston displacement of less than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, is designed to propel itself with not more than two (2) wheels in contact with the ground, has a seat or saddle for the use of the operator, is not designed for use on a highway, and is ineligible for a certificate of title. 
Sidewalk means a paved area running parallel to a street or a paved area in a park that is intended for pedestrian use. 
Split day school zone hours, K—4th grade means from the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and from 3:00 p.m. to 4:15 p.m. 
Split day school zone hours, 5th—8th grade means from the hours of 6:45 a.m. to 8:15 a.m. and from 3:00 p.m. to 4:15 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 1, § 1, 6-30-44; Ord. No. 71-456, § 2, 12-20-71; Code 1958, § 23-1; Ord. No. 10-1944, § 1, 8-16-2010; Ord. No. 12-1992, § 1, 8-6-2012; Ord. No. 12-2002, § 1, 11-19-2012; Ord. No. 16-2093, § 1, 3-7-2016; Ord. No. 16-2110, § 1, 8-8-2016; Ord. No. 16-2120, § 1, 11-21-2016) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, §§ 1—20M.  
Sec. 98-2. - Violations, penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or any rule or regulation made in compliance herewith shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 9, § 1, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-9) 
State Law reference— Penalties for misdemeanors, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 143.  
Sec. 98-3. - Authority of police and other officers—Direction of traffic. 
It shall be the duty of the department of police of this city to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Officers of the department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal in conformance with the provisions of this chapter, provided that upon a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic, as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 2, § 2, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-2) 
Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 54. 
State Law reference— Powers of local authorities, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 27.  
Sec. 98-4. - Same—Making and enforcing rules and regulations by chief. 
The chief of police is hereby empowered to make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 2, § 2, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-3) 
State Law reference— Accidents, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 38 et seq.  
Sec. 98-5. - Applicability of chapter—Government vehicles. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the operator of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the U.S. Government, the state, the county or the city, and it shall be unlawful for any such operator to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or to fail to comply with the rules and regulations herein, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter. 
(b)  The provisions of this section are subject to such specific exceptions as are set forth in this chapter or state law with reference to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 2, § 4, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-6) 
State Law reference— Applicability of state traffic laws, to persons riding animals or driving animal-drawn vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 25.  
Sec. 98-6. - Same—Authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions herein stated. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The exemptions granted under subsections (a) and (b) of this section to the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle apply only when the driver of the vehicle is making use, at the discretion of the driver, in accordance with policies of the state department of public safety or the local government that employs the driver, of audible or visual signals meeting the requirements of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 124, except as provided by subsection (e) of this section and except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle. 
(d)  A police officer who is the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle used for law enforcement purposes may operate without using the emergency warning devices required by this subsection only when the officer is: 
(1)  Responding to an emergency call or when the officer is in pursuit of a suspected violator of the law and the officer has probable cause to believe that: 
a.  Knowledge of the presence of the officer will cause the suspect to destroy or lose evidence of a suspected felony; 
b.  Knowledge of the presence of the officer will cause the suspect to cease a suspected continuing felony before the officer has acquired sufficient evidence to establish grounds for arrest; 
c.  Knowledge of the presence of the officer will cause the suspect to evade apprehension or identification of the suspect or the suspect's vehicle; 
d.  Traffic conditions on a multilaned roadway are such that movements of motorists in response to the emergency warning devices may increase the potential for a collision or may unreasonably extend the duration of the pursuit; or 
(2)  In compliance with written regulations relating to the use of emergency warning devices adopted by the state department of public safety or by the local government that employs the officer. 
(e)  The exemptions granted by subsection (a) of this section apply to a private vehicle operated as an authorized emergency vehicle by a volunteer firefighter only when the vehicle is making use of visual signals meeting the standards of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 124. 
(f)  This section shall not, however, protect the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle from the consequences of a reckless disregard for the safety of others, or of the property of others. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 2, § 5, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-7) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 24.  
Sec. 98-7. - Improper riding. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on any portion of any vehicle not designated or intended for the use of passengers when such vehicle is in motion. This provision does not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of his duty nor to persons riding within truck bodies intended for merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 8, § 13, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-8)  
Sec. 98-8. - Producing unnecessary noise. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate or cause to be used or operated within the city limits of Lake Jackson, Texas, any engine brake or compression brake designed to aid in the braking or deceleration of any vehicle (commonly referred to as "jake braking") that results in excessive, loud, unusual, explosive, or unmuffled noise from the vehicle. 
(c)  Sounds created by emergency equipment for emergency purposes are exempt from this section. 
(d)  Emergency use of the engine brake or compression brake shall be allowed in the event that the vehicle loses normal means to slow down or stop the vehicle. 
(e)  This provision is not intended to prohibit the passage of vehicles equipped with engine brakes or compression brakes, but rather to prohibit the use of such within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 8, § 6, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-44; Ord. No. 08-1881, § 1, 4-21-2008) 
Cross reference— Noise generally, § 38-51 et seq. 
State Law reference— Horns and warning devices, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 133; mufflers, prevention of noise, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 134.  
Sec. 98-9. - Roller skates, in-line skates, street skates and skateboards. 
(a)  For the purposes of this ordinances "skateboard" shall mean and include a single platform which is mounted on wheels and used to propel a person or persons along a surface or through the air while the person is standing (by foot or by hand) on the platform, and the device is moved by human power or a combination of human and motor power. 
(b)  Roller skates and in-line skates shall be allowed in residential areas. 
(c)  No person shall use, operate or ride upon any skateboard, roller skates, in-line skates, or street skates on any street, sidewalk, public parking lot, alley, ditch, way, drive, driveway, esplanade, park or parkway in all of Area J, (known as the original downtown area). No person shall use, operate or ride upon any skateboard, on any street, sidewalk, public parking lot, alley, ditch, way, drive, driveway, esplanade, park or parkway in any business or commercial zone in the city. Roller skates and in-line skates are permitted in business and commercial zones outside Area J. 
(Ord. No. 88-1090, §§ 1, 2, 12-5-88; Code 1958, § 14-32; Ord. No. 97-1424, § 1, 7-7-97)  
Sec. 98-10. - Driving areas, in general. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle, neighborhood electric vehicle, motor assisted scooter, or electric personal assistive mobility device on drainage or utility easements or on the grass or shoulder area of a street, except as permitted in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-1739, § 1, 12-1-2003; Ord. No. 10-1944, § 2, 8-16-2010)  
Sec. 98-11. - Downtown. 
No person shall operate or ride a motor assisted scooter or electric personal assistive mobility device on any sidewalk, alley, ditch, esplanade, park or parkway in downtown Lake Jackson. 
(Ord. No. 03-1739, § 2, 12-1-2003; Ord. No. 10-1944, § 2, 8-16-2010)  
Sec. 98-12. - Motor assisted scooters. 
(a)  A person may only operate a motor assisted scooter on a sidewalk. 
(b)  Exception: 
(1)  A person may operate a motor assisted scooter upon a street if the street has a speed limit of thirty (30) miles per hour or less and: 
a.  The person is merely crossing the street in a crosswalk; or 
b.  The person has been directed to do so by an official traffic control device or police officer. 
(c)  A person operating a motor assisted scooter must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 10-1944, § 2, 8-16-2010)  
Sec. 98-13. - Electric personal assistive mobility devices. 
(a)  A person may only operate an electric personal assistive mobility device on a sidewalk. 
(b)  Exception: 
(1)  A person may operate an electric personal assistive mobility device upon a street if the street has a speed limit of thirty (30) miles per hour or less and: 
a.  The person is merely crossing the street in a crosswalk; or 
b.  The person has been directed to do so by an official traffic control device or police officer. 
(c)  A person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 10-1944, § 2, 8-16-2010)  
Sec. 98-14. - Neighborhood electric vehicles. 
No person may operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on a sidewalk, or upon a street with a speed limit in excess of forty-five (45) miles per hour, unless the person is merely crossing a street with a speed limit in excess of forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 10-1944, § 2, 8-16-2010)  
Sec. 98-15. - Pocket bikes. 
It is unlawful for a person to operate or ride a pocket bike on any street, sidewalk, or public property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-1944, § 2, 8-16-2010)  
Secs. 98-16—98-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Texas Traffic Safety Act of 1967, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701j-1; driver education, V.T.C.A., Education Code § 21.102. 
 
Sec. 98-31. - Established; composition; qualifications, compensation of members. 
There shall be established and maintained a traffic commission of the city consisting of seven (7) voting members, who shall be residents of the city and who shall serve without compensation, and three (3) ex officio members. 
(Ord. No. 72-468, § 1, 6-19-72; Ord. No. 78-655, § 1, 5-1-78; Code 1958, § 23-9.76)  
Sec. 98-32. - Appointment of members; terms of office; ex officio members. 
Seven (7) members of the traffic commission shall be appointed by the city council, four (4) such members to be appointed in each even-numbered year, and three (3) such members to be appointed in each odd-numbered year, the appointments to be made each year within thirty (30) days following the regular election. The term of office of each such member shall be two (2) years. The three (3) ex officio members of the traffic commission shall be a city councilman, to be designated by the city council, the chief of police and the city attorney. Ex officio members shall serve the commission in an advisory capacity but shall have no voting rights, and shall attend meetings as requested by the council or the traffic commission. 
(Ord. No. 72-468, § 2, 6-19-72; Ord. No. 78-655, § 1, 5-1-78; Code 1958, § 23-9.77)  
Sec. 98-33. - Chairman; rules and procedures. 
The commission shall annually elect one of its number as chairman and shall establish its own rules and procedures which shall include the following: 
(1)  A quorum shall consist of the majority of the voting members of the commission and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, the chairman being entitled to vote upon questions. 
(2)  Meetings shall be held not less than once each month, shall be open to the public, and a record of all proceedings shall be kept, which records shall be filed with the person performing the duties of city secretary and shall be a public record. 
(Ord. No. 72-468, § 4, 6-19-72; Code 1958, § 23-9.79)  
Sec. 98-34. - General powers and duties. 
The traffic commission shall be and is hereby vested with the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies regarding the operation and parking of vehicles within the city, including private property used for public purposes. 
(2)  Recommend to the city council for adoption, policies regarding the movement of pedestrians upon the streets and sidewalks of the city by causing to be erected or placed proper signs or markers indicating the flow of pedestrian traffic. 
(3)  Recommend to the city council the location of all necessary signs or markers to be erected or placed on any street or part thereof when the commission shall deem the same necessary. 
(4)  Initiate studies on all vehicular and pedestrian traffic problems within the city, and hold public hearings as necessary with regard to these studies. 
(5)  Perform such other duties and be vested with such other powers as the city council shall from time to time authorize. 
(Ord. No. 72-468, § 5, 6-19-72; Code 1958, § 23-9.80)  
Secs. 98-35—98-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SIGNS AND SIGNALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Signs, ch. 78. 
State Law reference— Local traffic-control devices, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 31. 
 
Sec. 98-56. - Designation of type and location by council; placement and maintenance by chief of police. 
(a)  The city council shall determine and designate by resolution the character or type of all official traffic signs and signals, and shall designate the location where same shall be installed; provided, however, that the chief of police is hereby empowered to erect traffic signs and signals of a temporary nature when emergencies or special conditions exist. 
(b)  Subject to this section, the chief of police is hereby authorized, and it shall be his duty, to place and maintain or cause to be placed and be maintained all official traffic signs and signals. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 3, § 1, 6-30-44; Ord. No. 71-456, § 3, 12-20-71; Code 1958, § 23-10) 
State Law reference— Signs giving notice of one-way traffic, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 59.  
Sec. 98-57. - Presumption of legality of traffic control devices. 
Proof that a traffic control sign, signal or device exists or existed at a specific location within the city shall constitute prima facie evidence of its official and lawful installation. In the prosecution of any person for having disobeyed a traffic control sign, signal or device, it shall not be necessary for the state to prove the authority under which such traffic sign, signal or device was installed. 
(Ord. No. 71-449, § 1, 9-7-71; Code 1958, § 23-10.1)  
Secs. 98-58—98-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 98-81. - Driving through processions. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals or by police officers. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 8, § 1, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-38)  
Sec. 98-82. - U-turns prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall not make a U-turn on any street within the city, except at intersections and at designated turning areas. In this connection, it shall be considered that the driver has made a U-turn when a vehicle is parked in a street central parking area and thereafter the vehicle is driven forward out of the parking area. 
(b)  There shall be no U-turns: 
(1)  In the driveway of the Lake Jackson Recreation Center and MacLean Park (91 Lake Road); and 
(2)  On Lake Road from Canna Lane to Oak Drive between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. on school days. 
(Ord. No. 65-316, § 1, 4-19-65; Code 1958, § 23-42.1; Ord. No. 09-1920, § 2, 11-16-2009)  
Sec. 98-83. - Driving through a street central parking area. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not drive a motor vehicle through a street central parking area within the city. 
(Ord. No. 68-371, § 1, 4-1-68; Code 1958, § 23-42.2)  
Sec. 98-84. - Commercial vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a commercial vehicle upon any street, street right-of-way, street dedication or alley within the city except on the following designated truck routes: 
(1)  F.M. 2004. 
(2)  Old Angleton Road. 
(3)  North Dixie Drive. 
(4)  Highway 332. 
(5)  Highway 288. 
(6)  Oak Drive, from Highway 288/332 to Oyster Creek Drive. 
(b)  An operator of a commercial vehicle is allowed to travel on a street that is not a designated truck route for the purpose of arriving at a destination that is within the City of Lake Jackson city limits. When accessing such a destination, the operator must leave a designated truck route at the intersection that is nearest to his/her destination, proceed by the most direct route, and then return to the nearest designated truck route using the most direct route. The operator must need to reach the destination for the purpose of making a delivery, receiving goods, or performing a service. 
(c)  The following types of vehicles are exempt from this section: emergency, public utility, and government vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 71-445, § 1, 7-6-71; Ord. No. 77-608, § 1, 1-17-77; Ord. No. 88-1076, § 2, 6-20-88; Ord. No. 90-1134, § 1, 9-17-90; Code 1958, § 23-42.3; Ord. No. 96-1389, § 1, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 16-2093, § 2, 3-7-2016)  
Sec. 98-85. - Ready-mixed concrete trucks. 
Weight limits on ready-mixed concrete trucks allowed to travel public roads shall be thirty-six thousand (36,000) pounds for a tandem axle and twelve thousand (12,000) pounds for a single axle, not to exceed forty-eight thousand (48,000) pounds gross total, thus exempting the city from the weight limits established by Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d-12, § 1. 
(Ord. No. 77-631, § 1, 8-1-77; Ord. No. 88-1076, § 3, 6-20-88; Code 1958, § 23-42.4)  
Sec. 98-86. - Speed limits, generally. 
No person shall drive a vehicle on a street or highway at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard for the actual and potential hazards then existing. Except when a special hazard exists that requires lower speeds for compliance with the above, or except as otherwise ordered by the city council, the limits specified in this section shall be lawful, but any speed in excess of the limit specified in this section shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful: 
(1)  In the central business district, twenty (20) miles per hour. As herein used, "central business district" is defined as that portion of area "J" within the city limits bounded by and enclosed within, but not including, Oyster Creek Drive on the north, Oak Drive on the east, and SH 332 on the south and west. 
(2)  Outside the central business district, in all areas not included in subsection (3) of this section or as otherwise provided by the council, thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(3)  When passing an elementary or middle school building or the grounds thereof on days when school is in session, during all day school zone hours, twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 8, § 4, 6-30-44; Ord. No. 71-456, § 5, 12-20-71; Ord. No. 72-472, § 1, 8-7-72; Ord. No. 85-990, § 1, 11-4-85; Code 1958, § 23-43; Ord. No. 07-1833, § 1, 1-2-2007; Ord. No. 12-2992, § 2, 8-6-2012) 
State Law reference— Reckless driving, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 51; authority of municipal governing bodies to alter maximum prima facie speed limits, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 169.  
Sec. 98-86.1. - Speed limits at specific locations. 
Upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation heretofore made as authorized by the provisions of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, the following prima facie speed limits hereafter indicated for vehicles are hereby determined and declared to be reasonable and safe; and such speed limits are hereby fixed at the rate of speed indicated for vehicles traveling upon the named streets and highways, on either side, or parts thereof, described as follows: 
(1)  State Highway 332: 
a.  Along SH 332 from the west city limit to the point of five hundred ninety-seven (597) feet east of Lake Road, a distance of approximately 0.719 mile, the speed limit shall be forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
b.  Along SH 332 from the point of five hundred ninety-seven (597) feet east of Lake Road to the intersection of the bridge under SH 288, a distance of approximately 0.460 mile, the speed limit shall be thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
c.  Along SH 332 Main Lane from its junction with State Highway 288 to the east city limit, a distance of approximately 3.343 miles, the speed limit shall be sixty (60) miles per hour. 
d.  Along SH 332 Frontage Road from its junction with State Highway 288 to the east city limit, a distance of approximately 3.343 miles, the speed limit shall be forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
(2)  On County Road 288 from its crossing of Oyster Creek north to a point five hundred (500) feet north of its intersection with Willow Drive, a distance of approximately 1.0 mile, forty (40) miles per hour. 
(3)  FM 2004: 
a.  Along FM 2004 from the north city limit to one thousand four hundred fifteen (1,415) feet north of SH 332, a distance of approximately 2.782 miles, the speed limit shall be fifty (50) miles per hour. 
b.  Along FM 2004 from one thousand four hundred fifteen (1,415) feet north of SH 332 to one thousand fifty-six (1,056) feet south of SH 332, a distance of approximately 0.468 miles, the speed limit shall be forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
c.  Along FM 2004 from one thousand fifty-six (1,056) feet south of SH 332 to south city limit, a distance of approximately 2.660 miles, the speed limit shall be fifty-five (55) miles per hour. 
(4)  State Highway 288: 
a.  Along SH 288 east frontage road from three thousand sixty-two (3,062) feet north of FM 2004 to one thousand four hundred twenty-five (1,425) feet south of FM 2004, a distance of approximately 0.852 miles, the speed limit shall be forty-five (45) miles per hour.

g.  Along SH 288 main lanes from one thousand four hundred seventy-eight (1,478) feet north of FM 2004 to two thousand six hundred ninety-two (2,692) feet south of FM 2004, a distance of approximately 0.800 miles, the speed limit shall be sixty (60) miles per hour. 
h.  Along SH 288 main lanes from two thousand six hundred ninety-two (2,692) feet south of FM 2004 to six hundred thirty-four (634) feet south of SH 332, a distance of approximately 0.488 miles, the speed limit shall be fifty (50) miles per hour.

Sec. 98-87. - Following emergency vehicles. 
No person shall follow in a motor vehicle any ambulance or police car which is traveling on a public street in response to a report of an automobile collision or accident. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 25-6, 7-17-61; Code 1958, § 24A-6)

The following streets, avenues, drives, and alleys are hereby established to be two-way for the portions and limits as listed in this section: 
(1)  The entire alley that runs between and parallel to Circle Way and Parking Way. 
(Ord. No. 11-1957, § 1, 2-22-2011)

DIVISION 2. - ON PARK, SIDEWALK OR EASEMENT[4]

Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-1904, § 1, adopted April 20, 2009, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 98-101—98-106, pertained to similar subject matter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 98-101. - Operation of motor powered vehicles in parks. 
(a)  A person may only operate a motor vehicle or neighborhood electric vehicle in a park on paved roads. 
(b)  A person may only operate a motor assisted scooter or electric personal assistive mobility device in a park on sidewalks. 
(c)  Exceptions: 
(1)  If there is no road or sidewalk, the operator of a motor vehicle, neighborhood electric vehicle, motor assisted scooter, or electric personal assistive mobility device may drive in a straight uninterrupted line to a facility and immediately park the vehicle. To exit the park, the operator must drive in a straight uninterrupted line to the park's exit. 
(2)  A person may operate a motor vehicle, neighborhood electric vehicle, motor assisted scooter, or electric personal assistive mobility device on grassy areas if the director of parks and recreation or his designee determines that overflow parking on the grassy areas is needed for a special event. 
(3)  A person may operate a motor vehicle, neighborhood electric vehicle, motor assisted scooter, or electric personal assistive mobility device on grassy areas for the purposes of park maintenance or delivery of equipment. 
(4)  At no time may a person park a motor vehicle or a neighborhood electric vehicle within one hundred fifty (150) feet of a playground area.

Sec. 98-102. - Speed limits in parks. 
For the operation of all motor vehicles upon any street that is within a park a speed limit of ten (10) miles per hour is hereby determined and declared to be reasonable and prudent, and any rate of speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour shall constitute prima facie evidence that the speed was not reasonable and prudent and therefore unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 75-560, § 1, 5-19-75; Ord. No. 77-627, § 1, 7-11-77; Code 1958, § 23-66; Ord. No. 09-1904, § 1, 4-21-2009)

ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 98-126. - Owner of illegally parked vehicle presumed to be violator. 
When an unattended motor vehicle is parked, stopped, or left standing on a public street or upon public property within the city in any manner constituting a violation of this chapter or of any applicable law or regulation of this state, proof that such motor vehicle was, at the time of the alleged offense, owned by the person charged with such offense, shall constitute prima facie evidence that such motor vehicle was parked, stopped, or left standing by the owner thereof at the place alleged. 
(Ord. No. 71-450, § 1, 9-7-71; Code 1958, § 23-15.1)  
Sec. 98-127. - Loading and unloading, parking time limit. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or for the loading, unloading, delivery or pickup of materials, in any place marked as a loading zone. In no case shall the stop for loading and for unloading of materials exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 2(b), 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-16)  
Sec. 98-128. - Method of parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any operator to stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway free for movement of vehicular traffic, except on streets on which no parking is allowed during the actual unloading or loading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals or a police officer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any operator to park a vehicle within an alley in such manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any operator to park any vehicle within six hundred (600) feet of any burning building or structure or thing where firefighting apparatus is being used for the purpose of extinguishing same, except under the direction of the chief or other officer of the fire department, or a police officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 6, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-20) 
State Law reference— Where parking is permitted, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 96.  
Sec. 98-129. - Parking time limits; obedience thereto, erecting signs, resolution designating. 
The operator or driver of any vehicle shall not park such vehicle between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day within the district or streets designated by the city council by resolution, except in accordance with the time limit specified on the official signs and signals and other provisions of this chapter; Sundays and legal holidays excepted. Signs shall be placed or erected and maintained in each block designating the provisions of this section upon the passage of such resolution. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 7, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-21) 
State Law reference— Obedience to and required traffic control devices, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 32.
