(5)  The sections of Oak Drive and Oyster Creek Drive that are in front of the entrance and exit to Lake Jackson Fire Station #1 and Fire Station #2. 
(6)  The intersection of That Way and the bus entrance near FM 2004 at Bess Brannen Elementary School. 
(d)  No loading-unloading zones designated. There are hereby designated no loading-unloading of passenger zones in the following areas: 
Oyster Creek Drive, from Circle Way to the Lake Jackson Intermediate School circular drive entrance on Oyster Creek Drive. 
(Code 1958, § 23-21.1; Ord. No. 80-763, §§ 1, 2, 11-17-80; Ord. No. 81-777, §§ 1, 2, 2-2-81; Ord. No. 83-909, § 1, 12-5-83; Ord. No. 84-915, § 2, 2-20-84; Ord. No. 88-1076, § 1, 6-20-88; Ord. No. 92-1203, § 1, 6-15-92; Ord. No. 92-1267, § 1, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 93-1269, § 1, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 94-1287, § 1, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 94-1301, § 1, 7-18-94; Ord. No. 94-1313, § 1, 10-3-94; Ord. No. 95-1355, § 1, 11-6-95; Ord. No. 96-1370, § 1, 3-4-96; Ord. No. 96-1385, §§ 1—3, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 98-1568, § 1, 6-15-98; Ord. No. 99-1618, § 1, 12-20-99; Ord. No. 02-1697, § 1, 9-3-2002; Ord. No. 03-1711, § 1, 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 03-1714, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 05-1790, § 1, 9-6-2005; Ord. No. 06-1826, § 1, 10-2-2006; Ord. No. 08-1890, § 1, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 09-1920, § 1, 11-16-2009; Ord. No. 13-2007, § 1, 3-4-2013; Ord. No. 15-2071, § 1, 7-20-2015; Ord. No. 15-2072, § 1, 8-3-2015; Ord. No. 16-2094, § 1, 3-21-2016; Ord. No. 16-2097, § 1, 4-4-2016; Ord. No. 16-2104, § 1, 6-20-2016; Ord. No. 16-2115, § 1, 10-17-2016; Ord. No. 16-2123, § 1, 11-21-2016; Ord. No. 17-2128, § 1, 3-20-2017; Ord. No. 19-2191 , § 1, 12-16-2019)  
Sec. 98-129.2. - Time limited parking zones designated. 
(a)  The following is hereby designated as a time limited parking zone: 
Circle Way, north side, in downtown Lake Jackson, one (1) space in front of Lake Jackson Flowers and Gifts (26 Circle Way, Lot 13, Block 9, Area J, Brazoria County, Lake Jackson, Texas) with parking limited to periods no greater than fifteen (15) minutes during the hours of 6:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. 
Circle Way, north side, in downtown Lake Jackson, one (1) parking space in front of Champagne Appliances (30 Circle Way, Lots 15 and 16, Block 9, Area J, Brazoria County, Lake Jackson, Texas) with parking limited to periods no greater than fifteen (15) minutes during the hours of 6:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. 
Center Way, south side, in downtown Lake Jackson, two (2) spaces in front of ABC Realty with parking limited to periods no greater than thirty (30) minutes during the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any driver of a vehicle to park or stand his vehicle in the aforementioned parking place for a period of time longer than the time limit specified. 
(Ord. No. 96-1390, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 96-1397, § 1, 10-21-96; Ord. No. 96-1403, § 1, 12-2-96; Ord. No. 97-1429, § 1, 9-18-97; Ord. No. 01-1658, § 1, 4-2-2001; Ord. No. 03-1735, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 04-1756, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-2004; Ord. No. 10-1948, § 1, 10-18-2010; Ord. No. 17-2140, § 1, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 98-129.3. - No turn zones designated. 
(a)  It shall be illegal for a driver to turn left onto That Way from the exit lane of the circular drive in front of Bess Brannen Elementary School from the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 2:45 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. on school days. 
(b)  It shall be illegal for a driver to turn left from south bound That Way into the circular drive of Bess Brannen Elementary School. 
(Ord. No. 07-1871, § 1, 11-19-2007; Ord. No. 08-1890, § 2, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 16-2122, § 2, 11-7-2016) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-1871, § 1, adopted November 19, 2007, enacted provisions intended for use as section 98-129.2. Inasmuch as there are already provisions so designated, and at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as section 98-129.3.  
Sec. 98-129.4. - Right turn only zones designated. 
The following are designated as right turn only lanes: 
The right lane of east bound Oyster Creek Drive at its intersection with North Dixie Drive from the hours of 6:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. Monday through Friday. 
The right lane of north bound Yaupon Street at its intersection with FM 2004. 
The right lane of west bound Plantation at its intersection with Oleander. 
(Ord. No. 11-1965, § 1, 6-20-2011; Ord. No. 11-1977, § 1, 11-21-2011; Ord. No. 16-2113, § 1, 9-19-2016)  
Sec. 98-129.5. - Left turn only zones designated. 
The following are designated as left turn only lanes: 
The left and middle lanes of north bound Yaupon Street at its intersection with FM 2004. 
The left lane of west bound Plantation at its intersection with Oleander. 
South bound That Way into the circular drive of Bess Brannen Elementary School. 
(Ord. No. 11-1977, § 1, 11-21-2011; Ord. No. 16-2113, § 1, 9-19-2016; Ord. No. 16-2115, § 2, 10-17-2016; Ord. No. 16-2122, § 1, 11-7-2016)  
Sec. 98-130. - Disabled parking zones. 
(a)  The city or any political subdivision or any person that owns or controls property used for parking may designate one (1) or more parking spaces or a parking area for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting temporarily or permanently disabled persons. 
(b)  The penalties contained in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6675a-5e.1, § 10 shall apply to any person who parks a vehicle in any parking space or area for the disabled on public or private property designated in compliance with the identification requirements referred to in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6675a-5e.1, § 6A(a) when the person does not properly display the special device designating disabled persons. 
(Ord. No. 84-948, § 1, 10-1-84; Code 1958, § 23-21.2)  
Sec. 98-130.1. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to implement a program under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 681.010 to successfully train and appoint eligible citizens to file a charge or charges against a person or persons who commit an offense under §§ 681.009 or 681.011 by parking a vehicle in a parking space reserved, by the city or by a private owner, for persons with disabilities. A citizen who is appointed under this section must: 
(1)  Be a United States citizen of good moral character who has not been convicted of a felony; 
(2)  Take and subscribe to the same oath of office as other city officials; 
(3)  Successfully complete a training program of at least four (4) hours in length developed by the city administration. 
(b)  A person appointed under this section: 
(1)  Is not a peace officer; 
(2)  Has no authority under this section to enforce a law other than disabled parking ordinances; 
(3)  May not carry a weapon while performing duties under this section; 
(4)  Is not entitled to compensation for performing duties under this section, or to indemnification from the city or the state for injury or property damage the person sustains or liability the person incurs in performing duties under this section, and the city is not liable for any damages arising from an act or omission of a person appointed in performing duties under this section. 
(c)  A person who is successfully trained and appointed under this section shall have the authority to file a charge under the provisions of this section and section 98-130. 
(d)  Any person who violates section 98-130 or this section (98-130.1) shall be subject to a penalty for each violation of one hundred dollars ($100.00) up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) as set out in V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, § 681.011(g)—(l). 
(Ord. No. 99-1604, § 1, 7-6-99)  
Sec. 98-131. - Extended parking for passenger motor vehicles. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to passenger motor vehicles and motorcycles. For the parking of boats, trailers, commercial vehicles, or recreational vehicles, see section 98-152 et seq. 
(b)  Nonresidential areas. Passenger motor vehicles may not be parked on streets in nonresidential areas for more than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours. 
(c)  Residential areas. The following restrictions apply to parking on streets in residential areas: 
(1)  A passenger motor vehicle may be parked for up to seventy-two (72) consecutive hours on that portion of the street that lies alongside residential property the owner or operator of the vehicle owns or occupies. 
(2)  A passenger motor vehicle may be parked for up to seventy-two (72) consecutive hours on that portion of the street that lies alongside residential property if the owner or operator of the vehicle has permission to park from the owner or occupant of said residential property. 
(3)  Disabled passenger motor vehicles may be parked on a street for no more than forty-eight (48) hours if such motor vehicle is protected by flares or other approved signal devices. 
(4)  A passenger motor vehicle may not be parked on that portion of the street that runs alongside residential property that person does not own or occupy or does not have permission to park on from the owner or occupant of said property except for once every seven (7) days for no more than twenty (20) consecutive hours. 
(5)  Passenger motor vehicles on all other areas of residential streets may not be parked for more than seventy-two (72) consecutive hours. 
(6)  Passenger motor vehicles may not be parked in a manner that causes any part of the passenger motor vehicle to extend over a sidewalk. On a residential lot with no sidewalk, no passenger motor vehicles shall be parked within a five-foot setback from the curb edge (that edge of the curb closest to the house). 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 8, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-22; Ord. No. 94-1276, § 1, 1-3-94; Ord. No. 11-1963, § 1, 6-20-2011; Ord. No. 16-2120, § 2, 11-21-2016)  
Sec. 98-132. - Angle parking. 
The city council shall determine by resolution upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall, at the time of such determining, provide for the marking or signing of such streets. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 9, 6-30-44; Ord. No. 71-456, § 4, 12-20-71; Code 1958, § 23-23)  
Sec. 98-133. - Displaying vehicle for sale. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park upon a street any vehicle displayed for the purpose of selling same. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 10, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-24)  
Sec. 98-134. - Displaying for purpose of advertising. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park on any street any vehicle for the primary purpose of displaying advertising. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 11, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-25)  
Sec. 98-135. - Prohibited parking in any private area, unless invited; prohibited parking in fire lanes and fire hydrant zones. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a trespass for any person to park a motor vehicle upon any private parking area within the city unless expressly or implicitly invited to do so by the proprietor of such private parking area. The parking of a motor vehicle so as to block the passage of another motor vehicle from leaving the premises or gaining entry thereto, or parking the vehicle in lanes that are designated as traffic or fire lanes will conclusively negate an implied invitation by the proprietor to park within such private parking area. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a trespass for any person to park a motor vehicle upon any private parking area within the city in an area designated and identified as a fire hydrant zone. 
(Ord. No. 67-353, § 1, 7-3-67; Ord. No. 77-633, § 1, 8-1-77; Code 1958, § 23-26.1)  
Sec. 98-136. - Removal of illegally stopped vehicles. 
(a)  Any commissioned member of the state department of public safety or a peace officer listed under Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 2.12 is hereby authorized to remove, or to require the driver or other person in charge of a vehicle to remove, a vehicle from city property or from a highway, street, or road to the nearest garage or other place of safety, to a garage designated or maintained by the governmental agency by which the officer is employed, or to a position off the paved or main-traveled part of the highway, street, or road, when: 
(1)  Any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway, or in any tube or tunnel where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; 
(2)  Any vehicle is illegally parked so as to block the entrance to any private driveway; 
(3)  Any vehicle is found upon a highway or city property and report has previously been made that such vehicle has been stolen or complaint has been filed and a warrant thereon issued charging that such vehicle has been stolen; 
(4)  Any such officer has reasonable grounds to believe that any vehicle has been abandoned for more than forty-eight (48) hours; 
(5)  A vehicle upon a highway, street, or road or city property is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the owner or person in charge of the vehicle is incapacitated by reason of physical injury or other reason to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or is not in the immediate vicinity of the disabled vehicle; 
(6)  A vehicle upon a highway, street, or road is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the owner or person in charge of the vehicle does not designate a particular towing company or storage company; 
(7)  An officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is by law required to take the person arrested into custody; or 
(8)  In the opinion of the officer, the vehicle constitutes a hazard, or interferes with a normal function of a governmental agency, or by reason of any catastrophe, emergency or unusual circumstance the safety of such vehicle is imperiled. 
(b)  Any law enforcement agency other than the state department of public safety removing an abandoned vehicle in an unincorporated area shall notify the county sheriff. 
(c)  The owner of a vehicle that is removed or stored under this section is liable for all reasonable towing and storage fees incurred in the removal or storage, and any vehicle removed under provisions of this section to any storage facility may not be reclaimed except upon proof of ownership and payment of towing fees and cost of storage. 
(d)  In this section: 
(1)  Towing company means any person who is engaged in the business of towing vehicles on a public highway for compensation or with the expectation of compensation for the towing or storage of vehicles. The term includes the owner, operator, employee, or agent of a towing company. 
(2)  Storage company means any person who is engaged in the business of storing or repairing vehicles for compensation or with the expectation of compensation for the storage or repair of vehicles. The term includes the owner, operator, employee, or agent of a storage company. 
(Ord. No. 71-452, § 2, 10-11-71; Code 1958, § 23-26.2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 94.  
Secs. 98-137—98-145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUS STOPS; TAXICAB STANDS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Vehicles for hire, ch. 106. 
 
Sec. 98-146. - Establishment. 
The city council shall have the right to establish bus stops and taxicab stands on such public streets in such places and in such number as it shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop and taxicab stand so established shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 3, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-17)  
Sec. 98-147. - Use by other vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator or driver of any vehicle other than a bus to stand or park in an officially designated bus stop, or for the operator or driver of any vehicle other than a taxicab to stand or park in an officially designated taxicab stand, except that the operator or driver of any passenger vehicle may temporarily stop in any such stop or stand for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 4, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-18)  
Sec. 98-148. - Use required of buses and taxicabs. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any bus or taxicab to stand or park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the operator of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Ord. No. 13, art. 5, § 5, 6-30-44; Code 1958, § 23-19)  
Secs. 98-149—98-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PARKING OF BOATS, TRAILERS, RECREATIONAL OR COMMERCIAL VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-2161, § 1, adopted Sept. 17, 2018, changed the title of Div. 3 from "Parking of Recreational or Commercial Vehicles in Residential Areas" to read as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 98-151. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ambulance means a specialized vehicle for emergency or non-emergency care and transportation of the sick and/or injured, with a driver compartment and a patient compartment, carrying all equipment and supplies needed to provide emergency medical technician-basic level emergency care at the scene and enroute to an appropriate medical facility, whether or not an emergency may exist. 
Boat or watercraft means any motorized vehicle, registered or unregistered, used for recreation or commercial use on any body of water, river, or stream. 
Bus means any commercial vehicle designed to carry twelve (12) or more persons on streets, roads, or highways. 
Commercial vehicle means any vehicle designed or used primarily for transportation of persons, goods, property, or services for, or in connection with, a business, school, or church. 
Converted bus means a bus that has been converted to transport property or a service. 
Driveway means a private roadway leading from a public street or right-of-way to a garage, carport or parking space. 
Dwelling means a building or portion of a building which is arranged, occupied or intended to be occupied as living quarters and includes facilities for food preparation and sleeping. 
Fire apparatus means any of various large trucks that carry firemen and equipment to the site of a fire, including fire trucks, ladder trucks, hook and ladder trucks, and aerial ladder trucks. The term does not include suburban utility vehicles or pick-up trucks. 
Lease means a conveyance of a commercial vehicle for a specified term and for a specified rent at the fair market value for that particular vehicle. 
Motor vehicle means any motor vehicle subject to registration pursuant to the Texas Certificate of Title Act. 
Park or parking means to stop or stand an occupied or unoccupied vehicle. 
Parking space means an area of a driveway that is at least nine (9) feet wide and eighteen (18) feet long. 
Passenger vehicle means any vehicle which can carry one (1) or more passengers for transportation over a street or highway, including, but not limited to automobiles, trucks, SUVs, vans, or buses. The definition excludes recreational vehicles, golf carts, vehicles with less than four (4) wheels, and vehicles that are not self-propelled. 
Recreational vehicles means any unit primarily designed as a living quarters for recreation, camping, or travel use which either contains its own motor power as in the case of, but not limited to, motor homes, motor coaches, mini-motor homes, or recreational vans; can be temporarily or permanently mounted on a vehicle such as a coach, camper shell, truck camper or pickup camper; or is pulled by a motorized vehicle such as in the case of a "pop-up" camper. 
Trailer means any unpowered vehicle or device designed for carrying property, material, or passengers wholly on its own structure and for being drawn by a motor vehicle, as in the case, but not limited to utility trailer, boat or watercraft trailer, livestock trailer, cargo trailer, horse trailer, barbecue trailer, heavy equipment trailer, and car trailer. 
Truck-tractor means a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing another vehicle and is not constructed to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load to be drawn, such as tractor trailer rigs and ten-wheel tractors. 
Vehicle means any device in, upon, or by which any person or property may be propelled, moved, or drawn or otherwise transported upon a street or highway, except a device which is designed to be exclusively moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. The term "vehicle" shall include, but is not limited to, passenger vehicle, boat or watercraft, trailer, recreational vehicle, truck, motor vehicle, motorized vehicular home, motor coach, bus, converted bus, truck-tractor, and wrecker. 
Wrecker means any motor vehicle used or designed for the purpose of towing or removing disabled or wrecked vehicles. 
Wrecker business means the business of towing or removing disabled or wrecked vehicles, regardless of whether or not the purpose in towing such vehicle is to remove, repair, wreck, store, trade or purchase such disabled or wrecked vehicle. 
Wrecker company means any person engaged in the wrecker business. 
Wrecker rotation list means the rotation list of companies prepared and used as provided in section 106-123. 
(Ord. No. 06-1827, § 1, 12-18-2006; Ord. No. 18-2161, § 2, 9-17-2018)  
Sec. 98-152. - Boats and trailers. 
(a)  No boat or trailer may be parked on a residential street for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, equipment, or materials. In no case shall the boat or trailer be parked on the residential street for more than four (4) hours. 
(b)  Boats and trailers may not be parked in a manner that causes any part of the boat or trailer to extend over a sidewalk. On a residential lot with no sidewalk, no vehicles shall be parked within a five-foot setback from the curb edge (that edge of the curb closest to the house). 
(c)  To the extent of conflict of any other parking ordinances in the city code, this section is intended to prevail. 
(Ord. No. 06-1827, § 1, 12-18-2006; Ord. No. 16-2120, § 4, 11-21-2016)  
Sec. 98-153. - Recreational vehicles. 
Recreational vehicles shall be parked, kept or stored behind a line that is twenty (20) feet forward toward the street from the front building line (set back line as established by zone or plat) of the lot in E-1 and R-1 zoned subdivisions, and shall be parked, kept or stored with all the parts of the vehicle behind the sidewalk in R-2 and R-2a zoned subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 06-1827, § 1, 12-18-2006)  
Sec. 98-154. - Commercial vehicles. 
(a)  Commercial vehicles not owned, leased, or driven by the resident, shall not be parked or left standing on a residential lot except for the purpose of making a delivery, providing a service, or in connection with a house renovation or repair project that concerns the lot and then only during time of delivery, service, or during actual hours of renovation work. 
(b)  In any event, unless during actual hours of delivery, service or renovation work, the following commercial vehicles shall not be parked on a residential lot or in the street in a residential subdivision: 
(1)  Truck-tractors; 
(2)  Trailers designed to be drawn by truck-tractors; 
(3)  Wreckers; 
(4)  Limousines; 
(5)  Public or private buses, including school, church, greyhound, coach or tour buses; 
(6)  Converted buses; 
(7)  Heavy construction equipment, to include but not be limited to: graders, dozers, rollers, cement mixers, backhoes, dump trucks, and the like; 
(8)  Public or private ambulances; 
(9)  Fire apparatuses; and 
(10)  Any commercial vehicle exceeding thirty-five (35) feet in length. 
(Ord. No. 06-1827, § 1, 12-18-2006)  
Sec. 98-155. - Truck-tractor exception. 
(a)  Any owner or operator of a truck-tractor that parks his or her truck-tractor on his or her residential lot as of the date of final passage of the ordinance from which this division derives and who has resided at that residential lot for at least six (6) months may apply for a residential parking permit to continue parking that truck-tractor on that same residential lot. 
(1)  All permit applications and proof of residency must be received by the city manager's office within thirty (30) days after passage of this division. No applications will be accepted after the thirty (30) days have expired. 
(2)  The applicant shall write the truck-tractor's license plate number and vehicle identification number on the permit application. 
(3)  The applicant shall be charged a fee not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00). 
(4)  The original permit shall be kept on file with the police department and a copy of the permit shall be given to the permit holder. The permit holder does not need to display the permit. 
(5)  The permit cannot be transferred to a different: 
a.  Owner or operator; or 
b.  Residential lot. 
(6)  The permit holder must notify the police department within seven (7) days of receiving a new truck-tractor. 
(b)  The permit holder must: 
(1)  Park or cause the truck-tractor to be parked on a concrete pad; 
(2)  Park or cause the truck-tractor to be parked: 
a.  Behind the sidewalk, and 
b.  Not closer than ten (10) feet from a dwelling on an adjacent lot. 
(c)  The permit may be revoked if: 
(1)  The permit holder gave false or misleading information on his or her application; 
(2)  The permit holder or other individual parks the truck-tractor on a residential street; 
(3)  The permit holder or other individual parks the truck-tractor on a residential lot that is not on his or her permit; 
(4)  The permit holder or other individual does not park the truck-tractor on a concrete pad; 
(5)  The permit holder or other individual operates the truck-tractor in a manner that violates state law or this Code while the truck-tractor is on the permitted residential lot; or 
(6)  At least five (5) people who own property within five hundred (500) feet of the lot line of the residential lot where the truck-tractor is permitted to be parked file a sworn affidavit stating that the permit holder is operating the truck-tractor or allowing the truck-tractor to be operated in such a manner that it is a nuisance. The affiants must state specific facts that cause them to believe that the truck-tractor is a nuisance. No more than two (2) people from each household may file the affidavit. 
(d)  Notice of revocation shall be sent to the permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested, setting forth the reason for the revocation and advising the permit holder of the right to an appeal. The permit holder may appeal the revocation decision to the city council by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth the objections to the revocation, within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing stays the action until a final decision on the appeal is made. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day limit, the revocation is final. The city council shall hear the appeal. At the hearing the formal rules of evidence do not apply and the council shall render a decision based upon the preponderance of the evidence. The city council shall make its decision within thirty (30) days after the appeal is filed. If a decision is not rendered within thirty (30) days, the revocation is rescinded. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 06-1827, § 1, 12-18-2006)  
Sec. 98-156. - Wrecker exception. 
(a)  A wrecker company may allow one driver per night to park a wrecker at the driver's residential lot if the wrecker company obtains a residential parking permit from the city and if the residential lot is listed on the permit. 
(1)  Only wrecker companies that are on the city's rotation list may receive a residential parking permit. 
(2)  The city will issue one permit per company. 
(3)  Only wrecker drivers that work for wrecker companies that have a residential parking permit may park a wrecker on a residential lot. 
(b)  Residential parking permit application. 
(1)  A wrecker company can acquire a residential parking permit by filing an application with the city manager. 
(2)  The applicant shall be charged a fee not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00). 
(3)  The permit application shall contain a list of all of the Lake Jackson residential lots where a wrecker will or may be parked. 
(4)  Notice of the permit application shall be sent to the owners of real property lying within five hundred (500) feet of the lot line of the residential lots listed on the application. The owners shall have ten (10) calendar days to give notice, in writing, to the city manager of any objections they have to the wrecker driver parking the wrecker at the residential lot. If at least one of the property owners state that they object to having the wrecker park at said location, then the application will be denied. The wrecker company may appeal this denial in the manner provided for in subsection (g). If no property owners state that they have an objection, then the residential lot shall be listed on the permit. 
(c)  Permit. 
(1)  The permit cannot be transferred to a different wrecker company. 
(2)  The original permit shall be kept on file with the police department and a copy of the permit shall be given to the wrecker company. The wrecker driver does not need to display the permit. 
(3)  Each permit must be renewed annually. The wrecker company must submit the renewal application at least thirty (30) days before the permit expires. If the wrecker company submits the application less than thirty (30) days before the permit expires, the expiration date of the permit will not be affected. The city will follow the notification and objection procedures in subsection (b)(4). 
(4)  If the wrecker company wishes to add a new residential lot to their permit, the wrecker company must notify the city manager in writing. The city manager will then give notice and follow the procedures in subsection (b)(4). 
(5)  The wrecker company must give notice to the police department when a residential lot is no longer qualified to be listed on the permit. 
(d)  Parking the wrecker on a residential lot. A wrecker driver: 
(1)  Shall not park a wrecker that exceeds thirty-five (35) feet in length; 
(2)  Shall only park the wrecker on the residential lot on the days that he or she is on call; 
(3)  Shall only park the wrecker on the residential lot when the wrecker company he or she works for directs the wrecker driver to do so; 
(4)  Shall not park the wrecker on the residential lot more than fifteen (15) days a month; 
(5)  Shall not tow any vehicle to the residential lot; 
(6)  Shall back the wrecker in or park the wrecker behind a fence; 
(7)  Shall park the wrecker on a concrete pad; 
(8)  Shall not park the wrecker closer than ten (10) feet from a dwelling on an adjacent lot; and 
(9)  Shall park the wrecker: 
a.  Behind a line that is twenty (20) feet forward toward the street from the front building line (set back line as established by zone or plat) of the lot in E-1 and R-1 zoned subdivisions; and 
b.  Completely behind the sidewalk in R-2 and R-2a zoned subdivisions. 
c.  On a residential lot with no sidewalk, the wrecker owner or operator shall not park the wrecker within a five-foot setback from the curb edge (that edge of the curb closest to the house). 
(e)  Striking of a residential lot from the residential parking permit. The city will strike a residential lot from the permit if the following occurs: 
(1)  The wrecker driver or other individual parks the wrecker on a residential street; 
(2)  The wrecker driver or other individual parks the wrecker on a residential lot that is not on the residential parking permit; 
(3)  The wrecker driver or other individual operates the wrecker in a manner that violates state law or this Code while the wrecker is on the residential lot; or 
(4)  At least two (2) people who own property within five hundred (500) feet of the lot line of the residential lot where the wrecker is permitted to be parked file a sworn affidavit stating that the wrecker driver is operating the wrecker or causing the wrecker to be operated in such a manner that it is a nuisance. The affiants must state specific facts that cause them to believe that the wrecker is a nuisance. No more than one person from each household may file the affidavit. 
After receiving the affidavits, the city will give the wrecker driver and the wrecker company a written warning and place the wrecker driver on probation. If the city receives another two (2) complaints within one year, the city will strike the residential lot from the permit. The procedures for appeal of the probation and striking are set forth in subsection (g). 
(f)  Revocation of residential parking permit. The permit will be revoked if: 
(1)  The wrecker company gave false or misleading information on its application; 
(2)  Two (2) of the residential lots listed on the residential parking permit are stricken within one year; or 
(3)  The wrecker company violates any section of this subsection. The city will give the wrecker company a written warning and place the wrecker company on probation upon the first violation. If the wrecker company commits a violation within one year from the written warning, the city will revoke the residential parking permit. The procedures for appeal of the probation and revocation are set forth in subsection (g). 
(g)  Notice of a residential lot denial, probation, striking or revocation shall be sent to the wrecker company by certified mail, return receipt requested, setting forth the reason for the action and advising the wrecker company of the right to appeal. The wrecker company may appeal to the city council by filing with the city secretary a written request for a hearing, setting forth its objections, within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing stays the action until a final decision on the appeal is made. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day limit, the action is final. The city council shall hear the appeal. At the hearing the formal rules of evidence do not apply and the council shall render a decision based upon the preponderance of the evidence. The city council shall make its decision within thirty (30) days after the appeal is filed. If a decision is not rendered within thirty (30) days, the action is rescinded. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 06-1827, § 1, 12-18-2006)  
Sec. 98-157. - Parking in residential yards. 
(a)  This section applies only to private residentially zoned property areas that are visible from the right-of-way, including multifamily properties. 
(b)  The parking of a passenger vehicle in an area of private residentially zoned property that is visible from the right-of-way and that is not a driveway, parking space, carport or garage is an offense. It is presumed that the registered owner of the passenger vehicle is the person who committed the offense. However, the owner, lessee, or person in charge of the residential property is also responsible for an offense under this sub-section. 
(c)  The owner, lessee, and person in charge of the residential property are required to ensure that: 
1.  Parking spaces and driveways are graded and paved with an all-weather surface such as concrete, asphaltic concrete, gravel or crushed stone. 
2.  If the parking spaces or driveway are paved with loose material such as gravel, the loose material is compacted and the driveway has a border that prevents the loose material from being scattered. 
3.  The driveway has at least two (2) parking spaces that are behind the sidewalk. 
4.  There is sufficient space from the street to the required parking spaces so that motor vehicles can access the required parking spaces. 
5.  The required parking spaces only contain motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 18-2161, § 3, 9-17-2018)  
Sec. 98-158. - Same—Exceptions. 
(a)  The following activities are exceptions to section 98-157(b). The exception applies only when the listed activity is occurring. Passenger vehicles may not be parked in the yard in anticipation of the activity or after the activity ceases for the day. 
(1)  Loading and unloading of the passenger vehicle; 
(2)  Activities such as construction, remodeling, and landscaping; and 
(3)  Washing of the passenger vehicle. 
(b)  Passenger vehicles may also be parked in the yard for special events, such as parties or overnight guests. The special event may not last more than seventy-two (72) hours. 
(Ord. No. 18-2161, § 4, 9-17-2018)  
Secs. 98-159—98-165. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - AUTOMATED TRAFFIC SIGNAL ENFORCEMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, adopted August 20, 2007, enacted provisions intended for use as article VI, §§ 98-156—98-163. Inasmuch as there are already provisions so designated as subsection 98-156, and at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as article VI, §§ 98-166—98-173. 
 
Sec. 98-166. - Definitions. 
In this article: 
Department shall mean the police department of the City of Lake Jackson, Texas. 
Intersection shall mean the place or area where two (2) or more streets intersect. 
Owner shall mean the owner of a motor vehicle as shown on the motor vehicle registration records of the Texas Department of Transportation or the analogous department or agency of another state or country. 
Photographic traffic signal enforcement system shall mean a system that: 
(1)  Consists of a camera system installed to work in conjunction with an electrically operated traffic-control signal; and 
(2)  Is capable of producing at least two (2) recorded images that depicts the license plate attached to the rear of a motor vehicle that is not operated in compliance with the instructions of the traffic-control signal. 
Recorded image means an image recorded by a photographic traffic signal enforcement system that depicts the rear of a motor vehicle and is automatically recorded on a photograph or digital image. 
System location means the approach to an intersection toward which a photographic traffic signal enforcement system is directed and in operation. 
Traffic control signal shall mean an electronically operated traffic-control device that displays alternating red, amber and green lights that directs traffic when to stop at or proceed through an intersection. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-167. - Imposition of civil penalty for violations. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c), the owner of a motor vehicle is liable for a civil penalty of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) if while facing only a steady red signal displayed by an electronically operated traffic-control signal located within the city, the vehicle is operated in violation of the instructions of that traffic-control device, as specified in V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.007(d). 
(b)  An owner who fails to pay the civil penalty within the time specified in the notice of violation shall be subject to a late payment penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(c)  Failure to pay a civil penalty to contest liability in a timely manner, or to appear at an administrative adjudication hearing as provided for in this article is an admission of liability in the full amount of the civil penalty assessed in the notice of violation, and is a waiver of the right to appeal. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-168. - Enforcement; procedures. 
(a)  The department is responsible for the enforcement and administration of this article. 
(b)  In order to impose a civil penalty under this article, the department shall mail or cause to be mailed a notice of violation to the owner of the motor vehicle liable for the civil penalty not later than the 30th day after the date the violation is alleged to have occurred to: 
(1)  The owner's address as shown on the registration records of the Texas Department of Transportation; or 
(2)  If the vehicle is registered in another state or country, the owner's address as shown on the motor vehicle registration records of the department or agency of the other state or country analogous to the Texas Department of Transportation. 
(c)  A notice of violation issued under this article shall contain the following: 
(1)  A description of the violation alleged; 
(2)  The date, time, and location of the violation; 
(3)  A copy of a recorded image of the vehicle, including the registration number of the license plate, involved in the violation; 
(4)  The amount of the civil penalty to be imposed for the violation; 
(5)  The date by which the civil penalty must be paid and the address to which the payment should be mailed; 
(6)  A statement that the person named in the notice of violation may pay the civil penalty in lieu of appearing at an administrative adjudication hearing; 
(7)  Information that informs the person named in the notice of violation: 
a.  Of the right to contest the imposition of the civil penalty in an administrative adjudication; 
b.  Of the manner and time in which to contest the imposition of the civil penalty; and 
c.  That failure to pay the civil penalty or to contest liability is an admission of liability and a waiver of the right to appeal the civil penalty; 
(8)  A statement that a recorded image is evidence in a proceeding for the imposition of a civil penalty; 
(9)  A statement that failure to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed shall result in the imposition of a late penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00); 
(10)  A statement that, if at the time and place of the violation the vehicle was being operated by a person other than the owner, the owner may transfer liability for the violation to the person who was operating the vehicle at the time and place if the owner submits to the city by affidavit, on a form provided by the city, or under oath at an administrative adjudication hearing, the name and current address of the person: 
a.  Operating the vehicle at the time and place of the violation; 
b.  Who was the lessee of the vehicle at the time of the violation, if the vehicle was rented or leased from a person in the business of renting or leasing motor vehicles at that time; or 
c.  Who was the subsequent owner of the motor vehicle, if ownership of the vehicle was transferred by the owner before the time of violation; and 
(11)  Any other information deemed necessary by the department. 
(d)  A notice of violation under this article is presumed to have been received on the fifth day after the date of notice of violation is mailed. 
(e)  In lieu of issuing a notice of violation, the department may mail a warning notice to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-169. - Administrative adjudication hearing. 
(a)  A person who receives a notice of violation may contest the imposition of the civil penalty by requesting in writing an administrative adjudication of the civil penalty within thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of violation. Upon receipt of a timely request, the department shall notify the person of the date and time of the hearing on the administrative adjudication. The administrative adjudication hearing shall be held before a hearing officer appointed by the city manager. 
(b)  The civil penalty shall not be assessed if after a hearing, the hearing officer enters a finding of no liability. 
(c)  In an administrative adjudication hearing, the issues must be proved at the hearing by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(d)  The following evidence is admissible in the administrative adjudication hearing: 
(1)  An affidavit of an officer or employee of the city or the entity with which the city contracts to install or operate the system and who is responsible for inspecting and maintaining the system attesting to the reliability of the photographic traffic signal enforcement system used to produce the recorded image of the violation; 
(2)  An affidavit of an officer or employee of the city that describes a violation based on an inspection of the pertinent recorded image; and 
(3)  The recorded image upon which the violation is based. 
(e)  A person who is found liable after an administrative adjudication hearing or who requests an administrative adjudication hearing and thereafter fails to appear at the time and place of the hearing is liable for administrative hearing costs in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) in addition to the amount of the civil penalty assessed for the violation. 
(f)  A person who is found liable for a civil penalty after an administrative adjudication hearing shall pay the civil penalty and costs within ten (10) days of the hearing. 
(g)  It shall be an affirmative defense to the imposition of civil liability under this article, to be proven by a preponderance of the evidence, that: 
(1)  The traffic-control signal was not in proper position and sufficiently legible to an ordinarily observant person; 
(2)  The operator of the motor vehicle was acting in compliance with the lawful order or direction of a police officer; 
(3)  The operator of the motor vehicle violated the instructions of the traffic-control signal so as to yield the right-of-way to an immediately approaching authorized emergency vehicle; 
(4)  The motor vehicle was being operating as an authorized emergency vehicle under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 546 and that the operator was acting in compliance with that chapter; 
(5)  The motor vehicle was a stolen vehicle and being operated by a person other than the owner of the vehicle without the effective consent of the owner; 
(6)  The license plate depicted in the recorded image of the violation was a stolen plate and being displayed on a motor vehicle other than the motor vehicle for which the plate had been issued; 
(7)  The presence of ice, snow, unusual amounts of rain or other unusually hazardous road conditions existed and would make compliance with this article more dangerous under the circumstances than non-compliance; 
(8)  The person who received the notice of violation was not the owner of the motor-vehicle at the time of the violation; or 
(9)  The vehicle was being operated by a person other than the owner of the vehicle. 
(h)  To demonstrate that at the time of the violation the motor vehicle was a stolen vehicle or the license plate displayed on the motor vehicle was a stolen plate, the owner must submit proof acceptable to the hearing officer that the theft of the vehicle or license plate had been timely reported to the appropriate law enforcement agency. 
(i)  Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, a person who fails to pay the amount of a civil penalty or to contest liability in a timely manner is entitled to an administrative adjudication hearing on the violation if: 
(1)  The person files an affidavit with the hearing officer stating the date on which the person received the notice of violation that was mailed to the person; and 
(2)  The person requests an administrative adjudication hearing, in writing, within thirty (30) days of the date stated in the affidavit. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-170. - Order. 
(a)  The hearing officer at any administrative hearing under this article shall issues a signed and dated order stating: 
(1)  Whether the person charged with the violation is liable for the violation; and 
(2)  The amount of any civil penalty, late penalty, and administrative adjudication cost assessed against the person. 
(b)  The orders issued under subsection (a) shall be filed with the city secretary. The orders may be recorded using microfilm, microfiche, or data processing techniques. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-171. - Appeal from administrative adjudication hearing. 
(a)  A person who is found liable after an administrative adjudication hearing may appeal that finding of civil liability to the municipal court by filing a notice of appeal with the clerk of the municipal court. The notice of appeal and payment of court costs must be filed not later than the 31st day after the date on which the administrative adjudication hearing officer entered the finding of civil liability. Unless the person, on or before the filing of the notice of appeal, files a notarized statement of personal financial obligation amount of the civil penalty and any late fees, an appeal does not stay the enforcement of the civil penalty. 
(b)  An appeal shall be determined by the municipal court by trial de novo. The affidavits submitted under subsection 98-169(d) shall be admitted by the municipal judge in the trial de novo, and the issues must be proved by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-172. - Effect of liability; exclusion of civil remedy. 
(a)  The imposition of a civil penalty under this article is not a criminal conviction for any purpose. 
(b)  A civil penalty may not be imposed under this article on the owner of a motor vehicle if the operator of the vehicle was arrested for or was issued a citation and notice to appear by a peace officer for the same violation that was recorded by the photographic traffic signal enforcement system. 
(c)  The city attorney is authorized to file suit or cause suit to be filed to enforce collection of a civil penalty imposed under this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)  
Sec. 98-173. - Traffic safety fund. 
The penalties and fees collected from the imposition of civil liability under this article shall be deposited in a separate traffic safety fund account. Funds from the traffic safety fund may be expended only for the costs of automated signal enforcement under this article, public traffic or pedestrian safety programs, traffic enforcement and intersection improvements. 
(Ord. No. 07-1860, § 1, 8-20-2007)
